Chapter 6

Ok now chapter 6. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
# Chapter 6: Shit Gets Weirder Felix texts me sixty times Sunday. I'm not exaggerating. Sixty. I counted. All variations of "I'm sorry" and "please let me explain" and "Eugenie isn't usually like that" and "are you okay" and one that just says "trees are not her normal approach." I ignore all of them because I've got Biology revision and my dad's doing my head in about working in the shop Monday morning before school. "You never help anymore," he goes, like I don't work every Sunday and two evenings a week for literally no money except what I nick from the till. "I've got GCSEs," I tell him. "Your brother managed GCSEs and working." "Yeah and he got all 4s didn't he?" My mum clips me round the head for that but gentle-like because she knows I'm right. Dip's thick as shit and working at Halfords now so not exactly winning at life. Monday morning I'm trying to restock the crisps (we've started doing those posh Tyrrell's ones because gentrification's coming even to our shit area) when Felix appears at the shop door looking like he's been sleeping in a bin. "We're not open," I say through the glass. "Please." "Opens at seven." "Nish, please." My dad appears behind me. "Is this your boyfriend?" "No." "He looks unwell." "He always looks like that." "Does he want black pudding?" I'm going to kill my dad. Actually kill him. Felix's face does something complicated. "We're out," I lie. "No we're not," Dad says, because he's a traitor. "We've got loads. Too much. You want some, son?" Felix nods like a drowning man being offered a life jacket. Dad lets him in because my dad has no survival instincts and would definitely die first in a horror film. Felix buys eight packages of black pudding and demolishes one right there at the counter like it's a Kit Kat. "You weren't at school," I say. "I was dealing with things." "What things?" "Family things." Dad's watching this like it's EastEnders. "You two have a falling out?" "No," I say. "Yes," Felix says. "Which is it?" "His cousin's mental," I tell Dad. "Whose isn't?" Dad says, which fair point. Our cousin Raj thinks he's going to be on Love Island even though he looks like a potato with anxiety. Felix follows me to school which I can't stop him doing because it's a free country innit. He properly corners me behind the languages block where Year 9s go to vape and there's that weird smell that might be cat piss or might be Leon's lynx Africa. "Did Eugenie talk to you?" he asks, urgent. "Yeah, she's mental. Runs in the family clearly." "What did she say exactly?" "Told me to make sure you eat." His whole body relaxes. "That's all?" "Yeah. No wait, she said make sure you feed properly." "Did she say what specifically?" "No, but I assumed black pudding because you're obsessed." He looks so relieved I think he might cry. "She didn't mention the original arrangement?" "What arrangement?" "Nothing. It doesn't matter." "Felix, what arrangement?" But then the fire alarm goes off because of course it does. It's always the fire alarm. If there was an actual fire we'd all die because nobody takes it seriously anymore. We trudge out to the tennis courts for registration and Mr. Henderson's doing a head count but everyone knows it's just Year 10s vaping in the disabled toilets again. They never learn. "What arrangement?" I ask again but Felix pretends he can't hear me over everyone complaining about the cold. He avoids me the rest of the day. Literally turns around when he sees me coming. Sits on the other side of the classroom. At lunch he's nowhere, probably eating black pudding in a cupboard somewhere like the freak he is. Keya finds me after school. "You and Felix had a domestic?" "We're not together." "Madison says you are." "Madison thinks she saw Harry Styles in Primark last week." "Maybe she did." "In our Primark? In the Midlands? Harry Styles?" "Could happen." This is why Keya's pregnant. No critical thinking skills. That night I'm in bed scrolling TikTok when I get a text. Three blood drops. ü©∏ü©∏ü©∏ Same as before but it's a different number. Then: "He's getting hungry." I text back: "who is this" "You know who this is." "eugenie?" "Feed him." "he feeds himself like a big boy" "Not properly." "not my problem" "It will be." Then she sends a photo. It's me at the shop this morning, taken from outside. You can see Felix at the counter and me looking pissed off and my dad in his embarrassing Leicester City pajama bottoms he wears under his trousers when it's cold. "are you stalking me???" "Feed him properly or I will." "that a threat?" "It's a promise." I block the number immediately. Fuck this. Fuck Felix and his mental cousin and their weird black pudding cult or whatever this is. But I screenshot everything first because I'm not stupid. Tuesday Felix is back at the bins before school. "I need more," he says. "Your cousin's threatening me." "What?" I show him the texts. His face does that thing where he looks like he might throw up. "Oh no." "Oh no what?" "She's escalating." "Escalating what?" "The situation." "WHAT SITUATION?" "I can't tell you." "Why?" "Because you'll run." "I'm already running. This is me running. Your cousin's in trees and taking creepy photos and sending me threatening texts about feeding you." "I know." "So tell me what's happening." "I can't." "Felix." "I literally can't. She'll know. She always knows." The thing is, he looks properly scared. Not worried or anxious, but scared like when my brother saw our dad cry that one time. "Is she dangerous?" I ask. "Yes." "To me?" "To everyone." "Felix, what the fuck?" "Just keep bringing me black pudding. Please. I'll pay double. Triple. Whatever. Just until I figure this out." "Figure what out?" But he's already walking away, clutching his Tesco bag of black pudding like it's keeping him alive. Wednesday I get another text: "He's getting hungrier." Thursday: "Soon he won't be able to control it." Friday morning: "Last chance." I don't tell Felix about these texts. I don't know why. Maybe because he already looks like he's dying and I don't want to be responsible for pushing him over the edge. Or maybe because I'm starting to think Eugenie's right. Whatever's happening with Felix, it's getting worse. And I'm right in the middle of it.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 6)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter successfully maintains the darkly comic British YA voice established in earlier chapters while escalating the central mystery around Felix and Eugenie. The narrative follows Nish's distinctive first-person perspective, characterized by cynical observations, casual cruelty, and genuine teenage anxiety beneath the bravado. The chapter excels in character consistency. Nish's voice remains sharp and authentic throughout - her interactions with her father feel genuinely familial, mixing affection with irritation ("My dad clips me round the head for that but gentle-like because she knows I'm right"). Her observations about her brother and cousin are casually mean in ways that feel true to teenage social dynamics. Felix's escalating desperation is well-portrayed through his actions rather than exposition - buying eight packages of black pudding and "demolishing one right there at the counter like it's a Kit Kat" effectively shows his growing need. The plot development serves the overall arc well, introducing Eugenie's direct threats while maintaining the ambiguity about whether this is supernatural or psychological. The escalating text messages create genuine tension, and the inclusion of the stalker photo adds a concrete threat that grounds the supernatural elements in real danger. The dialogue feels natural and distinctly British without being performatively so. Conversations flow organically, particularly the family dynamics in the shop scene. The father's innocent involvement ("Does he want black pudding?") provides both humor and shows how the supernatural intrudes on mundane life. However, the chapter occasionally relies too heavily on coincidental timing (the fire alarm interrupting crucial conversation) and some transitions feel slightly mechanical. The exposition about Felix's avoidance behavior could be more subtle. The ending, while intentionally abrupt per the plan, leaves some emotional beats unresolved. The writing avoids purple prose and forced metaphors, maintaining the conversational tone throughout. The humor emerges naturally from character observations rather than forced jokes. The darkness of the situation (stalking, threats, potential supernatural danger) is balanced with genuine teenage concerns about family, school, and social dynamics. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Compelling Plot: 16 Coherent: 18 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 7 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 6 Amateurish: 5 Purple Prose: 2 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Characters Consistent with Profile: 19 Followed Chapter Plan: 18 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 18

Chapter 7

Ok now chapter 7. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
# Chapter 7: Shit Gets Weirder So that was three weeks ago and honestly I don't know what happened. Felix disappeared. Like properly disappeared, not just off school for a sick day disappeared. His name's not on any register, his phone's dead, even his shit's gone from the murder house (I checked, don't judge me). Madison's parents are getting divorced because of the party but really because her mum's been shagging the builder since January. The party was just the excuse her dad needed. Madison's pretending she's traumatized but she's already planning her two birthdays two Christmases angle. Keya's pregnant. Not Yasmin, which everyone assumed because Yasmin gained weight. Turns out Yasmin just discovered Uber Eats. Keya told everyone at lunch Tuesday, casual as anything, eating chips like "yeah so I'm keeping it." Jordan actually cried. Not cute crying either, proper ugly crying into his Subway sandwich. They're looking at flats now which is mental because neither of them can even drive. But that's all normal shit compared to what's happening to me. I'm still getting the texts. Different number every time so blocking's pointless. Started simple - just blood drops. Then words: "He's getting hungrier" "Feed him" "You promised" "He needs you" "Time's running out" I never promised shit. I sold black pudding to a weird posh boy for profit. That's not a blood oath or whatever this is. The paintings disappeared. I mean they're gone from the internet. I had screenshots on my phone - that Victorian woman with Felix's face, the soldier, all of them. Went to show Keya and they're corrupted files. The museum website's got nothing. Even that local history book I found on Google Books - the pages are missing. Just gone. "File not found." How does that even happen? Thursday the murder house burned down. Nobody reported it. I only know because I was on the bus to Tesco and saw the smoke. By the time I got there (yes I got off the bus to look, shut up) it was just black bones of building and no fire brigade, no police, nothing. Like it burned itself quietly without telling anyone. There's FOR SALE signs up already. "Development opportunity." My brother says they're building flats but my brother also thinks he's going to win the lottery so. I see Eugenie sometimes. Always in Tesco Express, always at the reduced section. Last week she bought twelve packages of black pudding, all the ones with yellow stickers. Winked at me as she left. The security guard didn't even look at her. Nobody ever looks at her except me. "That your mate's cousin?" the guy on the till asked. "How'd you know?" "Looks just like him innit. But fit." Which is gross because she's old (like thirty) but also true. She does look exactly like Felix if Felix wasn't malnourished and actually knew how to do his hair. My dad thinks I'm on drugs now because black pudding keeps going missing and I can't explain it. I'm not even taking it anymore - it's just disappearing. We had twenty packages Monday morning, by Wednesday there's three. "Are you selling them?" Dad asks. "To who? The black pudding dealers?" "Don't be smart." "Don't be stupid." Mum clips me for that but she's worried too. Started checking my arms for track marks like I'm in a Channel 4 documentary about youth gone wrong. The thing that nobody knows - that I'm not telling anyone - is I got my GCSE results early because of some admin fuck up. Straight 9s. Even in French and I don't speak French. The email said "exceptional circumstances" but wouldn't say what circumstances. Birmingham offered me a place for Medicine starting September. Full ride. Scholarship and everything. They never give scholarships to people like me. People from here. But there it is in writing - "exceptional candidate" and "unique potential" and "delighted to offer." I should be buzzing. I should be telling everyone. This is my ticket out, everything I wanted. But I'm not going. Because last night I found something under my pillow. A tooth. Old, like propery old. Wrapped in paper that had one word: "Soon." I know it's from Felix. Don't ask me how, I just know. The tooth is exactly like the ones in his jewelry box, and it smells like him - that weird rust and expensive cologne smell. He's coming back. Or he never left. Or something. Keya thinks I'm having a breakdown. "You've been proper weird since that posh boy left." "I'm fine." "You're not eating." "I'm eating." "You're not. And you keep looking at people's necks." Fuck. I am. I'm doing what Felix did, staring at jugulars like they're interesting. Tom's got a particularly good one. Very visible. Very accessible. "It's stress," I tell her. "What stress? You already got into Birmingham." "How do you know that?" "Your mum told my mum told everyone." Of course she did. The texts are getting more frequent now. Sometimes just coordinates. I looked them up once - it's the bypass, right where the murder house was. Sometimes it's times and dates. Tomorrow, midnight. Sunday, 3am. I never go but they keep coming. Today's was different. "He's so hungry he's forgotten how to be human." Then a photo. It's dark and blurry but there's something in it. A shape in a tree. Could be anything. Could be a big cat. Could be Felix. Could be nothing. I'm going mad. That's what this is. Stress-induced psychosis from GCSEs and my parents and Keya's pregnancy drama. There's no vampires, no Eugenie, no Felix in trees. Just a weird boy who moved away and my brain filling in gaps with horror film shit. But I keep the tooth under my pillow. Just in case.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 7)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter successfully maintains the established voice and tone while advancing the central mystery in appropriately unsettling ways. The writing demonstrates strong command of the unreliable narrator technique, with Nish's voice remaining consistently authentic throughout - her mix of bravado and vulnerability, her tendency to deflect serious moments with sarcasm, and her contradictory nature all ring true to the character profile. The chapter effectively follows its planned trajectory, hitting nearly every plot point outlined in the chapter plan. The pacing works well, moving from the immediate aftermath of Felix's disappearance through various escalating strange events to Nish's growing realization that something supernatural may genuinely be happening to her. The detail about the corrupted photo files and the mysteriously unreported house fire adds effective layers of unreality. The dialogue captures authentic British teenage speech patterns without feeling forced or performative. Nish's conversations with her parents and Keya feel natural, and her internal voice maintains its established rhythm of incomplete thoughts, casual profanity, and defensive humor. However, the chapter suffers from some pacing issues in the middle section, where the catalog of strange events (texts, Eugenie sightings, missing black pudding) feels somewhat listlike rather than building dramatic tension. The revelation about the Birmingham acceptance and scholarship feels underdeveloped - this should be a major moment for Nish but gets glossed over in favor of supernatural elements. The ending with the tooth under the pillow is appropriately unsettling and maintains the ambiguity between supernatural occurrence and psychological breakdown. The detail about Nish beginning to stare at people's necks like Felix did is a nice touch that suggests either supernatural influence or psychological contagion. The writing avoids purple prose and forced metaphors, maintaining the conversational tone throughout. The chapter succeeds in deepening the mystery while keeping readers uncertain about what's real, which aligns perfectly with the stated intention of never fully confirming or denying the vampire elements. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 15 Compelling Plot: 14 Coherent: 17 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5 Amateurish: 4 Purple Prose: 2 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Characters Consistent with Profile: 18 Followed Chapter Plan: 18 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 17

Chapter 8

Ok now finish the story with chapter 8. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
# Chapter 8: I Still Don't Know So that was three weeks ago and I honestly don't know what happened. I'm at the shop right now, it's Thursday afternoon, meant to be revising for Biology retakes even though I got a 9 but Mum doesn't believe me. Dad's in the back arguing with the Walkers delivery guy about cheese and onion proportions. Standard Thursday really. Except I've got twelve packages of black pudding in my school bag. Not selling them. Not eating them. Just... having them. Like how some people carry lucky pennies or whatever. Mine just happen to be processed pig blood that cost me thirty quid I don't have. Keya comes in around four, massive now, waddling like those women on One Born Every Minute. Jordan's with her carrying her bags like a proper boyfriend which nobody saw coming. "You alright?" she asks. "Yeah why?" "You're staring at my neck." "No I'm not." "You literally are." She's right. I am. It's got this vein that's properly visible and I can see her pulse and it's weirdly calming? That's mental. I'm mental. "Sorry. Tired." "You're always tired now." "GCSEs innit." "They're over." "Retakes." "You got all 9s." "How does everyone know that?" "Your mum put it on Facebook." Kill me. Jordan's buying energy drinks even though Keya's not meant to have caffeine but I don't serve him because I see Eugenie outside. She's just standing there on the pavement, looking at our shop window like there's something interesting about our display of out-of-date Pot Noodles. "Back in a sec," I tell Keya. Outside, Eugenie smells expensive. Proper rich person smell, like shops you're scared to go in. "He's coming back," she says. "Who?" "Don't be obtuse." "Felix?" "He's very hungry." "Not my problem." "You still have feelings for him." "I never had feelings for him. He was just some weird posh boy who ate black pudding." She smiles. It's not a nice smile. "You carry black pudding in your bag." How does she know that? "Coincidence." "Twelve packages is not coincidence. It's preparation." "For what?" "For when he comes back wrong." "Wrong how?" But she's already walking away. Not vanishing this time, just walking like a normal person except nobody looks at her. Jordan comes out and walks straight through where she was standing, doesn't even notice. That night I can't sleep. Keep checking my phone for texts but nothing comes. The tooth under my pillow feels warm, which is impossible but there it is. 3am I hear something outside. Not a cat. Bigger. I don't look. Friday's when it happens. I'm in Biology (retaking even though I don't need to but school admin's fucked) when the new kid walks in. It's Felix but it's not Felix. Same face, same stupid posh boy hair, same walk like he's underwater. But his eyes are different. Hungrier. And he's too pale even for February Felix standards. "Class, this is Francis," Mrs. Patel says. "He's just transferred." Francis. Not Felix. Francis. He sits right next to me even though there's loads of empty seats. "Hi," he says, and his voice is Felix's voice but colder. "Hi." "You smell like black pudding." What the fuck do you say to that? "I work in a shop." "No," he says. "You smell like you're carrying it. Twelve packages. In your bag." I look at him properly. Same face. Exactly the same face. But Felix had this softness, this anxiety, this trying-too-hard-to-be-human thing. Francis doesn't have that. Francis looks like he knows exactly what he is. "Want some?" I ask, because what else do I do? "Not yet." "When?" "When you offer it properly." Mrs. Patel's droning about cell division but all I can focus on is not-Felix beside me, smelling like rust and old money and something else. Something wrong. At lunch he follows me. Not like Felix did, all awkward and apologetic. This is deliberate. Predatory. "You knew him," he says. Not a question. "Who?" "My cousin. Felix." "Cousin?" "Distant. Very distant." "Right." "He talked about you." "Did he?" "Said you saved him." "I sold him black pudding." "Same thing, in his case." We're by the bins now, the same bins where this all started. Francis is standing exactly where Felix stood that first morning, but he's not shaking. He's perfectly still. Too still. Nothing about him moves except his mouth. "Is he coming back?" I ask. "Do you want him to?" "I don't care." "Liar." "I'm not‚Äî" "You kept the tooth." "How do you‚Äî" "I can smell it on you. Old calcium and desperation." That's properly mental but also accurate? The tooth does smell desperate, if desperation has a smell. "What are you?" I ask. "Hungry." "That's not an answer." "It's the only answer that matters." He leans closer and his breath is cold, like opening a freezer. "He was weak. Couldn't do what was necessary. But I'm not weak." "What's necessary?" "You'll see." Then he's gone. Not walked away, not even vampire-vanished. Just gone between one blink and the next. I've still got the twelve black puddings in my bag. They're getting heavy. That night I get one text: "Sunday. Midnight. Where it started." The bins. That's where it started. I'm not going. Obviously I'm not going. I'm not stupid. You don't meet maybe-vampires at midnight by bins. That's how you end up on true crime podcasts. But I put the tooth in my pocket. And I charge my phone. And I set an alarm for 11:45. Just in case. Because here's the thing nobody tells you about maybe-vampires: even when they're gone, even when you know they're dangerous, even when every logical part of your brain is screaming run‚Äî You still want to know what happens next. And I've got twelve packages of black pudding and nothing to lose except my life, which in this shit town isn't worth much anyway. Keya texts: "you coming out tomorrow?" I text back: "maybe. depends." "on what?" Good question. Depends on whether Felix is Felix or Francis or something else. Depends on whether Eugenie's threats are real. Depends on whether I'm brave or stupid or both. Depends on whether vampires are real or I'm just having a very specific mental breakdown involving black pudding and posh boys with eating disorders. My dad knocks on my door. "You alright? You've been quiet." "I'm fine." "Your mum's worried." "Mum's always worried." "This is different worried." "I'm fine." "Alright. Don't stay up too late." It's 11:30 now. Fifteen minutes to decide. The tooth is warm in my pocket. The black pudding's in my bag. My phone's charged. I know what I'm going to do. Have known all along, probably. Since that first text, those three blood drops, I've been heading towards this moment. Whatever Felix is, whatever Francis is, whatever's waiting at the bins‚Äî Actually wait, someone's at the door. At midnight? Dad's going mental, shouting about the time. But I can hear the voice and it's
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 8)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter effectively maintains the distinctive voice and tone established in the character profiles and writing plan. Nish's narration continues to feel authentically British teenage - the casual profanity, incomplete thoughts, and social observations ring true. The author successfully balances exposition (catching up on three weeks of events) with forward momentum, using Nish's characteristic rambling style to deliver information naturally. The introduction of Francis as a Felix doppelganger is a clever plot development that raises the stakes while maintaining the ambiguity about whether this is supernatural or psychological drama. The distinction between Felix's anxious, apologetic demeanor and Francis's predatory confidence is well-drawn and creates genuine tension. The writing shows strong technical control - dialogue feels natural, pacing builds effectively toward the cliffhanger, and the voice remains consistent throughout. The author avoids overwriting, letting Nish's personality carry the narrative without forcing metaphors or purple prose. Small details like Keya's pregnancy, the mysterious tooth, and the accumulated black pudding create a sense of mounting unease. However, some elements feel slightly underdeveloped. The Eugenie encounter, while maintaining her mysterious quality, delivers exposition somewhat mechanically. The chapter also relies heavily on setup for future events rather than providing its own dramatic peaks, making it feel more transitional than climactic. The ending works well as a cliffhanger but cuts off abruptly even by serial standards. While this matches the planned "ending mid-conversation," it feels slightly unsatisfying as a standalone reading experience. The character consistency is excellent - Nish's contradictory nature (claiming not to care while carrying twelve black puddings) perfectly matches her profile as someone who "pretends to be above the drama but desperately wants to be included."
