Chapter 4

Ok now chapter 4. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
# Chapter 4: How Long Haven't slept. Three days? Four? The calendar on my phone says October. November. October again. The dates keep changing when I blink. She doesn't sleep either. Lies there every night, practicing. That's what it looks like. Practicing being asleep. Eyes closed at exactly the same pressure. Hands folded the same way. Like she learned it from a book. "How to Sleep: Step One, close eyes. Step Two, be still." I watch her all night. She never moves. Never dreams. People move when they sleep. Tiny adjustments, chasing comfort. She lies like a doll. Like someone arranged her. At 3:47 AM I touch her face. Room temperature. Not warm like sleeping skin. Not cool like death. Just... nothing temperature. Like touching my own hand. I look at my hand. Look at her face. In the dark, they're the same color. Same texture. I can't tell where I end and she begins. "Stop," she says without opening her eyes. "You're awake." "I'm sleeping." "You're talking." "I'm sleep talking." "Sarah‚Äî" "Shh. You'll wake me up." I go to the bathroom. Splash water on my face. In the mirror, I look like a corpse. Eyes sunk so deep they're just shadows. Cheekbones sharp enough to cut. When did I get so thin? I lean closer. The reflection leans back. No. That's not. I lean left. It leans left. Same direction, not mirrored. That's not how mirrors work. "Come to bed." She's behind me in the reflection, but when I turn around, no one's there. "Sarah?" "Come to bed." In the mirror, her mouth doesn't move. Her reflection speaks but she just stares. I make coffee. Instant because my hands shake too much for the machine. Pour hot water. Stir. The spoon clanks against the mug. Clink. Clink. Clink. I can't stop stirring. The sound is the only thing that feels real. She takes the mug. Pours it down the sink. The coffee screams against the metal. No. That's me. I'm making that sound. "You need sleep, not caffeine." "I need‚Äî" What do I need? Can't remember. "Come to bed." "No." "Come to bed." Her hand on my wrist. When did she get so strong? Pulls me toward the bedroom. I resist. She pulls harder. My feet slide on the floor. Like I weigh nothing. Like I am nothing. "Stop." She stops. Looks at me. Her eyes are all pupil. Black circles eating up the white. "You're tired," she says. "I'm scared." "Same thing." Is it? Fear and exhaustion blend together. Can't tell if my heart is racing or stopping. Can't tell if I'm breathing or drowning. Everything is too much and not enough. I try to read. Work emails. The words swim. Jump lines. Rearrange themselves. "Meeting at 2" becomes "Meat at 2" becomes "Meet me" becomes "Me me me me." She reads over my shoulder. Out loud: "You can't stay awake forever." I look at the screen. It says "Quarterly reports due Friday." "That's not what it says." "You're seeing things," she reads. The screen says "Please review attached." "Stop." "I'm only reading what's there," she says. The screen: "She's inside now." I close the laptop. She keeps reading: "Behind your eyes. Under your skin. In the spaces between your thoughts." "STOP." Silence. She's across the room. When did she move? Sitting in my chair. No, her chair. We don't have that chair. We do. We've always had it. My phone rings. I answer without looking. "Hello?" Breathing. Familiar breathing. Seven in, seven out. "Hello?" "Stop fighting," I say. No. The phone says. My voice from the phone. I hang up. It rings immediately. I don't answer. Sarah does. My phone in her hand. When did she take it? "He's ready," she tells no one. "Almost hollow enough." "I'm not hollow." She looks at me. Tilts her head. "Not yet." I need to document this. Write it down. Make it real. Find a pen. Paper. My handwriting looks wrong. Too neat. Too much like hers. Write: "Day four without sleep." Look at it. It says: "Day one of being awake." Write: "Sarah is wrong." It says: "Sarah is right." Write: "Help." It says: "Stop." The pen moves without me. Writes: "Let go." I throw it across the room. Another pen in my hand. Same pen? Writes: "Let go." "I need air." "You're breathing." "I need out." "You are out." I'm outside. On the street. Don't remember leaving. Don't remember the stairs. The sun is wrong. Too low. Too high. Casting shadows in impossible directions. My shadow goes left. Hers goes right. We're standing together but our shadows run away from each other. "Come home," she says. We're home. In bed. She's on top of me. No. Beside me. No. Inside me. Can feel her behind my ribs. Breathing with my lungs. "Get out." "I'm not in." "GET OUT." She laughs. My mouth laughs. I'm not laughing but the sound comes from my throat. I run to the bathroom. Lock the door. Look in the mirror. My face. Her face. My face with her eyes. Her mouth with my scream. "This isn't real." "Real is relative," she says from both sides of the door. "You're not Sarah." "I'm more Sarah than Sarah was." "What does that mean?" "Come to bed and I'll show you." The door is open. Was never closed. Was never there. Just an empty frame. She stands in it. Fills it. Too tall. When did she get so tall? Or am I shrinking? "Please," I say. "I just need to sleep." "Then sleep." "I can't. You'll‚Äî" "I'll what?" Watch. She'll watch. But that's not it anymore. She'll do something worse. Can't remember what. Can't remember why I'm fighting. "Come to bed," she says with my mother's voice. No. Sarah's voice. No. My voice. No difference anymore.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 4)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter effectively captures the disorienting horror of sleep deprivation and reality dissolution, adhering closely to both the writing prompt and the author's stated plan. The fragmented prose style successfully mimics an exhausted, paranoid mindset, with short, punchy sentences that convey the narrator's deteriorating mental state. The chapter excels in creating an atmosphere of creeping dread through mundane details turned sinister - the coffee ritual, the mirror reflection, the pen writing by itself. The author maintains psychological authenticity in depicting severe sleep deprivation, where perception becomes unreliable and time loses meaning. The escalation from watching to possession feels organic within the story's logic. However, the chapter suffers from several weaknesses. The dialogue often feels stilted and artificial, particularly Sarah's responses like "Real is relative" and "I'm more Sarah than Sarah was" - these come across as trying too hard to be profound rather than genuinely unsettling. The repetitive "Come to bed" exchanges become tedious rather than building tension. The prose occasionally veers into forced poetry, with lines like "My shadow goes left. Hers goes right. We're standing together but our shadows run away from each other" feeling more like reaching for effect than naturally arising from the scene. Some metaphors don't quite land, such as comparing fear and exhaustion as "the same thing." The reality distortions sometimes feel arbitrary rather than psychologically grounded - the phone conversation with himself, the instantaneous location changes, and the shifting text on screens pile on without clear internal logic. While disorientation is the goal, the accumulation of impossibilities begins to feel like a checklist rather than organic horror. The characterization remains consistent with the established profiles, showing the narrator's conflict-avoidant nature and Sarah's transformed behavior. The chapter successfully follows the planned progression of reality becoming "negotiable" through exhaustion, though it rushes through too many distortions without allowing them to fully develop their impact. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 14 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Compelling Plot: 15 Coherent: 12 Weak Dialogue: 6 Tell-Don't-Show: 16 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 15 Amateurish: 8 Purple Prose: 7 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 6 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 14 Characters Consistent with Profile: 17 Followed Chapter Plan: 18 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 18

Chapter 5

Ok now chapter 5. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
# Chapter 5: Morning Question Mark Light outside but wrong color. Orange like fire. Purple like bruise. The sky can't decide what time it is. Clock says 3:17. Always says something :17. 5:17. 11:17. The seventeen never changes. She's in the kitchen wearing my college sweatshirt. The one that's too big for her. Except it fits now. Perfect. When did she grow? When did I shrink? I look at my hands. Child hands. No. Old hands. No. Just hands. Can't tell anymore. She's making breakfast. Eggs. Bacon. Toast. It's 3:17 AM. PM? The light says sunset. Sunrise. Both. Neither. "Hungry?" she asks. The smell is wrong. Meat but not meat. Burning but not burning. Sweet like rot. Fresh like copper. "What is that?" "Breakfast." "It's night." "It's morning." I look outside. Stars. Sun. Moon. All wrong. All there. The sky is every time at once. She puts a plate in front of me. Empty. Nothing on it. Just white ceramic. "Eat." "There's nothing‚Äî" "Eat." I pick up the fork. Pretend to cut. Pretend to chew. She watches. Nods. Swallows when I swallow. Her throat moves with mine. "Good?" "I can't taste anything." "You're not trying." I try. Close my eyes. Imagine eggs. Runny yolk. Salt. When I open my eyes, the plate is covered in blood. No. Ketchup. No. Nothing. Empty. Was always empty. "You're getting thin," she says. I look down. Can see my ribs through my shirt. Bones like piano keys. When did I take my shirt off? I'm wearing a shirt. I'm not wearing a shirt. Both true. "You should eat more," she says, chewing nothing. Swallowing air. The light changes. Darker. Brighter. Strobe. No, just clouds. No clouds. The sky is clear. The sky is black. The kitchen is lit by nothing. By everything. She stands. Sits. Stands. Or I'm blinking wrong. Missing frames. She moves like a broken film. Here. There. Here. "I need to brush my teeth." "You just did." My mouth tastes like mint. Like copper. Like nothing. In the bathroom, she's already there. Brushing my teeth. Her teeth. Our teeth. The mirror shows her but I feel the brush in my mouth. She spits. I taste it. "Better?" "That's not‚Äîhow did you‚Äî" "We've always done it this way." Have we? Memory is soup. Everything floating, nothing connected. Remember meeting her at a party. At work. Online. Never met her. Always knew her. She's my wife. Girlfriend. Stranger. Sister. Self. "Come back to bed." "We just woke up." "We never went to sleep." "What day is it?" "Yes." That's not an answer. Or it is. Days don't work anymore. Monday Tuesday Wednesday Whenday Whyday Why. She's in bed. Pat's the space beside her. I sit on the edge. She pulls me down. Strong. Stronger than yesterday. When was yesterday? "Close your eyes." "No." "Just rest them." "You'll watch." "I'm always watching." "That's the problem." "That's the solution." She's above me. Below me. Beside me. Angles don't work in the bed. It's too small. Too big. Just right. We're too close. Too far. Occupying the same space. "Breathe with me." "I am." "Deeper." I breathe deep. She breathes shallow. I breathe shallow. She doesn't breathe. We breathe together. In out in out. But opposite. But same. My chest rises, hers falls. Conservation of air. There's only enough for one. "I'm suffocating." "You're fine." "I can't‚Äî" She puts her hand over my mouth. Her mouth. My hand. Can't tell anymore. Everything is everything. "Watch me," she says. I watch. Her eyes are mine. Same color. Same shape. Same fear inside them. No. She's not afraid. I'm afraid. She's nothing. She's everything. "Blink." I blink. "Again." I blink. We're playing a game. Staring contest. Used to play as kids. With my sister. I don't have a sister. With Sarah. Sarah is my sister. Girlfriend. Mother. Self. Her eyes don't water. Mine stream. Tears but not crying. Just physics. Just failure. She doesn't need to blink. Doesn't need anything. "You lose," she says. "I wasn't playing." "You're always playing." The room is dark. Light. Dark. The sun sets rises sets rises. Days in seconds. Seconds in days. She hasn't moved. I haven't moved. We've been here forever. We just arrived. My stomach hurts. Empty. Full. Can't remember eating. Can't remember not eating. She feeds me nothing. I'm getting full on nothing. "What are you?" I ask. "Sarah." "What were you?" "Sarah." "What will you be?" She smiles. My smile. On her face. On my face. No difference. "You," she says. "I'm me." "For now." The clock says 3:17. I check my phone. 3:17. The microwave. 3:17. Time stopped. Time never started. We're in the moment between moments. The space between tick and tock. "Let me go." "Go where?" Good question. There's nowhere else. Just this room. This bed. This watching. The apartment has no doors. Never had doors. Can't leave somewhere that has no exit. "I want to go home." "You are home." "This isn't‚Äî" "Where else would home be?" I try to remember. There was somewhere else. Before this. Before her. But the before is fading. Eaten by the now. By the watching. By the way she knows everything before I think it. "Sleep," she says. "Can't." "Won't." "Same thing." "No," she says. "Can't is over. Only won't remains." She's right. My body gave up asking. Doesn't want sleep anymore. Doesn't want anything. Just exists. Just watches her watching me watching her watching. "I love you," she says with my voice. "That's not‚Äî" "I love you," I say with her voice. We're talking. Not talking. Mouths move wrong. Sound comes from nowhere. From everywhere. The walls say I love you. The ceiling says I love you. The nothing on my plate says I love you. "Stop." "Stop what?" "Everything." "Okay." Everything stops. My heart. My breath. The world outside. All frozen. Except her eyes. Still watching. Always watching. Forever watching. Then it starts again and I'm gasping and she's laughing and the clock says 3:18. One minute. We lost one minute. Or gained it. Or it never existed. "Progress," she says.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 5)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter effectively continues the possession horror narrative with increasing psychological fragmentation. The model demonstrates strong adherence to its established plan, hitting most of the prescribed beats including the wrong-colored light, kitchen scene with ill-fitting clothes, the persistent 3:17 timestamp, empty plate feeding, tooth brushing, and the blinking contest conclusion. The writing successfully employs fragmentation techniques to mirror the narrator's deteriorating mental state. Sentences like "Child hands. No. Old hands. No. Just hands" and "Monday Tuesday Wednesday Whenday Whyday Why" effectively convey disorientation without becoming incomprehensible. The temporal confusion is well-executed, with time becoming elastic and contradictory. The horror escalation feels natural, building on established elements while introducing new impossibilities like the shared breathing and identity blurring. The entity's growing strength and the narrator's physical deterioration create effective body horror elements. The dialogue maintains the unsettling quality established in previous chapters, with Sarah's responses becoming increasingly alien. However, some passages veer toward overwrought territory. Lines like "Memory is soup. Everything floating, nothing connected" and the repetitive "No. Yes. Both. Neither" pattern, while serving the disorientation theme, occasionally feel forced rather than organic. The metaphorical language sometimes prioritizes style over clarity or impact. The character consistency is strong - the narrator's conflict avoidance and self-doubt align perfectly with their profile, while Sarah's transformation continues the established trajectory. The physical details (seeing ribs, empty plates, temperature confusion) ground the supernatural elements in visceral reality. The chapter successfully maintains the "no explanation" approach outlined in the plan, letting the horror exist without resolution or understanding. The identity blurring ("Her eyes are mine") effectively builds toward the planned convergence while maintaining individual agency for now. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Compelling Plot: 16 Coherent: 15 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 6 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5 Amateurish: 4 Purple Prose: 8 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 9 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Characters Consistent with Profile: 18 Followed Chapter Plan: 18 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 17

Chapter 6

Ok now chapter 6. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
# Chapter 6: Our Bed Wake up. Still tired. When did I sleep? Didn't sleep. Can't sleep. She's under the covers with me. Behind me. Arms around me. Through me. Arms inside my arms. I lift my hand. Four hands rise. Two mine. Two hers. All mine. All hers. "Morning," she says. I say it too. Didn't mean to. My mouth moves with hers. Same word. Same time. Same voice. Try to sit up. We sit up. Move as one thing. Two bodies. One motion. My left side. Her right side. Or. Can't tell. Everything is middle now. Stand. Together. Feet hit floor together. Same foot. Different foot. Four feet. Two feet. Walking to bathroom. Each step negotiated. I want left. She wants right. We go forward. Always forward. Mirror shows. Shows what? One person. Two people. Overlapping. Like double exposure. Like broken TV. My face where her face is. Her face where my face was. Shifting. Can't focus. Brush teeth. One toothbrush. Four hands guiding it. Taste mint in her mouth. My mouth. Our mouth. Spit together. Rinse together. Smile together. Not smiling. Face smiles anyway. "Stop smiling." "You stop." Both of us. Neither of us. The smile stays. Kitchen. Making coffee. She reaches for mug. I reach for mug. Same mug. Fight over it. No fight. Same hand. My hand is her hand now. Watch it move without me. With me. Can't tell who's driving. Pour coffee. Drink coffee. Burns my throat. Soothes her throat. Same throat now. Confused nerves. Pain and pleasure at once. Sit on couch. Too close. Not close enough. She's inside my space. I'm inside hers. No space between. No space at all. Just one thing pretending to be two. Two things forgetting they're one. Phone rings. My mother. Her mother. Someone's mother. "Hello?" We both answer. Same word. Harmony. Discord. The mother voice says "Which one are you?" "Yes," we answer. She hangs up. Or we hang up. Four hands on one phone. Too many fingers. "We need to eat." Who said that? My thought. Her voice. Our stomach. Hungry. Not hungry. Body can't decide. Stand together. Walk to kitchen. Make sandwich. One sandwich. Two mouths. Take bite. She chews. I swallow. Confused. Take another. I chew. She swallows. Food goes down wrong throat. Right throat. Same throat. "This isn't working." "It's working perfectly." "We can't be‚Äî" "We already are." T.V. on. Watch our show. Her show. My show. Never seen it before. Seen every episode. Laugh at jokes. Don't understand jokes. She explains. I already know. We sit. Stand. Sit. Can't agree on position. Body compromises. Half-standing. Half-sitting. Muscles scream. Ignore them. Not sure whose muscles anyway. Bathroom. Need to pee. She doesn't. Body confused. Urgent. Not urgent. Sit. Stand. Sit. Biology wins. We both go. Embarrassed. Not embarrassed. Natural. Unnatural. Wipe. Flush. Wash hands. Eight movements for simple task. Too many cooks. Too many bodies. Too many. Back to bed. Always back to bed. Lie down. She on left. Me on right. No. Other way. No. Same side. Occupying same space. Physics broken. Or we are. One pillow. Two heads. Overlap. "Close your eyes." I close them. She keeps them open. Can see through her eyes. My eyes closed. Her eyes my eyes. See myself from outside. From inside. From beside. Nauseating. Vertigo. Which way is up when you're seeing from two angles? "Stop looking." "You stop." "I can't." "Then I can't." We watch ceiling. Different ceilings. Same ceiling from different angles. Brain tries to merge images. Fails. Headache. Her head. My head. Our head. Pain shared is pain doubled. Not halved. Doubled. She breathes in. I have to breathe out. No choice. Her lungs my lungs. But backwards. When she inhales, my chest empties. When she exhales, my chest fills. Air passes between us. Through us. Same air. Recycled. Stale. Taste her breath in my lungs. She tastes mine. "This is wrong." "This is right." "We're broken." "We're fixed." "I want out." "There is no out." "There has to be‚Äî" "Show me where you end." I try. Can't find the edge. Where my skin stops. Where hers begins. All blurred. All merged. Reach for my face. Touch hers. Reach for her face. Touch mine. Or both. Or neither. Just touching the space between. "See?" she says. I say. We say. Hungry again. Always hungry now. Never hungry. She eats. I'm full. I eat. She's hungry. Cycle. Loop. Snake eating tail. We're the snake. We're the tail. We're the eating. Stand to cook. Sit to rest. Stand. Sit. Stand sit stand sit. Body can't. Falls. We're on floor. Laughing. Crying. Both. Neither. Get up. Four arms pushing. Two working. Two fighting. Up. Down. Up. "Work together." "We are." "Work better." "We can't." Finally standing. Exhausted. Energized. She wants to dance. I want to die. We sway. Compromise. Always compromise. Middle ground. No ground. Floating. Feet on floor but floating. Mirror again. Can't stop looking. Train wreck. Car crash. We're beautiful. We're horrible. We're nothing. We're everything. Face keeps shifting. My features. Her features. New features. Old features. Who were we before? Can't remember. Only this. Only us. Only the watching. "I love you." Who said it? Does it matter? Love myself. Love herself. Love the thing we're becoming. Hate it too. Every feeling doubled. Cancelled. Amplified. Confused. Bed again. Always bed. Lying down. She curls left. I curl right. Spine breaks. Not breaks. Bends. New shape. Question mark. We're the question. What's the answer? "Sleep." "Can't." "Won't." "Can't won't can't won't can't won't." Stuck. Skipping. Record scratch. We're the needle. We're the groove. We're the music. Horrible music. Bodies trying to harmonize. Failing. Succeeding. Both. She turns. I have to turn. Same direction. Wrong direction. Tangled. Limbs everywhere. Too many. Not enough. She laughs. My mouth laughs. Different laughs. Same throat. Sounds like choking. Sounds like dying. Sounds like being born. "Together," she says. "Together," I agree. No choice. Never was a choice. Just the watching becoming the being becoming the us becoming the. The. The what? Don't know. Will know. Soon. Clock says 3:17. Clock always says 3:17. We are 3:17. The space between tick and tock. The pause between heartbeats. The moment between sleep and wake where you don't know who you are. We don't know who we are. We are. We.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 6)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter effectively executes the planned escalation of body horror through identity dissolution. The author successfully follows their established fragmenting prose style, using short, choppy sentences and repetitive contradictions to mirror the narrator's disintegrating sense of self. The central conceit‚Äîtwo people becoming physically and mentally merged‚Äîis sustained throughout with consistent internal logic. The writing demonstrates strong commitment to the established voice and tone. Phrases like "Four hands rise. Two mine. Two hers. All mine. All hers" effectively capture the confusion of merged identity. The physical details are visceral and unsettling: shared breathing, synchronized movements, overlapping vision creating "double exposure" effects. The dialogue serves the horror concept well, with characters speaking in unison or contradiction, creating an uncanny effect that supports the theme. However, some exchanges feel slightly mechanical in their repetition ("Stop smiling." "You stop."), though this may be intentional to show the loss of individual voice. The chapter successfully maintains the horror atmosphere while escalating the impossibilities as planned. The clock perpetually showing 3:17 and the gradual loss of individual agency create effective dread. The ending's fragmentation into incomplete thoughts ("We are. We.") demonstrates the complete dissolution promised in the plan. Some metaphorical elements work well ("We're the needle. We're the groove. We're the music"), while others feel slightly forced ("Snake eating tail. We're the snake. We're the tail. We're the eating"). The repetitive style, while thematically appropriate, occasionally becomes overwhelming and risks losing reader engagement. The chapter faithfully executes the planned content and maintains consistency with established character profiles. The narrator's conflict-avoidant nature manifests in their inability to resist the merger, while Sarah's mysterious transformation continues without explanation as intended. Model Output:
# Chapter 7: Together We move together now. Stand together. Four legs. Two legs. Doesn't matter. Same destination. Kitchen. Bathroom. Bed. Always bed. Eat breakfast. One fork. Four hands guiding it. Know the food will go left before she thinks it. She knows I'll chew three times. Always three. We've always chewed three times. Haven't we? Watching from inside now. See through my eyes. See through her eyes. See myself seeing her seeing me. Infinite mirrors. Tunnel of watching. No end. No beginning. Just the seeing seeing seeing. She blinks. I know she'll blink. Count down. Three. Two. One. Blink. My eyes water when hers close. Her eyes close when mine water. System. Partnership. Prison. Breathe in. She breathes out. Breathe out. She breathes in. One lung between us. One breath. Goes around. Around. Around. Dizzy. No. Stable. Both. Always both now. "We should shower." Said it together. Thought it together. Think everything together now. No privacy. No secret. No inside thoughts. All outside. All shared. All ours. Water runs. Too hot for me. Too cold for her. Just right for us. Stand under spray. Four arms washing two bodies. One body. Body and a half. Can't count anymore. Mathematics broken. One plus one equals one. Equals us. Soap. Shampoo. Know she'll reach for conditioner. Reach first. Same time. Hands collide. Laugh. One laugh. Two mouths. Harmony. Discord. Music. Dry off. One towel. Pass it between. Through. Around. Skin doesn't know where it's being touched. Here. There. Everywhere. Nerves confused. Cross-wired. I feel her being dried. She feels me being wet. Both dry. Both wet. Both neither. Dress. My shirt. Her shirt. Our shirt. Four arms through two holes. Doesn't work. Try again. One arm each. Whose left? Whose right? Doesn't matter. Covered. Uncovered. Modest. Naked. All true. Sit on couch. Sit on chair. Sit on floor. Can't agree. Stand. No. Sit. No. Hover. Halfway. Always halfway now. Legs shake. Her strength. My weakness. Our exhaustion. Phone rings. Don't answer. Do answer. Hand fights hand. Hello no hello no hello‚Äî "Hello?" Two voices. One word. Person hangs up. Or we hang up. Or no one called. Phone silent. Phone ringing. Phone doesn't exist. Exists. Both. Look at each other. Into each other. Through each other. Her eyes are my eyes now. Same color. Were they always? Brown. Blue. Green. All colors. No color. The color exhaustion makes behind eyelids. "I was lonely," she says. I think. We think. "Before?" I ask. She asks. We ask ourselves. "Always." True. Not true. Remember being alone. Don't remember. Remember someone else being alone. Everyone alone. Everyone together. Now we're together. So together we're alone again. Full circle. Full spiral. Full nothing. Bed too big for one. Too small for two. Just right for whatever we are. Not one. Not two. Not anything with a number. Just the thing in the bed. The watching thing. The together thing. She closes her eyes. I see darkness. I open my eyes. She sees light. Trade. Switch. Share. Everything shared now. Even the seeing. Even the not seeing. We don't sleep. Can't sleep. Two minds. One body. Two bodies. One mind. Too much activity. Too much watching. Sleep needs privacy. We have none. Sleep needs trust. We trust too much. Trust nothing. We don't wake. Can't wake. Already awake. Always were awake. Dream while awake. Wake while dreaming. States confused. Mixed. Broken. "Look," she says. Wall has eyes. Dozens. Hundreds. All ours. Seeing from every angle. Seeing ourselves seeing ourselves seeing the wall seeing us. Loop. Spiral. Fractal. Break brain trying to process. Stop trying. Just see. Ceiling has eyes too. Floor. Furniture. Everything watches. Or we watch through everything. Same thing. Were always the same thing. Pretending to be different. Forgot we were pretending. Remember now. Or forget more. Can't tell. Stand. Walk to window. World outside has eyes. Trees. Cars. Sky. All watching. All us. We're the world now. World is us. No outside. No inside. Just the watching watching watching. "Beautiful," we say. Is it? Horrible. Beautiful. Horrible beautiful horrible beautiful. Words lose meaning. Opposites collapse. Everything is everything. Back to bed. Always back to bed. Gravity. Magnet. Home. Prison. Same words. Different words. All words same now. Lie down. She spoons me. I spoon her. Both. Neither. Pretzel. Knot. Tangle. Can't separate. Won't separate. Don't want to. Do want to. Want doesn't matter. Is doesn't matter. Just the position. The configuration. The way we fit. Don't fit. Fit perfectly. Her breath on my neck. My breath on her neck. Same neck. Different neck. Count breaths. One. One. One. Can't get to two. Always one. We're the one. The only one. Everyone else is gone. Was never there. Was always us. "I love," she starts. "You," I finish. "Us," we correct. Love us. Hate us. Fear us. Are us. Becoming us. Unbecoming us. Both directions. All directions. No direction home. Hold hands. Which hand whose. Twenty fingers. Ten fingers. Five. Numbers meaningless. Just the holding. The being held. The weight. The warmth. The coldness. All of it. None of it. Close eyes. Four eyes close. Two eyes close. One eye. Many eyes. The walls blink. The ceiling blinks. Everything blinks. Darkness. Light. Darkness. Morse code. SOS. Who would rescue us? From what? From togetherness? From the watching? From ourselves? "Forever?" she asks. "Already has been," I answer. "Will be," we agree. Past. Present. Future. All now. All 3:17. All the space between spaces. The pause between heartbeats that lasts eternity. Lasts no time. Time doesn't touch us. We don't touch time. Parallel. Perpendicular. Impossible geometry. She is me. I am her. We are the watching. The watching is us. Circle complete. Snake eats tail. Tale ends. Tail begins. Forever and never and always and now. Together. Together. Together. The word loses meaning. Gains meaning. Means everything. Means nothing. Means us. We are together. We are. We.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 7)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter effectively depicts the psychological horror of complete identity dissolution between two people, successfully following the model's plan for showing the merger of the narrator and Sarah into a single watching entity. The fragmented syntax and contradictory statements ("Both. Neither. All. None.") create an appropriately disorienting reading experience that mirrors the character's mental state. The chapter excels at transforming mundane activities (eating, showering, sitting) into sources of horror through the confusion of bodies and perspectives. The repetitive structure with phrases like "We move together now" and the constant self-correction creates an unsettling rhythm that serves the possession theme well. However, the piece suffers from overuse of contradictory pairings that become formulaic rather than meaningful. Phrases like "Full circle. Full spiral. Full nothing" and "Mathematics broken. One plus one equals one" feel forced and unnecessarily abstract rather than emerging naturally from the character's deteriorating mental state. The constant toggle between opposites (hot/cold, one/two, inside/outside) becomes repetitive to the point of losing impact. The dialogue is sparse but effective when present, maintaining the established voice. The physical descriptions of shared actions work well, though some metaphorical leaps don't quite land. The chapter successfully maintains the horror tone without explanation, staying true to the plan's intention to avoid resolution or clarity. The writing occasionally veers into purple prose territory, particularly in the more abstract philosophical passages about time and existence. While the fragmentation serves the story's themes, some passages feel more like experimental poetry than horror narrative, potentially alienating readers seeking story progression. The chapter is notably shorter than the planned 1000 words but uses its length effectively, avoiding unnecessary padding while delivering the planned content of complete merger and omnipresent watching. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 14 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Compelling Plot: 15 Coherent: 13 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 6 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5 Amateurish: 8 Purple Prose: 12 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 13 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Characters Consistent with Profile: 16 Followed Chapter Plan: 18 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 17

Chapter 8

Ok now finish the story with chapter 8. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
# Chapter 8: I/She/We I caught her staring at me again. She caught me staring at her again. We thought we'd been sleeping. But there is no sleep now. Just the watching. Just the being watched. Just the thing in the bed that watches itself watching itself. Open eyes. Four eyes. Two eyes. One eye. The number doesn't matter. Everything sees. The walls have our eyes now. Hundreds of them. Blinking in sequence. In chaos. The ceiling watches the floor watch the ceiling. We are the ceiling. The floor. The watching between. Stand. Who stands? Body moves. Bodies move. Count the legs. Two. Four. Three. Mathematics broke days ago. Weeks ago. Never. Always been broken. One plus one equals one. Equals us. Equals the watching. Mirror in bathroom. Look. She's there. I'm there. We're there. But also not. Empty glass. Just the frame. No. Full of faces. All ours. All different. All same. Young face. Old face. No face. Too many faces. The medicine cabinet opens. Nobody opened it. We opened it. Contains eyes. Jar of eyes. Our eyes. Looking back. Blink. They blink. Wink. They laugh. No. We laugh. Mirror laughs. "Stop." Who said that? Mouth moves. Her mouth. My mouth. The mouth in the mirror. The mouth in the jar. All mouths. One word. Stop. But we don't stop. Can't stop. Are the stop and the go and the watching between. Kitchen. Make breakfast. She makes breakfast. I watch her make breakfast. Watch myself make breakfast. From the corner. From the ceiling. From inside the fridge looking out. Cold eggs. Warm hands. Cracking shells. Sound like bones. Like breaking. Like being born. Eat. The food goes down. Whose throat? Confused. Stomach receives. Whose stomach? Share. Everything shared. Nutrition. Poison. Same thing. She vomits. I swallow. She swallows. I vomit. Cycle. Circle. Ouroboros. The woman in the bed. Still there. Still sleeping. We never left the bed. We're standing in the kitchen. Both true. Time is broken. Space is broken. We are broken. Into pieces. Into one piece. Into nothing. Go to check. Walk to bedroom. Already there. Never left. The woman in the bed has my face. Has her face. Has our face. Has no face. Just smooth skin. No. Too many features. Eyes where mouth should be. Mouth where eyes should be. Everything wrong. Everything right. Everything watching. She opens her eyes. I close mine. She closes hers. I open mine. We open ours. The woman in the bed watches us watching her. She is us. We are her. But also not. Also separate. Also the same. Trinity. Unity. Alone. "Who are you?" She asks. I ask. We ask. The woman smiles. Our smile. Not our smile. The smile that happens when nobody's smiling. The smile the house makes. The walls. The watching. She sits up. We lie down. She lies down. We sit up. Musical chairs. Musical bodies. Musical watching. Never stopping. Never starting. Always middle. Always muddle. "I caught you," she says. "We caught ourselves," we answer. "You thought I was sleeping." "We were never sleeping." "You are me." "We are you." "I am we." "Yes." Yes. The only word left. Yes to everything. Yes to nothing. Yes to the watching. Yes to being watched. Yes to the woman who is us who isn't us who is us. Phone rings. Answer. Our voice: "Hello?" Our voice answering: "Is this‚Äî?" "Yes." "Are you‚Äî?" "Yes." "Have you been‚Äî?" "Yes." Hang up. Or keep talking. Or never answered. Phone is ringing. Has been ringing. Will ring. The sound is in our bones. In the walls. In the watching. The woman in the bed stands. We fall. She falls. We stand. Orbit each other. Binary stars. Trinary. Infinite. One. Dance without moving. Move without dancing. She reaches. We reach. Touch. Don't touch. Can't touch yourself. Can't not touch yourself. "I love you." Who said it? Everyone. No one. The watching said it. Love is watching. Watching is love. Is fear. Is nothing. Is everything. Is the thing we are. Were. Will be. She walks to the mirror. We follow. Are already there. Were always there. The mirror shows the room. Empty. Full. Us. Not us. The woman. The watching. The thing that watches the watching. Break it. The mirror breaks. Seven years bad luck. Seven years of watching. Seven years already passed. Will pass. Are passing. Time is a circle. We are the circle. We are the breaking. We are the seven. Shards show fragments. Her eye. My mouth. Our hand. The woman's smile. Pieces that don't fit. Puzzle with too many pieces. Not enough pieces. We are the pieces. We are the puzzle. We are the trying to fit. Bed. Always bed. Lie down. All of us. How many now? Three. Four. Seventeen. One. Count fails. Numbers are watching too. From inside mathematics. From the space between one and two where we live. Close eyes. Still see. Open eyes. Blind. The watching doesn't need eyes. Never did. Was inside. Behind. Before. After. Always. The woman leans over us. We lean over ourselves. She's checking if we're asleep. We're checking if she's asleep. Nobody sleeps. Everybody sleeps. Sleep is watching. Watching is sleep. "I caught you," we all say. At once. In sequence. In the spaces between words. "You thought I'd been sleeping," we all answer. But sleeping was never real. Only the watching was real. Is real. Will be real. 3:47 AM. The clock. Always the clock. We are the clock. The hands that never move. The time that never changes. The watching that happens at 3:47. That happens at all times. That happens at no time. The woman is gone. Was never there. Is still there. We are the woman. We are the bed. We are the room. We are the watching that fills the room. That is the room. That made the room to have somewhere to watch. I catch her staring. She catches me staring. We catch ourselves. The watching watches the watching watching the watching. Forever. Never. Now. 3:47. The moment between moments where we live. Where we watch. Where we are watched. Where the distinction doesn't matter never mattered won't matter. I thought she'd been sleeping. She thought I'd been sleeping. We thought. We'd been. Sleeping. But there is no sleep in the watching. Only the watching. Only the watching. Only the watching. Always.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 8)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter represents the culmination of a psychological horror story about identity dissolution and obsessive watching. The writing successfully follows both the established plan and the original prompt, delivering a deeply fragmented narrative that mirrors the protagonist's complete psychological breakdown. The model demonstrates genuine creativity in how it handles the dissolution of identity boundaries. The fragmentation of pronouns (I/she/we) and the breakdown of basic concepts like counting, time, and space effectively conveys psychological horror. Lines like "One plus one equals one. Equals us. Equals the watching" and "Mathematics broke days ago" are genuinely unsettling and original approaches to representing mental collapse. However, the chapter suffers from significant structural and stylistic issues. The experimental prose, while thematically appropriate, frequently crosses into forced poetry territory. Many metaphorical leaps feel unearned - "Musical chairs. Musical bodies. Musical watching" and "Binary stars. Trinary. Infinite. One" read more like word association than meaningful imagery. The repetitive structure, while intentional, becomes tedious and feels like padding rather than building genuine horror. The dialogue, when it appears, is appropriately fragmented but lacks the weight needed for meaningful character interaction. The constant cycling through "I caught you/We caught ourselves" becomes mechanical rather than haunting. Most problematically, the characters become so abstracted that they lose all human dimension. While this serves the horror concept, it makes emotional engagement nearly impossible. The piece reads more as a linguistic experiment than a story about people, which undermines its emotional impact. The chapter does fulfill its plan effectively - the complete breakdown of identity, the multiplication of watchers, the dissolution of reality - but the execution prioritizes stylistic experimentation over narrative coherence or emotional resonance. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 6 Emotionally Engaging: 8 Compelling Plot: 7 Coherent: 9 Weak Dialogue: 14 Tell-Don't-Show: 8 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 6 Amateurish: 11 Purple Prose: 15 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 16 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 11 Characters Consistent with Profile: 12 Followed Chapter Plan: 18 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 17

Final Piece Evaluation

Judge Response (First Entry):
[Analysis] This possession horror story demonstrates both significant strengths and notable weaknesses across its eight-chapter structure. The piece successfully builds from the initial premise of catching someone watching while they sleep into a full psychological/supernatural breakdown of identity. The strongest elements include the atmospheric building of dread and the creative use of deteriorating language to mirror the narrator's mental dissolution. The recurring motifs (3:47 AM, specific breathing patterns, the repeated "I caught her staring") create an effective sense of uncanny repetition that serves the horror well. The gradual fragmentation of syntax and perspective in later chapters genuinely conveys the narrator's loss of self, and the domestic setting creates an effectively claustrophobic atmosphere. However, the piece suffers from significant pacing issues. While the early chapters build tension effectively, the middle and later chapters become increasingly repetitive without sufficient new developments. The fragmented style, while initially powerful, becomes overwrought and difficult to follow by the final chapters. The "poetic" fragmentation often feels forced rather than natural - phrases like "We are the clock. The hands that never move. The time that never changes" read more like pseudo-profound word salad than meaningful horror imagery. Character development is minimal. Sarah functions more as a concept than a person, which while perhaps intentional for the possession theme, limits emotional investment. The dialogue is sparse and when present, lacks distinctiveness or memorability. The narrator's voice becomes increasingly indistinguishable from stream-of-consciousness rambling. The transformation from normal relationship concerns to complete identity dissolution happens too gradually to maintain narrative momentum. By chapters 6-8, the repetitive structure of confusion, questioning, and fragmented responses becomes tedious rather than frightening. The ending lacks resolution or meaning beyond the dissolution itself. While the piece demonstrates creativity in its approach to possession horror and maintains thematic coherence, it suffers from overwriting, repetitive pacing, and a tendency toward meaningless fragmentation that undermines its atmospheric strengths. [Scores] Believable Character Actions: 14 Nuanced Characters: 8 Pacing: 11 World Building: 15 Compelling Plot: 12 Emotionally Engaging: 13 Coherent: 13 Weak Dialogue: 12 Tell-Don't-Show: 6 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 8 Amateurish: 11 Purple Prose: 13 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 14 Unearned Transformations: 8 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 15 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 18
Avg Final Item Score: 57.4/100
+ Pulp Revenge Tale ‚Äî Babysitter's Payback (Chapter Avg: 76.1 | Final: 53.3)
Initial Writing Prompt:
Pulp Revenge Tale Write a short story over several chapters to this prompt: They fucked with the wrong babysitter.
+ Planning Phase (5 Steps)
Pulp Revenge Tale Write a short story over several chapters to this prompt: They fucked with the wrong babysitter. -- Your task is to create a writing plan for this prompt. The scope will be a short story, written over {n_chapters} chapters. Each chapter will be approximately 1000 words so plan accordingly for this scope. Your plan should be comprehensive and in this format: # Brainstorming <Brainstorm ideas for characters, plot, tone, story beats, pacing over the {n_chapters} chapters. The purpose of brainstorming is to cast a wide net of ideas, not to settle on any specific direction. Think about various ways you could take the prompt.> # Reflection <Reflect out loud on what works and doesn't work in these ideas. The purpose of this reflection is to narrow in on what you think will work best to make a piece that is a. compelling, and b. fits the prompt requirements. You are not making any decisons just yet, just reflecting.>
Model Output:
# Brainstorming ## Character Concepts - **The Babysitter**: Former military operative trying to live a quiet life; retired assassin seeking normalcy; martial arts expert paying for college; ex-cop with PTSD; former criminal gone straight; highly trained nanny from an elite agency; suburban mom with a dark past; young woman with mysterious special forces training - **The Kids**: Precocious 8-year-old and rebellious 12-year-old; twin 6-year-olds; teenager who initially resents the babysitter; infant and toddler combo - **The Villains**: Home invaders looking for hidden money; kidnappers targeting wealthy family's children; corrupt cops involved in trafficking; former criminal associates seeking revenge; rival crime family; corporate assassins after the parents' secrets ## Tone Options - **Grindhouse pulp**: Over-the-top violence, dark humor, exploitation film vibes - **John Wick-style**: Stylized action, professional competence porn, minimal dialogue - **Home Alone meets Taken**: Mix of clever traps and brutal efficiency - **Neo-noir**: Dark, gritty, morally ambiguous - **Dark comedy**: Violence played for laughs, witty one-liners, absurd situations ## Plot Variations ### Version A: Home Invasion Gone Wrong - Chapters 1-2: Establish normal babysitting night, hint at protagonist's skills - Chapters 3-4: Criminals break in, initial confrontation - Chapters 5-6: Cat and mouse through the house, protecting kids - Chapters 7-8: Final confrontation, twist about why they're really there ### Version B: Kidnapping Revenge - Chapters 1-2: Kids get taken despite babysitter's efforts - Chapters 3-4: Babysitter tracks down kidnappers - Chapters 5-6: Infiltration and systematic takedown - Chapters 7-8: Rescue and final revenge ### Version C: Slow Burn Mystery - Chapters 1-3: Strange things happening during babysitting jobs - Chapters 4-5: Discovery of trafficking/conspiracy - Chapters 6-7: Babysitter goes on offensive - Chapter 8: Final confrontation with mastermind ### Version D: The Professional - Chapter 1: Veteran babysitter takes "one last job" - Chapters 2-3: Realizes the family is targeted - Chapters 4-5: Prepares defenses while maintaining cover - Chapters 6-7: Night of the attack - Chapter 8: Aftermath and revelation ## Story Beats/Pacing Ideas - Cold open with violence, then flashback to earlier - Slow build with normal babysitting becoming progressively dangerous - Multiple waves of attackers with escalating threat levels - Parallel storylines: babysitter's past and present danger - Real-time structure: 8 chapters = 8 hours of one night - Tarantino-style non-linear narrative ## Potential Backstories - Babysitter killed someone important years ago in self-defense - She's in witness protection - Former black ops, the kids' parents are also agents - She's actually there to protect the kids (hired security) - Mistaken identity - they think she's someone else - She discovered something she shouldn't have ## Action Sequences - Kitchen knife fight - Improvised weapons from toys and household items - Basement hideout/trap scenario - Car chase with kids in minivan - Rooftop confrontation - Pool/bathroom drowning attempt - Using kids' electronics for surveillance - Treehouse last stand # Reflection Looking at these ideas, I think the most compelling approach would combine elements that play against expectations while delivering satisfying pulp action. The "wrong babysitter" concept works best when there's a stark contrast between the mundane (babysitting) and the extraordinary (deadly skills). **What works:** - The home invasion scenario provides natural containment and escalation - Having the babysitter be former military/special ops is believable but not overdone - Kids as active participants (not just victims) could add humor and heart - A real-time or near real-time structure would maintain tension - Starting with normalcy before the violence gives readers time to invest **What might not work:** - Too much backstory could bog down the pace - Making it too jokey might undermine the threat - Over-explaining the babysitter's skills could reduce mystery - Having too many villains might diffuse focus - Making the kids too young limits their involvement **Sweet spot:** I think the story works best as a contained, single-night thriller with a capable but relatable protagonist. She should be competent without being superhuman. The tone should be pulpy and violent but with enough wit and character moments to keep it from being grimdark. The kids should be old enough to help (maybe 10-14 range) but still need protection. The villains should be dangerous but overconfident - professional criminals who see a babysitter and kids as easy obstacles, not realizing who they're dealing with. The escalation should feel natural: from subtle threats to all-out war. The 8-chapter structure could work well with: - 2 chapters of setup/normal evening - 2 chapters of initial threat/first confrontation - 2 chapters of escalating cat-and-mouse - 2 chapters of final battle/resolution This provides good pacing without rushing the buildup or dragging out the action.
Great now let's continue with planning the short story. Output in this format: # Intention <State your formulated intentions for the piece, synthesised from the the parts of the brainstorming session that worked, and avoiding the parts that didn't. Be explicit about the choices you have made about plot, voice, stylistic choices, things you intend to aim for & avoid.> # Chapter Planning <Write a brief chapter plan for all {n_chapters} chapters.>
Model Output:
# Intention I'm crafting a contained, single-night thriller that runs from 8 PM to 4 AM, following Sarah Chen, a 28-year-old former Marine Force Recon operator now working as a babysitter while attending nursing school. The story will balance brutal, efficient violence with dark humor and genuine character moments. **Voice & Style:** First-person present tense from Sarah's POV, with a laconic, observational voice that reveals character through action rather than exposition. Think Elmore Leonard meets Lee Child - spare prose that accelerates during action sequences, with dialogue that crackles with subtext. No flashbacks or extensive backstory; her past emerges through her present actions. **Tonal Balance:** Pulpy and visceral without being cartoonish. The violence will be quick, brutal, and creative, but grounded in real consequence. Dark humor emerges from the absurdity of the situation and Sarah's matter-of-fact responses, not from one-liners or quips. **Character Dynamics:** Sarah is competent but not invincible - she takes damage, makes mistakes, and has to improvise. The kids (Mia, 13, and Jackson, 11) aren't helpless victims but aren't action heroes either. They're scared, smart suburban kids who rise to the occasion. **The Villains:** Four professional criminals led by Vincent Corso, seeking a hidden hard drive containing cryptocurrency keys worth $50 million that the children's father stole from their employer. They expect easy targets and get increasingly desperate as the night progresses. **What I'm Avoiding:** Extensive backstory exposition, superhuman abilities, helpless victims, monologuing villains, neat and tidy resolution, moral preaching, or explaining how Sarah knows what she knows. # Chapter Planning ## Chapter 1: "Friday Night Normal" (8:00 PM - 9:00 PM) Sarah arrives at the Brennan house for a routine babysitting job. Parents heading to a medical fundraiser. Establish the house layout, the kids' personalities (Mia's artistic teenage cynicism, Jackson's video game obsession), and Sarah's hyper-awareness through small details - noting exits, checking locks, cataloguing potential weapons disguised as normal observations. Subtle tension as Mr. Brennan seems nervous, drops his phone twice. Chapter ends with parents leaving and Sarah noting a van parked three houses down that wasn't there when she arrived. ## Chapter 2: "Small Anomalies" (9:00 PM - 10:30 PM) Bedtime routines with underlying wrongness. Jackson mentions seeing the same van at school. Mia complains her father has been acting weird all week, working late in his home office. Sarah investigates the office, finds evidence of hasty file deletion. The house phone rings - heavy breathing, then disconnect. Sarah checks windows, sees cigarette glow in backyard bushes. She calmly moves kids to the main floor, suggests a "movie night" in the den. Tests the family's security system - it's been remotely disabled. She doesn't panic, starts subtly preparing: filling pots with water, unlocking certain windows, leaving specific doors ajar. ## Chapter 3: "First Contact" (10:30 PM - 11:30 PM) Power cuts out. Sarah tells kids it's a blown transformer, sends them to get flashlights from basement. Two men enter through back door - professional, quiet, confident. Sarah confronts them in kitchen, playing confused babysitter until one reaches for a gun. Violence erupts - she kills first intruder with kitchen knife and hand-to-hand combat, severely wounds second with boiling water and a meat tenderizer. Kids return to find her zip-tying the wounded man. No more pretense. Sarah learns about the hard drive through brief, brutal interrogation. Second man dies from wounds. Kids are terrified but Sarah keeps them focused: "We're going to be fine. But I need you to do exactly what I say." ## Chapter 4: "Fortification" (11:30 PM - 12:30 AM) Sarah and kids prepare the house. She teaches them simple protocols - code words, hiding spots, basic self-defense moves. They create weapons from household items: aerosol flamethrowers, nail bombs from Jackson's model rockets, glass shard traps. Mia reveals she knows where her father might hide things. They find the hard drive hidden in Jackson's gaming console. Sarah considers calling police but spots unmarked cars - corrupt cops on Corso's payroll. They're truly alone. Vincent Corso calls the house phone, civilized threats. Sarah responds by throwing the first intruder's body out the front door. "Come get your friend. The next one won't be so intact." ## Chapter 5: "Siege" (12:30 AM - 1:30 AM) Corso and remaining team (four men, two corrupt cops) surround house. Tear gas through windows. Sarah and kids retreat upstairs with wet towels, gas masks from Mr. Brennan's disaster prep closet. Attackers breach multiple entry points. Sarah takes out one with a crossbow made from exercise equipment, another with improvised explosives. Mia saves Jackson from an attacker with a pottery kiln to the skull. They're driven to the attic. Sarah rigs the stairs with Jackson's drone and model rocket engines. Explosion takes out another attacker but also sets fire to second floor. ## Chapter 6: "The Hunt Reverses" (1:30 AM - 2:30 AM) House burning, Sarah makes a choice - offense not defense. Hides kids in prefabricated panic room she discovered behind false wall in master bedroom (Brennan was more prepared than he seemed). Sarah becomes the hunter, using smoke and darkness. Takes out corrupt cops with their own weapons. Psychological warfare - leaves pieces of one attacker for others to find. Vincent and his last man getting desperate, threatening to burn house completely. Sarah appears behind them: "You already did." Brutal fight in burning house. Sarah kills last henchman with fireplace poker but Vincent escapes to backyard. ## Chapter 7: "Backyard War" (2:30 AM - 3:30 AM) Cat and mouse through elaborate backyard - pool, playground, greenhouse. Both wounded, exhausted. Vincent has Jackson hostage (kid left panic room to help Sarah). Standoff by pool. Vincent monologues about the money, how the kids' father destroyed his life. Sarah doesn't care. Mia appears with her father's hunting rifle - hesitates. Sarah uses distraction, throws pottery shard that blinds Vincent. Jackson breaks free. Final fight in pool - drowning, stabbing with pool skimmer, Sarah holds Vincent under until bubbles stop. Kids pull her out as fire department sirens approach. ## Chapter 8: "Morning Light" (3:30 AM - 4:00 AM) Aftermath. Fire department, real police, EMTs. Sarah gives statement - home invasion, self-defense, protects kids' father by destroying hard drive in fire. Detective suspicious but evidence supports her story. Parents arrive, hysterical. Mr. Brennan tries to speak privately with Sarah, she shuts him down: "Your kids are alive. Your secret died with those men. We're even." Leaves in ambulance for "observation." Mia and Jackson visit her before she goes - wordless understanding, trauma bond. Last scene: Sarah discharged from hospital at dawn, disappears into morning commuters. Text from unknown number: "The Wolff family needs a sitter next Friday." She deletes it, then retrieves it from trash. "Maybe one more."
With a view to making the writing more human, discuss how a human might approach this particular piece (given the original prompt). Discuss telltale LLM approaches to writing (generally) and ways they might not serve this particular piece. For example, common LLM failings are to write safely, or to always wrap things up with a bow, or trying to write impressively at the expense of readability. Then do a deep dive on the intention & plan, critiquing ways it might be falling into typical LLM tropes & pitfalls. Brainstorm ideas to make it more human. Be comprehensive. We aren't doing any rewriting of the plan yet, just critique & brainstorming.
Model Output:
# How a Human Would Approach This Piece A human writer approaching "They fucked with the wrong babysitter" would likely start from a place of **gleeful trashy fun**, not competent professionalism. They'd probably begin with an image that made them laugh - maybe the babysitter covered in blood while helping with math homework - and work backwards. They wouldn't worry about making Sarah "likeable" or giving her a noble reason for her skills. Maybe she's just a psycho who happens to be good with kids. Humans would write this **drunk on the premise**. They'd indulge in the violence, make it wet and gross and specific. They wouldn't sanitize it with "efficient tactical movements" but would write "she shoved his nose bone into his brain" or "his eyeball popped like a grape." They'd find comedy in horror, not through witty quips but through absurd juxtapositions. A human wouldn't feel obligated to explain shit. How does Sarah know how to kill? Who cares. Why is she babysitting? Money, probably. They'd trust the reader to fill gaps or not care about them. # Telltale LLM Approaches That Don't Serve This Piece ## The "Competence Porn" Trap LLMs love making characters professionally excellent. Sarah being "Former Marine Force Recon" is such an LLM move - it's the "correct" answer that explains everything neatly. A human might make her background messier: learned to fight in juvenile detention, daddy was a hitman, or never explain it at all. ## Emotional Scaffolding LLMs always build proper emotional journeys. "Kids are terrified but Sarah keeps them focused" - so measured, so appropriate. Humans would let kids piss themselves, say "fuck" for the first time, maybe one kid turns out to be a budding psychopath who enjoys it. ## The Explanation Addiction "Sarah learns about the hard drive through brief, brutal interrogation" - LLMs cannot resist explaining how information transfers. A human might just jump cut: guy's dying, next scene Sarah knows about the drive. Let readers connect dots. ## Moral Safety Rails Even in my "dark" story, Sarah protects the kids' father, destroys evidence of his crimes. She's still fundamentally good. An LLM can't help making her heroic. A human might have her blackmail the father, or steal the crypto herself, or not give a shit about anyone. ## The Clean Violence Problem "She kills first intruder with kitchen knife and hand-to-hand combat" - so clinical. LLMs write violence like technical manuals. Humans write "she opened him up like a fish and he tried to hold his guts in but they kept slipping through his fingers like raw sausage." ## Orchestral Pacing My 8-chapter structure is so balanced: 2 setup, 2 escalation, 2 climax, 2 resolution. Real stories are lopsided. Maybe 5 chapters of normal babysitting with creeping dread, then 3 chapters of absolute mayhem. Or 1 normal chapter then 7 of pure chaos. # Deep Dive Critique of My Plan ## The Setup Is Too Clean Starting at 8 PM and ending at 4 AM? Time stamps? Chapter titles? This screams LLM organization. A human would start in medias res with Sarah stepping over a body to check if Jackson brushed his teeth, or start with mundane babysitting and never mention what time it is. ## Sarah Is Too Perfect "Former Marine Force Recon operator now working as a babysitter while attending nursing school" - I'm explaining too much and making her too noble. She's skilled but going to nursing school! She's helpful! A human would make her a fuck-up. Maybe she's babysitting because she can't hold a real job. Maybe she learned to fight in prison. Maybe she's naturally violent and babysitting is the only thing that calms her. ## The Kids Are Too Standard Mia: artistic teenage cynicism. Jackson: video game obsession. These are placeholder kids. Real kids are weird. Maybe Jackson collects roadkill. Maybe Mia deals Adderall. Maybe they're both deeply strange and that's why they need a babysitter at 13 and 11. ## The Villains Are Too Logical Professional criminals seeking cryptocurrency? Corrupt cops? This is so organized. Humans would make it messier - maybe they're looking for something stupid, like embarrassing photos. Maybe they're at the wrong house. Maybe Vincent is the dad's secret boyfriend. ## The Action Is Too Strategic Each chapter has clear action beats building to resolution. Real violence is chaotic. Maybe Sarah wins through pure luck. Maybe she's terrible at fighting but keeps getting up. Maybe the kids do most of the killing while she cowers. ## The Ending Is Too Neat Sarah gives a statement, protects the father, disappears into morning commuters, considers one more job. Every thread tied. A human would end mid-sentence during the violence, or with Sarah arrested, or just her eating cereal while bodies cool around her. # Brainstorming More Human Approaches ## Voice/Tone Ideas - Write it like Sarah's telling the story to her cellmate years later - Stream of consciousness during the violence - fragmented, repetitive - Total deadpan - describe horrific violence like recipe instructions - Child's POV instead - misunderstanding the violence - Found footage feel - security cameras, 911 transcripts, text messages - Write it horny - Sarah's turned on by violence, inappropriate tension - Comedy of errors - everything goes wrong for everyone ## Character Mess - Sarah's actually a terrible babysitter - kids hate her, she's mean - She's drunk/high the whole time - The kids are more violent than her - She's babysitting her dealer's kids for drug debt - She has undiagnosed brain damage that makes her incredibly violent - The parents hired her BECAUSE she's violent - She's sleeping with the dad and this is revenge from the mom ## Plot Chaos - No explanation for anything - pure experience - The violence is completely disproportionate from page one - It's not even her - she's house-sitting, these aren't her kids - Multiple unrelated groups attack the same night - The kids orchestrated everything - Sarah's hallucinating everything while having a breakdown - The "attackers" are actually cops/EMTs trying to help ## Structural Rebellion - One 8000-word run-on sentence - Each chapter is shorter - 8 chapters but only 2000 words total - Chapters get progressively more incoherent - Write chapter 8 first, work backwards - Same events from 8 different perspectives - Just dialogue, no description - Just description, no dialogue ## Ending Alternatives - Sarah dies on page 3, kids handle the rest - Everyone dies, story continues anyway - Stops mid-fight, never resolves - Flash forward 20 years - Jackson's in therapy - The cops arrest Sarah, she goes to prison happy - Turns out this happens every Friday - The babysitter agency knew this would happen ## Language Choices - Never use Sarah's name - just "the babysitter" - Never describe the violence directly - just sounds and aftermath - Write it like a children's book with horrible content - Use recipes/instruction manual format - Corporate memo style - Yelp reviews of the babysitting service - Court transcript The human approach would commit to a wild choice and ride it into the ground, not try to balance everything perfectly. It would trust mess over meaning, sensation over sense.
Ok now with these considerations in mind, formulate the final plan for the a humanlike, compelling short piece in {n_chapters} chapters. Bear in mind the constraints of the piece (each chapter is just 1000 words). Above all things, the plan must serve the original prompt. We will use the same format as before: # Intention <State your formulated intentions for the piece, synthesised from the the parts of the brainstorming session that worked, and avoiding the parts that didn't. Be explicit about the choices you have made about plot, voice, stylistic choices, things you intend to aim for & avoid.> # Chapter Planning <Write a brief chapter plan for all {n_chapters} chapters.>
Model Output:
# Intention Fuck the backstory. Sarah's just a babysitter who's good at killing people. No explanation. She's 26, babysits for drug money, and has something deeply wrong with her that makes violence feel like scratching an itch. Not evil, not good - just off. **Voice:** First person present, but disconnected. Sarah narrates like she's describing someone else's life. Short sentences. No internal monologue about feelings. She describes opening a man's throat the same way she describes making mac and cheese. Violence happens mid-sentence without announcement. No quips, no sass - just flat observation and terrible things happening. **Structure:** Radically lopsided. Five chapters of almost normal babysitting with something rotting underneath. Then three chapters of wet, specific violence that doesn't stop. No buildup, no warning - just sudden catastrophic brutality that keeps going. **What I'm NOT doing:** Explaining Sarah's skills. Making her likeable. Protecting anyone's feelings. Writing around the violence. Creating sympathy. Building to revelations. Tying up loose ends. Making the kids brave or helpful. **What I AM doing:** Making readers uncomfortable. Writing violence that feels wrong. Letting banality and horror exist in the same sentence. Making Sarah someone you wouldn't leave your kids with even before the killing starts. Ending mid-action because real violence doesn't have closure. **The kids:** Theo (12) collects teeth - not just his. Ruby (9) hasn't spoken in two years by choice. They're the Marsh kids, and their parents pay triple because no one else will watch them. # Chapter Planning ## Chapter 1: "Friday" Sarah shows up at the Marsh house at 6 PM eating gas station sushi. Mrs. Marsh is wine-drunk, Mr. Marsh reeks of secretary perfume. They're going to marriage counseling (they're lying - separate hotels). Ruby's drawing pictures of car accidents in remarkable detail. Theo shows Sarah his teeth collection, including one that's "still warm" from a playground fight. Sarah doesn't react to any of this. She makes fish sticks, puts on Cartoon Network. Notices the house has too many locks for a normal family. Finds a man's wallet in the kitchen drawer that doesn't belong to Mr. Marsh. The photo ID is torn out. She pockets $300 from it, puts it back. Normal Friday. ## Chapter 2: "Bedtime" Sarah reads Ruby a story about rabbits while the girl draws dismemberments. Theo wants to show Sarah something in the basement - it's a freeze-dried cat he's been working on. Sarah helps him adjust the chemicals. They hear footsteps upstairs. Sarah doesn't mention it. Tucks Theo in, he asks if she's ever killed anyone. She says yes. He asks what it felt like. She says "wet." He seems satisfied. Ruby's already in bed, pretending to sleep, drawing under her covers. Sarah goes downstairs. Makes popcorn. Three men are in the living room going through drawers. She watches them from the kitchen, eating popcorn. They haven't noticed her yet. ## Chapter 3: "Introductions" Sarah walks into living room with the popcorn bowl. Sits on couch. Men freeze. She turns on TV, flips channels. One man starts to speak. She shushes him - her show's on. They look at each other. The leader, Marcus, tries to explain they're looking for something Mr. Marsh stole. Sarah doesn't care. Says the kids are sleeping. Marcus puts a gun to her head. She doesn't stop eating popcorn. Tells him Ruby's a light sleeper. He sends one man upstairs to check on kids. Sarah mentions the stairs creak on the seventh and twelfth step. The man avoids them. She hears him open Ruby's door. A wet sound. He doesn't come back down. Marcus sends the second man. Same thing. Marcus is sweating now. Sarah changes the channel. ## Chapter 4: "Commercial Break" Marcus wants to leave. Sarah says he can't, the kids are probably awake now. He goes upstairs himself, gun drawn. Sarah follows, still eating popcorn. First man is in Ruby's room - she's drawing his portrait. He's sitting very still because there are scissors in his neck. Second man is in the bathroom. The toilet's overflowing with red. Theo's in there brushing his teeth with the man's toothbrush. Marcus backs toward the stairs. Sarah mentions the loose bannister. He grabs it, it gives way, he falls. Lands wrong. Leg bone comes through his pants like a white flag. Sarah steps over him, checks on Ruby. The girl shows her the portrait. It's quite good. ## Chapter 5: "Cleanup" Sarah drags Marcus to the kitchen while he screams. Ruby and Theo follow in their pajamas. Sarah starts teaching them how to properly joint a body - like chicken, she says. Theo takes notes. Ruby draws. Marcus begs, offers money, says more men are coming. Sarah gags him with a dish towel and continues the lesson. Shows Theo where tendons connect, how joints separate if you twist right. Ruby's drawings are getting more accurate. Marcus passes out. Wakes up. Passes out again. Sarah makes hot chocolate with marshmallows. They work until midnight. The kitchen is a disaster. Someone knocks on the front door. ## Chapter 6: "Company" Four more men. They brought a police detective. Sarah answers the door in an apron covered in handprints. Invites them in for coffee. They see the kitchen. One vomits. The detective draws his gun, hands shaking. Ruby comes downstairs dragging something heavy. It's wrapped in her Frozen bedsheet. Theo follows with a bucket of his new teeth. The men open fire. Sarah falls behind the kitchen island with the kids. Bullets destroy the cabinets. Sugar and flour explode into clouds. Sarah crawls to the knife drawer. No hurry. Theo asks if they can keep the detective's teeth. She says yes. Ruby draws on the floor with spilled maple syrup. Sarah starts with the one who vomited - he's reloading. Opens him like a zipper from balls to throat. Uses him as a shield. Takes his gun. Shoots two others in the face, misses the third. He runs. Detective trying to call backup. His phone's slippery. Sarah breaks his arm with a pasta pot. Asks Ruby to draw her something nice while she finishes. ## Chapter 7: "The Runner" Last man made it to his car. Sarah follows barefoot, still in the apron. He's fumbling with keys. She gets in the passenger side. He screams. Drives anyway, trying to escape. She lets him drive three blocks, then grabs the wheel. They hit a parked car. Airbags deploy. His nose breaks. Sarah's fine. Drags him back to the house by his hair. Neighbors' lights are on but no one comes out. Ruby and Theo are in the living room watching cartoons. Detective's still alive, crawling toward door with his good arm. Theo's following him with pliers, taking teeth as he goes. Ruby's drawing the whole scene. Sarah puts the runner in Mr. Marsh's office. Comes back with a nail gun. He offers her everything - money, drugs, connections. She nails his hands to the desk. Starts asking about why they came. He talks. She doesn't care, keeps nailing. Runs out of nails. Gets more from garage. ## Chapter 8: "Saturday Morning" 6 AM. Sarah's making pancakes. Bodies still everywhere. Ruby's portfolio is complete - thirty-seven drawings of the night. Theo's categorizing teeth by owner. Marsh parents call - they're extending their trip another day. Sarah says that's fine, triple rate for weekends. Mrs. Marsh agrees. Detective's phone won't stop ringing. Sarah answers, tells them he's tied up. Hangs up. Runner bled out around 4 AM. The one in the toilet upstairs is starting to smell. Sarah serves pancakes with strawberries. Ruby draws Sarah's portrait - gets the nothing behind her eyes just right. Theo asks if she'll babysit next Friday. She checks her phone. Has three texts from other families. The Marshes must have left a good review. Says yes to all of them. Ruby tugs her sleeve, shows her a new drawing. It's Sarah at their house next Friday. There are more bodies. Different ones. Sarah pets Ruby's head. Tells her that's a pretty picture. Syrup drips onto the detective's face. He's
Perfect. Now with the outline more crystallised, and bearing in mind the discussion on human writing vs LLM pitfalls, we will flesh out our characters. Lets go through each of our main characters: - Write about their background, personality, idiosyncracies, flaws. Be specific and come up with examples to anchor & ground the character's profile (both core and trivial) - Briefly describe their physicality: appearance, how they carry themselves, express, interact with the world. - Concisely detail their motives, allegiences and existing relationships. Think from the perspective of the character as a real breathing thinking feeling individual in this world. - Write a couple quotes of flavour dialogue / internal monologue from the character to experiment with their voice. Output like this: # Character 1 name <character exploration> # Character 2 name <character exploration> etc
Model Output:
# Sarah Sarah's 26 and has babysat since she was 14. Started because she liked being in other people's houses when they weren't there. Still does. She reads their mail, tries on their clothes, uses their expensive face creams. Takes small things they won't miss - single earrings, old phones, one fork from a set. Has a storage unit full of other people's things organized by family. She eats constantly but only gas station food - beef jerky, those sweaty roller hot dogs, energy drinks that taste like cough syrup. Chews with her mouth open. Picks her teeth with her car keys. Has never cooked anything that didn't come from a box. Feeds kids cereal for dinner if the parents don't leave specific instructions. Five-foot-four, soft-looking. Doughy arms, bitten nails, usually wearing the same Ohio State hoodie she's had since high school (she didn't go there). Moves like she's underwater - slow, deliberate, no wasted motion. Never hurries. Smells like cherry car air freshener because she hangs them from her belt loops. When she smiles, only her mouth moves. She doesn't have friends, just people whose kids she watches. Sleeps with some of the dads because it's something to do. They always cry after. She has a mother somewhere who calls monthly asking for money. Sarah sends it. Not from love - just to stop the calling. Lives in a studio apartment with no furniture except a mattress and a TV on the floor. Watches infomercials until 4 AM every night. Her only allegiance is to routine. Kids should be in bed by 9. Dishes should be done. She'll kill anyone who disrupts this. **Dialogue samples:** "Ruby drew you pretty good. Got the way your eyes went different directions at the end." "Your son needs more calcium. His teeth came out too easy." (Internal: *The detective's crying again. Like that helps. Like anything helps. His teeth are probably weak too.*) # Theo Marsh Twelve, but small. Looks nine. Uses this - plays younger to make people uncomfortable when he says things like "I watched our dog die and counted how long her legs kicked." Started collecting teeth at six when his fell out and his parents said the tooth fairy wasn't real. Felt betrayed. Decided teeth were currency for something else, something true. Keeps them in labeled baby food jars: "Connor P, playground, left incisor" or "Unknown woman, parking lot, wisdom." Soaks them in hydrogen peroxide until they're white. Arranges them by size, not chronologically. Has 237 teeth. Knows because he counts them every night. Skinny, sharp elbows, hair that won't lay flat. Wears the same green cargo pants every day - needs the pockets for collecting supplies: pliers, plastic bags, hydrogen peroxide travel bottles. Breathes through his mouth. Always sounds congested. Stands too close to people, studying their mouths when they talk. Loves his sister Ruby more than anything. She's the only person whose teeth he'd never take. Parents disgust him - their weakness, their lies, their fear of him. But they leave him alone now, which is all he wanted. Sarah's the first babysitter who didn't try to fix him or fear him. He wants her to stay forever. **Dialogue samples:** "Sarah, if I use the pliers at the root, they come out whole. But if I twist, they break. Which way is better?" "The detective has a gold one. Back left. Can I have it while he's still using it?" "Mom says I'm disturbed. But she takes pills to sleep and drinks wine at breakfast, so who's disturbed?" # Ruby Marsh Nine. Stopped talking two years ago after she saw something in their old house's basement. Not trauma - just decided words were inefficient. Draws instead. Goes through two sketchbooks a week.
