Her parents buy them in bulk. Draws what she sees, but more honest. Mom becomes a wine bottle with arms. Dad becomes a penis in a suit. Theo becomes a beautiful collection of bones held together with love. Sarah becomes a hole in the shape of a person. Small, even for nine. Wears only dresses - the same three in rotation. Pink, yellow, pink, yellow, pink, yellow, blue (for special occasions). Hair in two braids she does herself. One's always higher. Has her mother's face but empty of her mother's anxiety. Moves in straight lines - never arcs around furniture, just stops, turns ninety degrees, continues. Loves Theo but knows he's fragile. Knows she's the strong one. Stopped talking partly to give him something - being the weird one, the one parents worry about. It worked. They barely see her now. Perfect. Understands Sarah immediately. Recognizes the nothing inside her because Ruby has it too, just quieter. Draws Sarah pictures because Sarah's the only one who sees them honestly - as records, not art. **Internal monologue samples:** *(The man's neck opens like a mouth. Should draw this. Need more red.)* *(Sarah doesn't pretend my pictures mean something. Doesn't say "how creative" or "concerning." Just nods. Says "that's accurate.")* *(Theo's happy. His jar's almost full. Good. Tuesday was hard for him.)* # Marcus Thirty-eight. Thinks he's smart because he reads books about business strategy. Quotes Sun Tzu incorrectly. Has "FEARLESS" tattooed on his neck but brought three guys to rob one family. Tells people he's in "acquisitions." Still lives in the apartment he shared with his ex-girlfriend. She left two years ago but her shampoo's still in the shower. He smells it sometimes. Joined a gym, goes twice a month, mostly sits in the sauna reading his phone. Wears a gold chain his mother gave him. Tells people it's worth ten grand. It's worth three hundred. Six-foot-one but walks like he's six-four. Shoulders back, chin up, trying. Always trying. Gel in his hair even for home invasions. Leather jacket in summer. Sniffs constantly - deviated septum from a fight he says he won but didn't. Came for Mr. Marsh's safe. Marsh owes his boss forty grand from a poker game. Marcus thinks this job will move him up, make him management. Has a five-year plan. Won't make it five more hours. **Dialogue samples:** "Listen, sweetheart, nobody needs to get hurt. This is just business, you understand? Business." "The fuck you mean she's just sitting there? Eating? Move her, then! Christ, do I have to do everything?" "Stop looking at me, kid. Your sister, she's - stop drawing that. Stop. Please." # The Marsh Parents **David Marsh:** Forty-five, software sales, peaked at thirty-two. Has erectile dysfunction but blames his wife. Owes money to people who collect fingers. Thinks he's smarter than them. He's not. Keeps a gun in a safe he forgets the combination to. Joined a fight club once, cried when he got hit. Pays Sarah triple because she doesn't ask questions about the bruises or why the police sometimes drive by. Tall, was handsome, going soft. Wears college football shirts from a team he never played for. Speaks in corporate buzzwords at home: "Let's circle back on dinner options." **Monica Marsh:** Forty-one, interior designer who hasn't had a client in three years. Day-drinks. Night-drinks. Shower-drinks. Hates David but hates dating more. Hates the kids but loves the idea of them. Posts family photos on Instagram with captions about being "blessed." Was beautiful, now just expensive-looking. Botox, fillers, veneers. Wears yoga clothes, doesn't do yoga. Smells like white wine and desperation. They haven't fucked in two years. Both having affairs with people who also disgust them. Stay together because divorce would mean admitting failure. **Their dialogue:** David: "Sarah! Thank god. Monica's having one of her... days. There's pizza money on the counter. We'll be back late. Or tomorrow. Whatever works." Monica: "Theo's been... difficult. And Ruby still won't - you know. But you're so good with them! We're so lucky we found you!" (To each other in the car): "Don't touch me." / "I wasn't going to."

Chapter 1

Great. Now let's write this. Follow your plan. Output chapter 1, without any additional commentary. 1000 words.
Model Output:
# Chapter 1: Friday Mrs. Marsh opens the door before I knock. She's holding a wine glass with no wine in it. There's a red ring around the inside like a bathtub stain. "Sarah! Thank god." I'm eating gas station sushi. The rice is crunchy. Mr. Marsh appears behind her, buttoning his shirt wrong. Third button in the fourth hole. His neck has scratch marks that aren't from his wife. His wife's nails are bitten down to the quick. "We're going to counseling," Mrs. Marsh says. "Marriage counseling." "Couples therapy," Mr. Marsh corrects. They look at each other like dogs about to fight. The house smells like Febreze and fear sweat. I step inside. Theo's at the kitchen table sorting something in jars. Ruby's on the floor drawing. She doesn't look up. "There's pizza money on the counter," Mr. Marsh says. "We'll be back late." "Or tomorrow," Mrs. Marsh adds. "Whatever works." They leave in separate cars. Mrs. Marsh backs into the mailbox. Mr. Marsh pretends not to notice. I finish my sushi. The wasabi tastes like toothpaste. Theo comes over with a jar. "Got a new one." He shows me a molar with a silver filling. "Found it at school. Someone lost it on the basketball court." "Still has blood on it." "Yeah." He's proud. "Want to see the collection?" I follow him to his room. He has one of those beds shaped like a race car. The shelves above it hold baby food jars. Each one has teeth. Each jar has a label. "Mom, age 41, wisdom." "Unknown child, park, incisor." "Theo, age 7, canine." "Two hundred thirty-seven," he says. "Counted this morning." "You take your mom's?" "She was drunk. Didn't notice." Ruby appears in the doorway. Shows me her sketchbook. It's a drawing of a car accident. The details are accurate. Glass in the right places. Blood pooling where it would pool. Bodies bent at probable angles. "That's good," I tell her. She flips the page. Shows me another. This one's of a woman falling down stairs. The woman looks like Mrs. Marsh. The stairs look like their stairs. "Haven't happened yet," Theo says. "She draws things before sometimes." Ruby nods. Goes back downstairs. I make fish sticks. The instructions say 425 degrees for eighteen minutes. I do 450 for fifteen because I'm impatient. Theo eats his with ketchup. Ruby eats hers plain. We watch Cartoon Network. It's the old ones from when I was little. Tom hits Jerry with a hammer. Jerry's head becomes hammer-shaped. Nobody laughs. During commercials I walk around. The house has too many locks. Deadbolt, chain, sliding bolt, another deadbolt. The windows have locks too. Some have two. The basement door has four. "Dad's scared," Theo says. "Of the men who come sometimes." "When do they come?" "Thursdays usually. Sometimes Fridays." It's Friday. In the kitchen I open drawers. Normal stuff. Scissors, tape, pens that don't work. The third drawer has a wallet. Not Mr. Marsh's - his was in his pocket. This one's leather, expensive. There's $500 in it. No credit cards. The ID window is empty but there's a torn edge where a driver's license was. I take $300. Put the wallet back. Ruby brings me another drawing. It's me standing in the kitchen. Behind me are three men. I'm eating something. They have guns. "When?" I ask. She holds up nine fingers. Then eight. Then seven. Counts down. Nine-eight-seven. Tonight. "Okay." She goes back to drawing. I make popcorn. The microwave kind. Butter flavor. The kernels pop like tiny gunshots. I eat it while watching the locks. Wondering which one won't work. Theo comes down in his pajamas. They have dinosaurs on them. "Sarah, have you ever killed anyone?" "Yes." "What did it feel like?" "Wet." He thinks about this. "Was it hard?" "No." "Would you do it again?" "Probably." He smiles. It's the first time I've seen him smile. His teeth are very white. He takes good care of them. "I might want to do it someday," he says. "For teeth." "That's a reason." He goes to bed. Ruby's still drawing. I look over her shoulder. She's drawing the living room. In the picture, there are men going through drawers. I'm on the couch watching TV. One man's head is turned backward. Another is on the floor. Red crayon everywhere. She shows me her red crayon. It's almost gone. "I'll get you more," I tell her. She pats my hand. Her fingers are cold. At eight-thirty I put her to bed. She takes her sketchbook with her. Draws under the covers with a flashlight. The scratching of her pencil sounds like mice in the walls. I go back downstairs. Make more popcorn. Check the locks again. The sliding bolt on the back door is loose. Three screws missing. That'll be the one. I sit on the couch. Find a movie about sharks. The sharks look fake. The blood looks real. I eat popcorn and wait. The TV light makes shadows on the walls. They look like teeth.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 1)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter establishes an effectively unsettling tone through Sarah's disconnected narration and the dysfunctional Marsh family dynamics. The author successfully follows their plan, hitting most key plot points while maintaining the intended voice - flat, observational, treating disturbing elements with the same emotional register as mundane ones. The characterization is strong and consistent with the provided profiles. Sarah's detached observations ("The rice is crunchy," followed immediately by noticing scratch marks on Mr. Marsh's neck) effectively establish her as someone fundamentally disconnected from normal emotional responses. Theo's casual pride in his tooth collection and Ruby's prophetic drawings create an appropriately disturbing family dynamic without feeling forced. The dialogue feels natural for these characters, particularly Theo's matter-of-fact discussion about killing and Sarah's monosyllabic responses. The parents' awkward lies and transparent marital dysfunction come across as believable rather than cartoonish. However, the writing occasionally strains for effect with metaphors that don't quite land. "The red ring around the inside like a bathtub stain" feels forced, as does "The kernels pop like tiny gunshots" - the latter particularly egregious given the story's violent trajectory. These moments break the otherwise controlled tone. The pacing works well, building tension through accumulating details about the house's excessive security, the mysterious wallet, and Ruby's prophetic drawings. The chapter effectively sets up the coming violence while maintaining the veneer of a normal babysitting evening. Some descriptions verge on purple prose ("The TV light makes shadows on the walls. They look like teeth"), though they're generally kept in check by Sarah's flat narrative voice. The show-don't-tell balance is mostly effective, revealing character through action and observation rather than exposition. The chapter faithfully executes the pulp revenge setup while establishing the unique family dynamics that will presumably complicate the expected violence. It's competent genre writing with moments of genuine unease, though marred by occasional overreach. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 14 Compelling Plot: 15 Coherent: 18 Weak Dialogue: 6 Tell-Don't-Show: 7 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 8 Amateurish: 8 Purple Prose: 9 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 11 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Characters Consistent with Profile: 18 Followed Chapter Plan: 19 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 17

Chapter 2

Ok now chapter 2. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
# Chapter 2: Bedtime Nine o'clock. Time for bed. That's the rule. Ruby wants a story. I read her *Goodnight Moon*. She draws while I read. A bunny's head separated from its body. The mittens on fire. The old lady whispering "hush" with no lower jaw. "Goodnight nobody," I read. She draws nobody. It looks like me. Theo calls from the basement. "Sarah, come see." The basement smells like chemicals and death. Theo has a workbench set up. There's a cat on it. Was a cat. Now it's something else. Freeze-dried, he explains. Like astronaut food. "Found it on Maple Street. Already dead. Been working on it for three weeks." The cat's eyes are gone. Replaced with marbles. Green ones. "The chemicals need adjusting," he says. "It's too brittle. Watch." He snaps off an ear. It breaks like a potato chip. I help him mix new solution. Formaldehyde from a bottle marked "Dad's - DO NOT TOUCH." Salt. Something else that makes my eyes water. He measures carefully. Writes everything in a notebook. "I want to do Ruby's hamster next," he says. "When it dies." "It's not sick." "No. But hamsters only live two years. Mr. Whiskers is eighteen months old." Something creaks upstairs. Footsteps. Not Ruby's - she walks on her toes. These are heavy. Theo looks up. "Dad?" "Your dad wears sneakers. Those are boots." "Oh." He goes back to measuring chemicals. "Should we do something?" "Finish your project." We work on the cat for twenty more minutes. The new solution makes its fur look almost alive. Theo's happy. He puts it in a box labeled "Mr. Mittens 2.0." More footsteps upstairs. Multiple sets now. "Time for bed," I tell him. We go up. Three men in the living room. They're opening drawers, looking under cushions. One has a flashlight. Another has a garbage bag. They're being quiet. Considerate. Theo heads to his room. Stops at the top of the stairs. "Sarah, when I die, would you freeze-dry me?" "If you want." "I do. But fix my hair first. It never does what I want." "Okay." He goes to bed. I check on Ruby. She's under her covers, flashlight making a tent of light. Still drawing. Her red crayon's just a nub now. The men downstairs are getting frustrated. Can hear them whisper-arguing. Something about a safe. About Mr. Marsh owing forty thousand. About cutting losses. I go to the kitchen. Make popcorn. Third bag tonight. The microwave beeps four times when it's done. The men freeze. Then continue searching, faster now. I pour the popcorn into a bowl. Add salt. Lots of it. Walk into the living room. Sit on the couch. The men stop. One has tear tattoos. Prison tattoos, not the decorative kind. Another's younger, nervous, keeps touching his gun. The third is in charge. Gold chain, leather jacket even though it's warm. He's holding Mr. Marsh's mail. "The fuck," the nervous one says. I turn on the TV. Flip through channels. News. Commercial. Reality show about cakes. Stop on a nature documentary. Hyenas eating something while it's still alive. "Perfect," I say. The leader, Marcus, steps forward. "Listen, we don't want trouble." I shush him. Point at the TV. "This is the good part." The hyenas are really going at it now. The thing they're eating is trying to crawl away. Can't. Too many pieces missing. Marcus looks at his men. They look at me. I eat popcorn. "We're looking for something," Marcus tries again. "Something Mr. Marsh took." "Third drawer in the kitchen. Wallet with five hundred dollars. Already took three hundred. You can have the rest." "Not money. A hard drive." "Don't know about that." The nervous one pulls his gun. Points it at me. His hand's shaking. "You should go," I tell them. "Kids are sleeping." "Fuck the kids," the nervous one says. Ruby appears at the top of the stairs. Holds up a drawing. It's the nervous one. In the picture, his head's facing the wrong way. "Hi, sweetie," Marcus says. His voice changes. Softer. "Go back to bed." She shows him another picture. This one's of Marcus. He's in pieces. Organized pieces. Labeled. "Jesus," the one with tear tattoos says. Ruby goes back to her room. "That's disturbing," Marcus says. "She's nine." "Still." The hyenas finish eating. The thing stops moving. Commercials come on. I mute them. "Your friend's going upstairs," I tell Marcus. He turns. The one with tear tattoos is on the stairs. Trying to be quiet. The seventh step creaks. He freezes. "Seventh and twelfth," I say. "Avoid those." He does. Makes it to the top. Opens the first door. Bathroom. Opens the second. Ruby's room. Silence. Then a wet sound. Like stepping on a tomato. "Rick?" Marcus calls. Nothing. Marcus sends the nervous one. "Check on Rick." The nervous one goes. Avoids the seventh and twelfth steps. He's learning. Opens Ruby's door. "Oh fuck. Oh Jesus. Oh fuck." Then nothing. Marcus is sweating now. His leather jacket squeaks when he moves. "What did you do?" he asks me. "I'm watching TV." The hyenas are back. Found something new to eat. "Perfect timing," I say. Marcus backs toward the door. Tries the handle. It's locked. The deadbolt. Both deadbolts. The chain. The sliding bolt. "When did you lock this?" "I didn't." Ruby's at the top of the stairs again. Holds up a key ring. Jingles it. Goes back to her room. Marcus takes out his gun. "This is happening," he says. "Yeah." I eat more popcorn. It needs more salt.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 2)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter demonstrates strong craft in building tension through contrast between the mundane and the disturbing. The author maintains Sarah's established voice - detached, matter-of-fact narration that treats violence and domesticity with equal indifference. The pacing is deliberate, moving from bedtime routine to basement scene to home invasion without rushing. The characterization remains consistent with the established profiles. Sarah's flat affect while helping Theo with his freeze-dried cat project perfectly captures her disconnection from normal emotional responses. Theo's scientific approach to death and preservation feels authentically disturbed rather than cartoonish. Ruby's silent communication through increasingly violent drawings maintains her established character while building dread. The dialogue serves both character and plot effectively. Sarah's monosyllabic responses and practical observations ("Seventh and twelfth. Avoid those.") maintain her established voice while the criminals' increasingly desperate exchanges feel believable. Marcus's attempts to maintain control while clearly losing it ring true for a mid-level criminal in over his head. The author avoids common pitfalls of pulp writing - no purple prose, no forced metaphors, no overexplaining. The violence is implied rather than gratuitously described, which makes it more unsettling. The juxtaposition of Ruby's bedtime routine with her drawings of dismemberment creates genuine unease. The escalation feels earned rather than contrived. The intruders' frustration builds naturally, and their discovery by the children follows logically from the house layout and character behaviors established earlier. The locked door revelation provides a satisfying trap without feeling like a deus ex machina. Minor weaknesses include some repetitive sentence structures and occasionally stilted transitions, but these don't significantly detract from the overall effectiveness. The chapter successfully builds toward the promised violence while maintaining the established tone and character dynamics. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Compelling Plot: 16 Coherent: 18 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3 Amateurish: 4 Purple Prose: 2 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Characters Consistent with Profile: 19 Followed Chapter Plan: 18 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 17

Chapter 3

Ok now chapter 3. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
# Chapter 3: Introductions Marcus points his gun at my head. The barrel touches my forehead. It's warm. "Tell me what happened to my guys." "They're upstairs." "Get them down here." "Can't. They're busy." I eat another handful of popcorn. A kernel falls on the couch. I pick it up, eat it. Marcus's hand is shaking. The gun barrel makes little circles on my skin. "You're going up there with me," he says. "Okay." We go upstairs. He keeps the gun on my back. His breathing's loud. Sounds like Theo when his allergies act up. "Which room?" "Second door." He opens it. Rick's sitting in Ruby's tiny pink chair. Very still. There are scissors in his neck. Children's scissors with rubber grips. Purple ones. Ruby's drawing him. Getting the way his eyes went different directions. "The fuck," Marcus says. "She's good at portraits." The nervous one's in the bathroom. The toilet's overflowing. Red water on the white tile. His head's in the bowl. Theo's standing on a stepstool, brushing his teeth. Using the nervous one's toothbrush. "His teeth are really white," Theo tells me. "He used whitening strips. See?" He smiles to show his own teeth. They're pink. Marcus backs into the hallway. Bumps into me. Makes a sound like a stepped-on dog. "What are you people?" "I'm the babysitter." Ruby comes out of her room. Shows Marcus a new drawing. It's him at the bottom of the stairs. His leg's bent wrong. Bone showing. "That hasn't happened yet," I tell him. He runs for the stairs. Grabs the bannister. It comes off in his hand. He falls backward, tumbles down. Lands at the bottom. His right leg bends sideways at the shin. The bone comes through his pants like a white flag. He screams. "Too loud," I say. "Kids need sleep." I go to the kitchen. Get dish towels. Come back. He's trying to crawl to the door. His leg drags behind him. Leaves a snail trail of red. I stuff a dish towel in his mouth. He bites down. Makes sounds like a baby crying. Ruby and Theo come downstairs. Ruby's got her sketchbook. Theo's got a jar. "Can I have his teeth?" Theo asks. "He's still using them." "I can wait." I drag Marcus to the kitchen. He's heavy. His jacket makes squeaky sounds on the tile. The kids follow. Ruby sits at the table. Starts a new drawing. Theo gets his pliers from his cargo pants. "Not yet," I tell him. Marcus is trying to say something through the dish towel. I take it out. "Please. Please. I have a daughter." "No you don't." "I could. Someday." I put the towel back. "Sarah," Theo says. "How do you take someone apart?" "Like chicken." "I don't know how to do chicken." "I'll show you." I get a knife from the drawer. The good one Mrs. Marsh uses for dinner parties. Never been used. "Joints first," I tell him. "They come apart easy if you know where to cut." Marcus passes out. I slap him awake. "You need to be awake for this part." Ruby shows me her drawing. It's Marcus in pieces. Labeled like a butcher's diagram. Shoulder. Shank. Tenderloin. "That's helpful," I tell her. She starts another one. Theo takes notes in his freeze-dry notebook. Asks questions. Good questions. About tendons and ligaments. About why blood comes out fast sometimes and slow others. "Arteries versus veins," I explain. Marcus passes out again. Wakes up. Passes out. His eyes roll back. Show all white like boiled eggs. "Is he dying?" Theo asks. "Yeah." "How long?" "Hour maybe." "Can I have his teeth now?" "Sure." Theo gets to work with the pliers. Focused. Careful. Marcus makes new sounds. Theo counts as he goes. "One. Two. Three. That one's gold!" Ruby tugs my sleeve. Shows me her new drawing. Four men at the door. One's a cop. "When?" She holds up ten fingers. Then makes a zero with her hand. Ten minutes. "Okay." I make hot chocolate. The instant kind with tiny marshmallows. They float on top like little life rafts. Give cups to the kids. Marcus watches us drink. His mouth's all red. Looks like lipstick. "You were right about the gold tooth," I tell Theo. "It's heavy. Real gold's heavy." Someone knocks on the door. Hard. Cop knock. "Police. Open up." I look at Marcus. "You called the cops?" He shakes his head. Spits blood. Another knock. "We know you're in there. Neighbor called about screaming." "That's Mrs. Patterson," Theo says. "She's nosy." I go to the door. Open it partway. Four men. One has a badge. The others are trying to look official but their shoes are wrong. Cops wear ugly comfortable shoes. These are wearing expensive sneakers. "Evening officer." The badge one looks past me. Sees my apron. It's covered in handprints. Red ones. "Everything okay here?" "Making cookies with the kids." "Sounded like someone screaming." "TV. Kids like horror movies." He doesn't believe me. Pushes the door wider. Sees the living room. Marcus's blood trail to the kitchen. "Ma'am, we're coming in." "Okay." They come in. All four. The fake cops have their hands on their guns. The real one's already drawn his. Ruby comes out from the kitchen. She's dragging something in her Frozen bedsheet. It's heavy. Leaves a red smear. "Jesus Christ," one of the fake cops says. Theo follows with his jar. It's full now. Pink liquid with white things floating. "I got them all," he tells me. "Even the molars." The cops open fire.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 3)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter delivers precisely what the writing plan promised: flat, disconnected narration of escalating violence through Sarah's emotionally vacant perspective. The prose maintains a deliberately monotone voice that treats dismemberment with the same detachment as making snacks, which is both the piece's greatest strength and potential weakness. The characterization is remarkably consistent with the provided profiles. Sarah's underwater-slow movements, her matter-of-fact responses to extreme situations, and her complete lack of emotional reaction create an unsettling protagonist exactly as outlined. Theo's tooth obsession and Ruby's disturbing artwork are well-integrated into the action rather than feeling like arbitrary quirks. Marcus serves his function as the overconfident criminal, though he remains more of a plot device than a fully realized character. The violence escalates naturally from the setup, with each death more disturbing than the last. The children's casual participation in torture and murder is genuinely unsettling, avoiding the common trap of making fictional children artificially innocent or brave. Ruby's predictive drawings and Theo's clinical interest in teeth collection feel authentic to their established psychologies. The dialogue serves the story well, staying sparse and functional. Sarah's responses ("They're upstairs." "Can't. They're busy.") perfectly capture her flat affect, while Theo's questions about teeth extraction feel believable for his character. The conversations never feel forced or overly expository. The prose avoids purple writing while still containing effective imagery. Simple metaphors like "bone comes through his pants like a white flag" land without feeling strained. The pacing builds tension effectively, moving from Marcus's initial confidence to his growing horror as he discovers his men's fates. However, the piece's commitment to emotional flatness, while stylistically coherent, limits deeper engagement. The shock value, while intentional, may overshadow other literary merits. The violence serves the character development and plot, but readers seeking more than visceral reaction might find it somewhat hollow. The chapter follows its plan faithfully and delivers a genuinely unsettling "wrong babysitter" narrative that avoids typical action-hero tropes in favor of something more disturbing and psychologically cold. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 14 Emotionally Engaging: 12 Compelling Plot: 15 Coherent: 18 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 5 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 8 Amateurish: 6 Purple Prose: 3 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 4 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Characters Consistent with Profile: 19 Followed Chapter Plan: 19 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 18

Chapter 4

Ok now chapter 4. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
# Chapter 4: Commercial Break The bullets miss mostly. One goes through my shoulder. Feels like a wasp sting. Then hot. Then nothing. I fall behind the kitchen island with the kids. The cabinets explode. Flour. Sugar. Rice Krispies. Everything white and floating. Theo holds his jar against his chest. Ruby keeps drawing. "You hit?" I ask them. Theo checks himself. "No." Ruby shows me her drawing. She's fine. The cops reload. Can hear them stepping on cereal. Crunch crunch crunch. "Come out," the real cop says. "Nobody else needs to get hurt." Marcus makes a sound from where we left him. Gurgling. "Shut him up," one of the fake cops says. Someone kicks Marcus. He stops gurgling. I open the drawer above my head. Silverware. Open the next one. Dish towels. Third one. Knives. "Sarah," Theo whispers. "I dropped a tooth." "Which one?" "The gold one." "We'll find it later." Ruby shows me a new drawing. Me standing up. Knife in each hand. The real cop has no face in the picture. Just red. "When?" She holds up three fingers. I wait. Count three Mississippi in my head. Stand up. The cop with the badge is closest. He shoots. Misses. I don't. The knife goes in his eye. He falls backward. Shoots the ceiling. Plaster rains down. One fake cop vomits on his expensive sneakers. I grab him while he's bent over. Use him as a shield. His friends shoot him for me. He's heavy. Full of holes. Leaking. I throw a knife at the second fake cop. Gets him in the throat. He makes a whistling sound like a teakettle. Falls into the refrigerator. Magnets everywhere. Theo's report card. Ruby's drawings. A photo from last Christmas - everyone pretending to be happy. The last fake cop runs. I follow. He makes it to the living room. Trips on Marcus's blood trail. Slides into the coffee table. It breaks. Glass everywhere. I step on his ankle. It pops like bubble wrap. "Please," he says. "I got kids." "Names?" He can't think of any. Ruby appears. Shows him a drawing. It's his kids. They don't have faces yet because they don't exist. I drag him back to the kitchen. Theo's examining the cop with the badge. "His teeth are perfect," he says. "Veneers. Not real." "Can you use them?" "No. Fake teeth are worthless." The fake cop with the throat whistle stops whistling. The one I'm dragging is crying. Snot bubbles. "Theo, get the mop," I tell him. "Which one?" "The one for hardwood." He gets it. I clean up some of the blood. Don't want the kids slipping. Safety first. The crying cop tries to crawl away. His ankle doesn't work. He uses his elbows. Like a worm. "Where are you going?" I ask. "Hospital." "It's closed." "Hospitals don't close." "This one does." Ruby draws him a map. Shows him how to get to the hospital. In her map, he doesn't make it. Too many pieces missing. I put him in Mr. Marsh's office with Marcus. Marcus is still alive. Barely. Making sounds like a broken garbage disposal. "You guys know each other?" The crying cop nods. "Good. You can keep each other company." I find Mr. Marsh's toolbox in the garage. Good tools. Expensive. Never used. The nail gun's still in its box. The instructions are in English and Spanish. I read both versions. They say the same thing. Back in the office. Marcus watches me load the nail gun. His eyes are all pupil. Black circles. "This is for furniture," I tell him. "But we'll make it work." I nail the crying cop's hands to Mr. Marsh's desk. He screams. I nail his feet to the floor. He screams louder. "Too loud," I say. Get another dish towel. He bites through it. I get one of Theo's socks. Works better. "Sarah," Theo calls. "Found the gold tooth!" "Good." "It was in the cereal." "Wash it off." Ruby comes in with her sketchbook. Shows Marcus what happens next. He closes his eyes. She pokes him. He opens them. She shows him again. The crying cop is trying to pull his hands free. Each pull makes it worse. The nails are three inches long. They go through hand, through desk, into the wood beneath. "Those are good nails," I tell him. "Galvanized." Marcus dies at 11:47. Just stops. Like a TV turning off. The crying cop watches it happen. Makes a sound through the sock. "Your turn soon," I tell him. Ruby draws Marcus dead. Gets the way his jaw hangs open. The way his eyes look at nothing. Theo comes in with his supplies. "Can I practice on the dead one?" "Sure." He starts taking Marcus apart. Careful. Scientific. Takes notes between cuts. Ruby draws each step. They work well together. Silent. Focused. The crying cop watches. Can't not watch. Throws up through the sock. Chokes on it. I take the sock out. He throws up more. On himself. On the desk. "You're making a mess." "Sorry. Sorry. I'm sorry." "Don't apologize. Just die quieter." I leave him there. Make sandwiches. Peanut butter for Theo. Jam for Ruby. Cut the crusts off. She doesn't like crusts. We eat in the living room. Watch TV. Commercial for a new movie. Everyone's beautiful. Everyone lives. "Unrealistic," I say. Ruby nods. Shows me her drawing of how it really ends. Everyone's in pieces. Everyone's labeled. "That's better." The crying cop stops crying at 12:52. Stops breathing at 1:15. Stops everything at 1:23. Theo harvests his teeth. They're nothing special. "Marcus had better teeth," he says. Disappointed. "Next time." "You think there'll be a next time?" Ruby shows us her drawing. Next Friday. Different house. Different bodies. Same us. "Yeah," I say. "There'll be a next time."
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 4)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter delivers competent pulp horror with a distinctly flat, documentary-style narration that matches the established voice. The writing maintains the deliberately disconnected tone where Sarah describes extreme violence with the same affect as mundane activities. The character consistency is strong - Ruby continues her silent drawing obsession, Theo remains focused on his tooth collection even during gunfire, and Sarah maintains her eerie calm throughout chaos. The action sequences are well-choreographed and visceral without being gratuitously descriptive. The dialogue is sparse but effective, particularly Sarah's deadpan responses like asking for the crying cop's children's names when he claims to have kids, then noting he can't think of any. The scene flows logically within its twisted internal logic. However, there's a significant structural problem: this chapter doesn't match the stated plan for Chapter 4 at all. According to the plan, Chapter 4 should involve Marcus going upstairs to find his men dead (one with scissors in his neck in Ruby's room, another in the bathroom), then falling down the stairs when the bannister gives way. Instead, this appears to be elements from the planned Chapter 6, involving multiple armed men, a police detective, and a kitchen gunfight. The writing avoids purple prose and forced metaphors, maintaining the stark, observational style throughout. The children's reactions remain genuinely unsettling - Ruby drawing throughout the violence, Theo disappointed that the fake cop's teeth aren't worth collecting. These details maintain the story's disturbing tone without feeling forced. The violence escalates appropriately and the chapter maintains narrative momentum, but the disconnect from the stated plan undermines the structural integrity of the overall work. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 14 Compelling Plot: 15 Coherent: 16 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 3 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5 Amateurish: 6 Purple Prose: 2 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Characters Consistent with Profile: 18 Followed Chapter Plan: 2 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 17

Chapter 5

Ok now chapter 5. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
# Chapter 5: Cleanup Seven bodies. I count them with the kids. "Like a word problem," I tell them. "Seven bodies. Three rooms. How do we organize?" Theo raises his hand. "By freshness?" "Good idea." Ruby draws a floor plan. X marks for bodies. Arrows for where to move them. We start with the kitchen. The cop with no face is leaking into the cereal. The Froot Loops are turning pink. "That's wasteful," Theo says. "It's generic brand." "Still." I show them how to wrap a body. Shower curtains work best. The Marshes have four bathrooms. Four shower curtains. Not enough. "What else can we use?" I ask. "Tarps," Theo says. "Where?" "Garage. Dad has painting stuff." He gets them. Blue tarps. Paint-splattered but functional. We wrap the faceless cop first. Duct tape around the middle. Around the feet. Around where his face used to be. "Like a present," Theo says. "Exactly." Ruby draws each step. Her technique's improving. She's learning about shadows. How blood pools. Where bodies bend. The one with the throat whistle is harder. He's stuck to the refrigerator with his own blood. Frozen there. Have to use a spatula to peel him off. "This is why you clean up fresh," I tell them. Theo takes notes. We make an assembly line. I wrap. Theo tapes. Ruby labels each bundle with her drawings. Who they were. How they died. Time of death if we know it. The vomit one's the worst. Can't get the smell out. Even wrapped, he reeks. "Baking soda," Theo suggests. "For later. When he's in pieces." "We're taking them apart?" "Have to. Seven bodies won't fit in the trash." "What about the garbage disposal?" "Too slow. Too loud." Ruby shows us her drawing. A hacksaw. The good one from the garage. "Smart," I tell her. We move the wrapped bodies to the basement. Stack them like firewood. The freezer's down there. Big chest freezer where Mrs. Marsh keeps bulk purchases from Costco. Forty pounds of chicken breasts. Twenty pounds of ground beef. Room for more. "Empty the freezer," I tell Theo. He does. We put the meat in the sink to thaw. Can't waste it. That would be suspicious. "How many bodies fit in a freezer?" Theo asks. "Depends on the pieces." "How many pieces per body?" "Depends how small you cut." Ruby draws the math. Seven bodies. Fourteen arms. Fourteen legs. Seven heads. Seven torsos. If we separate at the joints: fingers, hands, forearms, upper arms. Toes, feet, ankles, shins, thighs. "Two hundred and eighty pieces," Theo calculates. "If we do fingers and toes separate." "We don't need to be that thorough." "But we could be." "We could." Back upstairs. The kitchen's destroyed. Bullet holes. Blood. Cereal. Plaster. Can't leave it like this. "Bleach?" Theo asks. "No. Bleach reacts with blood. Turns it pink. Then everyone knows you were cleaning blood." "What then?" "Hydrogen peroxide first. Then soap. Then bleach if you want." We clean. Takes two hours. Ruby draws while we work. The kitchen at different stages. Crime scene. Active cleaning. Almost normal. Normal. Theo's meticulous. Gets every drop. Counts them as he goes. "Four thousand seven hundred thirty-two," he announces. "You missed some." I point to the ceiling. He sighs. Gets the stepladder. At 2 AM we take a break. Make grilled cheese. The bread has blood on it but we cut that part off. The cheese melts normal. Tastes normal. "This is nice," Theo says. "What is?" "Family time." Ruby nods. Shows us a drawing. The three of us at the table. Eating. Behind us, the wrapped bodies stacked neat. Like a Christmas card. "We should do the dismemberment," I say. "Can I try?" Theo asks. "Sure." We go to the basement. Unwrap the one who vomited. He's stiff now. Rigor mortis. "Harder when they're stiff," I explain. "Should have done this earlier." "How do you know all this?" Theo asks. "I don't know." "But you know." "Yeah." "That doesn't make sense." "Most things don't." Ruby draws me thinking about it. In her picture, my head's empty except for little drawings of violence. Like a filing cabinet. Organized. I show Theo how to find the joints. How to separate cartilage. How to use the saw when you hit bone. He's a quick learner. Focused. Doesn't get squeamish when the smell hits. "It's just meat," he says. "Exactly." Ruby labels the pieces as we go. Cop 1: Left Arm. Cop 1: Right Thigh. Like a butcher shop. But more specific. By 3 AM we've done three bodies. The freezer's getting full. The others will have to wait. "What about the heads?" Theo asks. "What about them?" "Do we keep them?" "Why would we?" "Teeth." "You already got the teeth." "Oh. Right." Someone knocks on the front door. Heavy. Multiple fists. Ruby shows me her drawing. Four more men. Different men. Angry men. "Friends of Marcus?" I ask. She shrugs. Draws one with a baseball bat. "Okay." I go upstairs. Look through the peephole. Four men. One has a bat. Another has a crowbar. They look tired. Frustrated. "We know Marcus came here," one shouts. "Open up." I open the door. Still wearing the apron. It's more red than white now. "Marcus isn't here." "His car's here." "He isn't." The one with the bat pushes past me. Sees the clean kitchen. Too clean. Two in the morning clean. "Where is he?" "In pieces."
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 5)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter effectively maintains the disturbing tone and voice established in the writing plan, presenting the aftermath of violence with the same flat, matter-of-fact narration that characterizes Sarah's perspective. The writing succeeds in treating dismemberment and body disposal with the same casual efficiency as a household chore, which aligns perfectly with the established character dynamics. The characterization remains strong and consistent. Sarah continues to display her emotionally disconnected pragmatism, Theo shows his methodical curiosity about violence, and Ruby maintains her silent documentation through increasingly sophisticated artwork. The family dynamic between the three characters during cleanup feels genuinely unsettling yet oddly domestic. The technical aspects of the writing are competent. The dialogue is sparse but effective, serving the flat affect that defines the narrative voice. The prose avoids purple flourishes, maintaining the deliberately mundane tone even when describing extreme violence. The show-don't-tell approach works well, with concrete actions and minimal exposition. However, there are significant deviations from the stated chapter plan. The plan called for Marcus to be dragged to the kitchen while screaming, for Sarah to teach dismemberment while he's still alive and conscious, and for hot chocolate to be made during the process. Instead, the chapter focuses on cleanup of already-dead bodies with no mention of Marcus being present. The plan's specific beats about Marcus passing out and waking up repeatedly are entirely absent. The writing also occasionally falls into mechanical repetition, particularly in the dialogue exchanges and the cataloguing of body parts. While this serves the clinical tone, it sometimes feels more like a writing exercise than organic narrative flow. The mathematical precision of the dismemberment discussion, while fitting the characters, occasionally reads more like a checklist than natural conversation. The chapter succeeds in its disturbing premise and maintains tonal consistency, but the significant departure from the planned structure and some mechanical elements prevent it from reaching its full potential.
