(pause) No, that's a lie. But I've seen comparable." # Tom (?) Nobody's entirely sure. Might be Tim. Arrived a month ago, or three weeks, or he's always been there. Claims he was an accountant but holds a knife like a soldier. Missing two fingers on his left hand - story changes: mutant, accident, frostbite, was born that way. Laughs at inappropriate times. Either forgets to blink or stares without breaking. Makes origami from wrapper garbage when his hands are idle. Definitely had a different name before. Aggressively average face that's hard to remember even while looking at it. Moves with too much or too little purpose, nothing in between. Puts things in his pockets that aren't his. Stands in doorways. Breathes too quietly. Here but not here, like a placeholder for someone more real. Survives. That's it. That's all. Attached to the group like a remora, feeding on their certainty. No loyalty, no betrayal, just presence. Might be dangerous or might be nothing. Watches Marie cook with either hunger or study. Agrees with whoever spoke last. "Yes." "That reminds me of‚Äî never mind." "I had a dog once. (long pause) Or a brother."

Chapter 1

Great. Now let's write this. Follow your plan. Output chapter 1, without any additional commentary. 1000 words.
Model Output:
# Chapter 1: The Good Fat The thing is coming apart under my knife like it wants to. Like it's been waiting for this. David's screaming something about his shoulder but I'm looking at where my blade went too deep, past the mutant's spine and into the meat of it, and there's this marbling running through the muscle like‚Äî Jesus. Like wagyu. Like those $300 steaks Marcus used to show me photos of back when the restaurant had a beef program and I was still lying about being sous chef. The mutant's not quite dead. Its spores are puffing out in little gasps that smell like truffle oil and copper. David's still screaming. The fat under its skin is white as butter. "Marie. MARIE." I snap back. Pull the knife out. The mutant drops and David's clutching his shoulder where the thing got him with those fingernails that aren't fingernails anymore. Rosa's already there with the vodka we've been saving. Kai's vomiting in the corner again. Tom (Tim?) is standing in the doorway, watching. "Is it dead?" David asks. I look down. The thing that used to be someone's grandmother or father or teenage son is twitching in a pool of its own fluids. The marbling catches the light from our last working flashlight. "Yeah." We've been eating dandelions for two weeks. Dandelions and those bitter roots Rosa insists are medicinal and half a can of water chestnuts I've been rationing like communion wafers. Yesterday Kai brought back a pigeon but it was mostly feathers and disappointment. My stomach's been eating itself since Tuesday. Or what I think was Tuesday. That night I wait until everyone's sleeping. David's moaning through his vodka haze. Rosa's making her lists out loud in whispers. Kai's doing that thing where he scratches himself raw. Tom's either asleep or dead in the corner‚ÄîI should check but I don't. I take the jar. The good jar, the one with the seal that still works. The mutant's where we left it because where else would it be? We don't bury them anymore. Too many. Too tired. The meat around the wound I made has darkened but when I cut deeper, it's pink. Perfect pink. That beautiful marbling spreading like roads on a map to nowhere. I take the tenderloin. Or what would be tenderloin on a pig. On a person. On a whatever-this-is. Back in the kitchen that isn't a kitchen‚Äîjust a corner with a camp stove and my pan, the cast iron I've been babying for three years‚ÄîI bring out the bacon grease. Been saving it in a tin like my grandmother did. No bacon for eighteen months but the grease remains. Holy oil. Sacred fat. The meat hits the pan and the sound is sexual. That sizzle. That immediate crust forming. Seventeen. Eighteen. Nineteen bites if I cut it small. I cut it small. The smell fills our shelter and I should worry about the others waking but I'm crying now, actually crying, because it smells like food. Like real food. Like before-food. Like Saturday morning breakfast-for-dinner food. Like first-date-trying-to-impress food. Three minutes each side. The fat renders out clear and clean. No foam. No weird colors. Just meat doing what meat does when you treat it right. I take the first bite too hot and it burns my tongue but I don't care because it's‚Äî fuck. Fuck me. It's perfect. It's better than perfect. It's got that umami depth, that almost-mineral backend that good beef has, but there's something else. Something bright. Almost citrus. The fat melts like bone marrow. Twenty. Twenty-one. Twenty-two. I'm making sounds I haven't made in two years. These little moans that would be embarrassing if shame still existed. The tenderloin's gone so I go back to the pan, run my finger through the rendered fat and grease. It coats my mouth like a promise. There's more on the body. Second trip. I take the strip along the back. The cheek meat. Something that might be kidney but looks too pretty to be organ meat. My knife work's getting sloppy because my hands are shaking. Hungry shaking. Or something else. I cook it all. Every piece. The kitchen fills with smoke but who cares? The cheek meat falls apart like pot roast. The maybe-kidney tastes like concentrated life. The backstrap has this texture like scallops but better, meatier, more itself. I eat until my stomach hurts. Until my jaw aches. Until I can't tell if I'm laughing or sobbing. Both. Neither. I lick the pan clean, my tongue finding every brown bit, every trace of fat. I suck the grease from under my fingernails. Forty-three. Forty-four. Forty-five bites. When I finally stop, I'm lying on the floor looking at the ceiling that might be growing something or might just be water damage. My stomach's making sounds like distant thunder. Satisfied sounds. Happy stomach sounds I'd forgotten existed. I should feel sick. Guilty. Something. Instead I'm thinking about breakfast. About how the thigh meat would take a slower cook. How the organs might work in a hash. Whether the spinal fluid would reduce to a glaze. I'm thinking about marinades. Rosa finds me in the morning, the pan clutched to my chest like a baby. "What did you do?" she asks, but she already knows. The smell tells everything. I look at her. Really look at her. Past the tired, past the hungry, to the part that wants to survive. "I made dinner."
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 1)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter demonstrates sophisticated execution of a challenging premise, blending visceral horror with sensual food writing to create an unsettling but compelling narrative voice. The author successfully captures Marie's perspective as someone whose culinary background becomes both salvation and damnation in the post-apocalyptic setting. The characterization is particularly strong. Marie's voice feels authentic - her professional food knowledge mixed with obvious insecurities (the lies about being sous chef), her compulsive bite counting, and her desperate hunger all align perfectly with the character profile. The way she processes this transgressive act through familiar culinary frameworks ("like wagyu," "like scallops but better") creates cognitive dissonance that drives the horror. The prose walks a difficult tightrope between sensual food writing and body horror. Phrases like "The meat hits the pan and the sound is sexual" and the detailed description of marbling work because they're filtered through Marie's professional obsession with food. However, some metaphors feel slightly forced - "fingernails that aren't fingernails anymore" lacks the precision of the better food imagery. The pacing is excellent, building from desperate action to secretive transgression to complete surrender to appetite. The author wisely focuses on the sensory experience rather than moral implications, which serves both the "cozy" aspect and Marie's increasingly unreliable narration. Technical execution is strong throughout. The author shows rather than tells Marie's transformation, lets her actions and obsessive focus reveal character, and maintains consistent voice. The bite counting (a detail from the character profile) becomes both compulsive behavior and narrative rhythm. The chapter serves its function well as an opening, establishing the core transgression that will drive the rest of the story. It follows the chapter plan closely while adding effective details like the bacon grease ritual and Rosa's knowing reaction at the end. Minor weaknesses include occasional overwrought moments ("Holy oil. Sacred fat.") and some repetitive phrasing, but these don't significantly detract from an otherwise accomplished piece that successfully launches a difficult premise. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Compelling Plot: 16 Coherent: 18 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 2 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 4 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 5 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Characters Consistent with Profile: 19 Followed Chapter Plan: 18 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 19

Chapter 2

Ok now chapter 2. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
# Chapter 2: Breakfast Three days later. Or a week. Time's gone elastic since the meat started disappearing. Tom's standing there and I've got a chunk in my mouth, raw, still warm from the body I found this morning. Not killed. Found. There's a difference. The texture's like tuna sashimi but wrong, fibers running the wrong direction, and I'm sucking the juice from it when he says: "Oh." Just that. Oh. The meat's hanging from my mouth and I could drop it, pretend it's something else, but we're past that. We're so far past that. I bite through. Chew twice. Swallow. "Want some?" He looks at the body. Female, maybe. Young by the lack of scarring. The good fat concentrated in the hips and upper arms. I've already taken the best bits‚Äîthe tender nuggets behind the knees, the sweet meat between the ribs. My fingernails are pink with it. Tom (I'm almost sure it's Tom) makes a sound like a question. I tear off a strip from the shoulder. Hand it to him. He takes it with those three fingers on his left hand, examines it like evidence. "Just eat it." He does. His whole body convulses. He runs to the corner and vomits, really vomits, not like Kai's performative gagging. Comes back wiping his mouth. "More." This time I give him belly meat, softer, less aggressive. He keeps it down. Chews thoughtfully. His face does something that might be surprise. "It's‚Äî" "I know." "But it's‚Äî" "I know." By dawn we're both on our third helping and I'm showing him things. The way the grain changes near the joints. How to identify good marbling by candlelight. The smell difference between fresh dead and too dead. My notebook's out and I'm sketching diagrams while he holds pieces up for comparison. "This part here," I say, running my finger along what would be the psoas major if I'm remembering David's bullshit Latin correctly, "this is money. This is what you save for when you're really hungry." "I'm really hungry now." "No. Hungrier." Tom nods like this makes sense. He's got blood under his remaining fingernails. There's something on his chin that might be fat or might be drool. "My brother was a butcher," he says suddenly. "Yeah?" "Or my father. Someone." Kai's in the doorway. Has been for who knows how long. Watching us portion out someone's parent or child or lover like we're breaking down a deer. His face is doing that thing where he wants to look disgusted but can't stop staring. His tongue keeps darting out to wet his lips. "Morning, Kai." He doesn't answer. Steps closer. The body between us like a table full of breakfast. "Rosa know?" he asks. "Rosa knows everything," I say, which isn't an answer but is. Tom's discovered the organs. He's holding the liver up to the light from the window, studying the deep purple shine of it. "Can we eat this?" "Can we?" Kai asks, and his voice cracks on the want. I take the liver from Tom, feel its weight. Still warm. Still perfect. "Twenty minutes in the pan. Low heat. Don't overcook it or it gets chalky." "How do you know?" Kai's closer now. Close enough I can smell his hunger-breath. "I just do." --- **MORNING SCRAMBLE** *Serves 4 or 2 very hungry people* - 2 cups diced [PROTEIN], cut against grain - 6 eggs (theoretical) - 1 onion, minced (if onions existed) - Salt (remember salt?) - Pepper (a dream) - The good fat - Fresh herbs (whatever's growing in the dark) - Shame (optional) Heat pan until it sings. Add fat. When it shimmers like heat waves off summer asphalt, add protein. Don't stir. Let it crust. Let it brown. Let it become itself. If eggs existed, scramble them separately. Fold them in gentle. But eggs don't exist so just eat the meat and pretend. The pretending is important. Garnish with herbs that might be parsley or might be weeds. No one can tell anymore. Serve immediately. Serve hot. Serve before the others wake and ask questions. Pairs well with forgetting. --- "You're writing recipes?" Kai's reading over my shoulder. "Documentation." "For who?" I don't answer. Tom's cooking the liver and the smell is making all of us lean toward the pan like plants toward light. David's voice drifts from the other room, still moaning about his shoulder. Rosa's humming something that might be a lullaby. "Should we save them some?" Tom asks. We look at each other. At the body that's already looking less like a person and more like provisions. At our red hands. At the pan where the liver's browning perfect and sweet. "They'll eat when they're ready," I say. Kai makes a sound that wants to be a laugh. "We're all ready. We've been ready. We just didn't know it." The liver's done. We eat it with our fingers, burning them on the crispy edges. Tom closes his eyes while he chews. Kai moans. Actually moans. I'm counting bites again‚Äîsix, seven, eight‚Äîand thinking about lunch. "There's more outside," Kai says through a mouthful. "Three more. Found them this morning." "Fresh?" "Fresh enough." Tom's already reaching for the knife. I'm already thinking about dinner. About whether the brain would scramble like eggs. About what temperature renders shame. Rosa appears in the doorway. Looks at us. At the body. At our faces shining with grease. "Save me the tenderloin," she says, and shuffles back to bed.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 2)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter effectively advances the central premise with a darkly compelling blend of cozy domesticity and visceral horror. The writing maintains Marie's unreliable, food-obsessed voice while showing the spread of cannibalistic normalization through the group. Strengths include strong character differentiation - each person has distinct reactions and mannerisms that feel authentic to their established profiles. Tom's vague confusion about his identity, Kai's conflicted arousal/disgust, and Rosa's pragmatic acceptance all ring true. The dialogue is naturalistic and revealing, particularly the understated exchanges that carry heavy subtext. The sensory details are viscerally effective without becoming gratuitously purple. Descriptions like "fingernails pink with it" and "tongue darting out to wet his lips" create visceral impact through specificity rather than overwrought language. The recipe format provides an unsettling counterpoint that reinforces the theme of normalizing the abnormal. The chapter follows its planned structure faithfully while maintaining narrative momentum. The time ambiguity ("Three days later. Or a week") effectively reinforces the unreliable narrator and dissociative atmosphere. However, some metaphors feel slightly strained - "Time's gone elastic since the meat started disappearing" works better than "like plants toward light" which is more conventional. The piece occasionally veers toward forced poeticism in phrases like "heat waves off summer asphalt" that don't quite earn their lyrical reach. The horror remains effectively understated rather than explicit, maintaining the "cozy horror" tone requested in the prompt. The gradual revelation of Rosa's awareness and casual acceptance provides a strong ending that suggests the complete normalization of their new reality. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Compelling Plot: 15 Coherent: 16 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 5 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3 Amateurish: 4 Purple Prose: 6 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 7 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Characters Consistent with Profile: 18 Followed Chapter Plan: 18 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 17

Chapter 3

Ok now chapter 3. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
# Chapter 3: The Fat Tuesday Argument "That's MY portion." David's holding his plate like a shield, grease running down his wrist. Rosa's got her fork in what he claims is his but we all know is communal. The thing about the end of the world is property rights get fuzzy. "You had the liver yesterday," Rosa says, not moving her fork. "That was different liver." "It was literally the same body." "Different organ system. Different nutritional‚Äî" "Oh fuck off with your nutritional profiles." This is Kai, mouth full, talking through meat. "Just eat your food." David clutches his plate harder. "This is about the salt." Here we go. We have one container of salt left. Morton's, the girl with the umbrella faded to a ghost. David wants to use it for preservation. Smoking the meat, curing it for winter. Says we need to think long-term. I want it for cooking. For bringing out the flavors. For making the meat sing the way it wants to. For that perfect crust. Rosa thinks we should ration it, grain by grain, like medicine. Kai wants to eat it straight. Says his body's craving minerals. Tom doesn't vote. Tom never votes. "We could find more salt," I say, same argument, third day running. "Where?" David's voice cracks. "The grocery stores are stripped or collapsed. The‚Äî" "There's salt in bodies," Kai says, casual as weather. "In the blood. We could‚Äî" "NO." David and Rosa together, a harmony of disgust that would be funny if Kai wasn't right. If we weren't all thinking it. Tom starts crying. Just tears, no sound, while sawing through his portion with a butter knife because all the sharp ones are for hunting now. "My mom," he says to no one, "used to make Sunday roast." We keep eating. "With the little potatoes," he continues. "Those tiny red ones? And carrots. The carrots would get sweet from the meat juice." Rosa passes him her napkin. We still use napkins. This matters somehow. "Yorkshire pudding," Tom's sobbing now but still chewing. "From scratch. The mix from a box was never puffy enough, she said." "My wife made brisket," David says, and we all freeze because he never talks about her present tense. "Every Friday. House smelled like onions for days." "Can we not?" I say, but I'm thinking about Marcus's coffee-rubbed short ribs, how he'd kiss me in the walk-in cooler with his mouth tasting like espresso and dead cow. "Bulgogi," Kai whispers. "My mom's bulgogi." Rosa sets down her fork. "Every Easter, my grandmother would‚Äî" "STOP." But we can't. We're crying and eating and listing foods that don't exist anymore. Beef Wellington. Coq au vin. Hamburger Helper. McNuggets. Those disgusting gas station taquitos Kai's embarrassed about missing. The memories hurt worse than hunger. "This is better," I say, and everyone turns on me. "Better?" David's standing now. "Better than civilization? Better than‚Äî" "Better than starving." "We're eating people, Marie." "We're eating meat." "That was someone's‚Äî" "Someone's nothing. They're gone. This is what's left." I take another bite, deliberate, maintaining eye contact. "And it's perfectly seasoned without salt." That's the wrong thing to say. David throws his plate. It's plastic so it just bounces, meat sliding across the floor. Tom drops to his knees and scoops it up, puts it back on the plate, hands it back to David like nothing happened. "Two tablespoons," Rosa says suddenly. "What?" "Two tablespoons of salt. For cooking. The rest for preservation." "That's nothing‚Äî" I start. "It's something," she says. "It's what we have." David sits back down. Takes the plate from Tom. Brushes off the floor dirt. Eats it anyway. "It needs acid," Kai says. "The meat. Needs something bright. Vinegar or‚Äî" "Lemon," Tom says, still crying. "Remember lemons?" We do. We remember everything. That's the problem. I watch them eat. David with his precise small bites, probably counting nutrients. Rosa tearing with her hands because she's given up on utensils making us civilized. Kai sucking the bones. Tom organizing his portions by size. "Tomorrow I'm trying a roast," I announce. "Slow cook. All day. The smell will‚Äî" "Attract them," David says. "Let them come. We need groceries." Rosa laughs. Actually laughs. "Groceries." "What else do we call it?" "The truth." But none of us want that. We want to call it protein and provisions and meat. We want to complain about the salt and remember our mothers' cooking and pretend this is temporary. My portion's gone but I'm still hungry. Always hungry now. Kai passes me a piece from his plate without being asked. This is love or something like it. "The hip meat's getting tough," I say. "We need to tenderize better." "Or eat the young ones," Kai suggests. Another silence. Another line we pretend exists. "Veal," Tom says, and giggles. The giggle turns into sobbing. The sobbing continues while he licks his plate. David starts his lecture about protein structures and muscle development. Rosa hums. I sketch tomorrow's menu in my notebook, using little stars to mark the tender cuts. Outside, something howls. Or someone. The distinction matters less each day. "Dessert?" Kai asks, and we all look at the door. "Not tonight," Rosa says, but we all know she means not yet. We sit in our anger and our fullness and our memories of better meals. The meat settles in our stomachs like a secret. Like a promise. Tomorrow I'll use a tablespoon of salt. David will measure it twice. Rosa will document the results. Kai will hunt. Tom will cry about something else his family used to cook. We'll eat in angry silence. It will still be delicious. It's always delicious now.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 3)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter effectively captures the slow normalization of cannibalism within a survival group, using a mundane argument about salt as the vehicle for deeper character exploration. The writing successfully maintains Marie's unreliable narrator voice established in the plan - present tense, sensory-obsessed, with cookbook-like observations bleeding into horrific reality. The character work is particularly strong. Each person's dialogue and behavior aligns perfectly with their established profiles: David's need for authority masked as scientific concern, Rosa's practical nursing mindset, Kai's uncomfortable attraction to violence, and Tom's disconnected presence. Marie's voice remains consistent throughout - dismissive yet obsessive about food quality, using culinary language to distance herself from the moral implications. The central conflict over salt usage serves multiple narrative functions: it's both petty and essential, highlighting how survival strips away civilized pretenses while revealing deeper character tensions. The breakdown into nostalgic food memories creates genuine pathos without sentimentality, showing how the group processes loss through shared vulnerability. The horror elements work subtly - the casual discussion of eating "young ones," the reference to attracting mutants for "groceries," and Tom's disturbing giggle-sob transition. These moments feel earned rather than forced, growing naturally from the established tone. The dialogue is particularly effective, with each character having a distinct voice. David's pedantic corrections, Rosa's practical interjections, and Kai's blunt observations all ring true. The repetition of "It's always delicious now" creates an effective refrain that reinforces the story's central horror. Some minor weaknesses include occasional moments where the prose reaches for effect that doesn't quite land, and the pacing occasionally slows during the nostalgic food sequence. However, these are minor issues in an otherwise compelling chapter that successfully advances both character development and the broader narrative arc. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 18 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Compelling Plot: 16 Coherent: 18 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 3 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 4 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 5 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Characters Consistent with Profile: 19 Followed Chapter Plan: 19 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 18

Chapter 4

Ok now chapter 4. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
# Chapter 4: Michelin Starred *Day 47 (or 74?)* *Notes on the Younger Specimens: Bright acidity on the tongue, almost effervescent. The muscle fibers separate like pulled pork but with the delicate texture of monkfish. Pair with wild garlic (growing behind the collapsed pharmacy) and that fermented berry mash Rosa insists isn't alcoholic. Serves 2-3 if you're lying about portions.* Kai brings in a runner while I'm still documenting yesterday's bulk. Its leg meat twitching even after he's removed the head. The head watches from the counter, blinking slow. "Still fresh," he says, blood up to his elbows like evening gloves. I'm writing: *The marbling on mature specimens suggests a diet rich in‚Äî what? Other mutants? Rats? The things we don't talk about seeing them eat?* "Marie." He's standing too close. Always does now when he's fresh from a kill. Pupils dilated. Breathing through his mouth. That smell on him‚Äîcopper and adrenaline and something else. Something that makes me lean in instead of away. "This one's different." He spreads the body on my prep table. My clean prep table. But I'm looking at how his hands know exactly where to cut now. How the knife moves like an extension of his want. The mutant is perfect. That's the only word. Like someone designed it for eating. Fat distribution even, muscles long and clean, organs intact and gleaming. "Female," I say, though we're not supposed to gender them anymore. David's rule. "Young female," Kai corrects, and there's something in how he says it that makes me need to look away. But I don't. --- *The Feast of St. Whatever (Tuesday?)* *Tasting notes: The runners possess a gaminess reminiscent of venison crossed with duck. High myoglobin content? The flesh darkens when exposed to air‚Äîoxidation that enhances rather than diminishes flavor. Must be consumed within 2 hours of harvest for optimal texture.* Rosa's developing her scoring system on the wall. Tenderness: 1-10. Flavor profile: Mineral/Sweet/Umami/Uncategorizable. Preparation method: Raw/Seared/Slow-cooked/Preserved. "This batch ranks 8 for tenderness," she announces, poking the hanging meat. We've strung them up like a proper butcher shop. Professional. "Seven," David argues. "The connective tissue is still‚Äî" "Eight," Rosa insists. "Feel the spring-back." She demonstrates, pressing her thumb deep into the flesh. We all watch the slow return to form. Mesmerizing. Tom reaches out to try but Rosa slaps his hand. Three fingers or not, he needs to wait his turn. --- *Lover's Knots (revised)* *The intestines, when cleaned properly (channel water through repeatedly until the smell changes from sulfur to salt), can be braided into decorative garnishes. Alternatively, stuff with minced organ meat and wild herbs. The casings snap between teeth like those expensive sausages Marcus would order from‚Äî Marcus is gone. The sausages remain, different animal, same principle.* "You're writing about him again," Kai says, reading over my shoulder. I close the notebook. "Writing about food." "Same thing lately." He's not wrong. Every recipe becomes a memory becomes a body becomes a meal. The categories collapsed sometime last week when I started dreaming in flavor profiles. David's in the corner with his calculator, doing nutrition math that doesn't matter anymore. "Based on protein density, we need 1.5 pounds per person per day, accounting for‚Äî" "I could eat more," Tom says. We all could. We're hungrier since we started eating well. Like our bodies remembered what full meant and want to get back there. --- *On the Aging Process:* *Like proper beef, the meat improves with controlled decomposition. 3-4 days in our makeshift cool room (the basement where the temperature holds at 38¬∞F) develops complex flavors. Notes of blue cheese, truffle, that funky sweetness of overripe fruit. David calls this "dangerous." I call it "dry-aging." We're both right.* Kai's teaching Tom to field-dress while I document. The knife moves, the skin parts, the reveal of what's underneath. Tom's getting hard. We all pretend not to notice but it's obvious in those thin pants. Kai keeps explaining, hands over Tom's hands, guiding the blade. "Feel for the separation," Kai says. "Natural seams. Don't force it." I'm writing about texture but watching Kai's neck, that tendon that stands out when he concentrates. He looks up, catches me looking. Smiles with just his eyes. --- *Menu Planning, Next Week (if weeks still exist):* *Monday: Carpaccio with preserved lemon (no lemons, substitute staghorn sumac)* *Tuesday: Braised shanks with reduction of‚Äî what are we reducing? Everything?* *Wednesday: Organ meat special (market price)* *Thursday: Tartare on toast points (toast points from what bread?)* *Friday: Staff meal (we're all staff now)* "Your handwriting's getting worse," Rosa observes, looking at my notebook. She's right. The words layer over each other, margins full of sub-recipes and annotations. Drawings of cuts that look more like anatomy textbook than cookbook. Temperature notes in three different inks. "Running out of pages." "Write smaller." "Or get another notebook." "From where?" We both know there are notebooks in houses. In stores. In the bags of the bodies we don't check anymore. But leaving means missing a meal. Means the others might eat without me. Means they might discover they don't need a cook. --- *On Doneness:* *The meat tells you when it's ready. A sound change in the sizzle. The way it releases from the pan. Internal temperature of‚Äî does temperature matter when you're cooking something that couldn't have existed in any chef's imagination? 165¬∞F for safety. 135¬∞F for pleasure. We chose pleasure three weeks ago.* Tom's successfully removed the tenderloin. Holds it up like a baby, proud and disturbed. Kai claps him on the shoulder, leaves a handprint in blood. "Tomorrow you can do it solo," Kai says. "I don't want to do it solo." Nobody asks what he means. I'm plating tonight's dinner with the care I used to reserve for critics' tables. Fanned slices, microgreen garnish (dandelions count), sauce drizzled (blood reduced with vinegar). The plates don't match but the presentation's flawless. "It's beautiful," Rosa says, and means it. David takes a photo with his dead phone. We eat in reverent silence, the kind that used to exist in expensive restaurants. Every bite considered. Savored. Between courses, I catch Kai watching me. Not my face. My hands, how they hold the knife. My mouth, how it closes around the fork. "More?" I ask. "Always," he says. I serve seconds. Thirds. Until we're groaning full but still somehow hungry for something we can't name. Tom starts giggling. "We're restaurant critics now. Of our own restaurant. Of the only restaurant." "Five stars," Rosa says. "Michelin starred," I correct, because precision matters. Outside, the mutants gather. Drawn by cooking smells or death smells or the smell of what we're becoming. "Tomorrow's menu?" David asks. I open my notebook to a fresh page. There aren't many left.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 4)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter demonstrates strong execution of the established concept and voice. The writer maintains Marie's obsessive, food-focused narration effectively, using her cookbook format to normalize the horrific while building tension through mundane restaurant-style documentation of cannibalistic practices. The character work is particularly strong. Each character behaves consistently with their established profiles - David's need to intellectualize everything, Rosa's clinical scoring system, Kai's sexual arousal around violence, and Tom's enigmatic presence. The sexual tension between Marie and Kai feels organic and disturbing in the right ways, emerging naturally from their shared participation in butchery. The structure works well, alternating between Marie's cookbook entries and present-action scenes. This creates effective pacing and maintains the unreliable narrator voice. The timeline ambiguity ("Day 47 (or 74?)") reinforces Marie's deteriorating grip on normalcy while maintaining the established narrative style. The dialogue feels natural and character-specific without being heavy-handed. David's pedantic corrections, Rosa's practical assessments, and Kai's loaded comments all ring true. The group dynamics feel lived-in and authentic. The horror remains effectively cozy - they discuss human butchery with the same tone as restaurant criticism, complete with plating aesthetics and temperature concerns. This normalization is genuinely unsettling while avoiding cheap shock tactics. Some of the food descriptions border on purple prose, but they serve the character effectively - Marie's obsession with culinary detail is established, so the elaborate descriptions feel authentic rather than authorial showing off. The metaphors generally land, though a few ("blood up to his elbows like evening gloves") feel slightly forced. The chapter follows its planned beats faithfully while advancing the larger narrative of gradual transformation and moral dissolution. The restaurant critic angle adds dark humor without undermining the horror. Chapter 5

Ok now chapter 5. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
# Chapter 5: The Dinner Party His name is Graham and he still has all his teeth. This bothers me more than his refusal to eat. "I have supplies," he says, clutching his backpack like we're going to steal it. We are going to steal it. Later. After dinner. "What supplies?" Rosa asks, all grandmother concern while eyeing his caloric potential. "Canned goods. Rice. Beans." Beans. Fucking beans. I've prepared seven different cuts in the last week, developed a reduction sauce from spinal fluid that would make Marcus weep, and this man wants to talk about beans. "Stay for dinner," I say. "You must be hungry." "I'm fine." He's not fine. His cheekbones could cut glass. His fingers shake. That particular yellow tinge around the eyes that says his body's eating his liver. I know the look. We all wore it before. Tom sets the table. The good plates‚Äîmismatched china we pulled from a house where everyone was already gone. Five settings. Cloth napkins Rosa boiled yesterday. The silver that doesn't match but gleams. "You don't have to eat," David says, shooting me a look that says he absolutely does. "Just sit with us." Graham sits. Watches us work. Kai's brought three runners, fresh this morning, already dressed and sectioned. I'm working with the tenderness of someone preparing a last meal. Which this might be. His or ours, depending. "Smells good," Graham admits. "Rabbit," I say, testing. "That's not rabbit." "How would you know?" This from Kai, aggressive, knife in hand. "I've eaten rabbit." "So have we," Rosa lies. "This is rabbit." Graham watches me work. The way I butterfly the meat, stuff it with herbs and that soft cheese Rosa makes from god knows what. The careful trussing. The pan-sear before the oven that doesn't exist so we use the covered pot over coals. "What happened to your group?" I ask, casual. "Gone." "Dead?" "Worse." We don't ask what's worse. We know. They started eating the mutants. They changed. They became. All the things Graham thinks are worse than death but we call Tuesday. --- I've made six courses because I'm angry and trying to prove something. First: Carpaccio, sliced so thin you can see through it. Dressed with oil and something Rosa fermented that tastes like capers but probably isn't. "Beef?" Graham asks. "Venison," we all say in unison. Rehearsed. He doesn't eat it. Second: Soup. Clear broth I've been working on for days. Bones and aromatics and time. Float of green onion. Single perfect dumpling made with the last of our flour. "It's good," Graham says, sipping just the broth. "Rich." "Bone broth," David explains. "Healing properties. Minerals." Graham sets down his spoon when he finds a vertebra I forgot to strain out. Too small for deer. Too familiar. Third: The salad course. All foraged greens. No meat. Graham relaxes, eats with enthusiasm. "This I can do," he says. Tom giggles. Covers it with a cough. Fourth: What I'm calling "Chicken." Breaded, fried in the good fat, crispy and golden and perfect. My greatest achievement. Even the smell makes me proud. "Definitely not chicken," Graham says. "Tastes like chicken," Kai argues, mouth full. "Everything tastes like chicken." "Not this," I say, offended. "This tastes like itself. Complex. Layered. The breading alone took‚Äî" "I'm not eating it." I stand. Rosa puts a hand on my arm. I sit. Fifth: The roast. My masterpiece. Twelve hours of slow cooking. Basted every thirty minutes. The meat falls apart at a fork's touch. The smell fills the shelter like a church. "Please," I say. Not begging. Stating. "Please try it." "What is it?" "Does it matter?" "Yes." "Pork," Rosa says. "There are no pigs." "Wild boar," David corrects. "In the city?" "Escaped from the zoo," Kai adds. We're all terrible liars. Graham knows. We know he knows. He knows we know he knows. The meat sits between us, gorgeous and damning. "Just one bite," I say. "One bite and I'll never ask again." Graham looks at me. At the others. At the feast we've prepared with the care of people trying to stay human through ritual. He takes a piece. Small. Raises it to his mouth. Stops. "I can't." "You can," Tom says. First thing he's said all meal. "I won't." "You will," Tom says. "Eventually. When you're hungry enough. We all did." Graham sets down his fork. "You're all sick." "We're all alive," Rosa says. "That's not living." "It's not dying either." Graham stands. "I should go." "It's dark," David says. "The mutants‚Äî" "I'll take my chances." "Your funeral," Kai says, then laughs because it's funny now. Everything's funny when you're full. Graham backs toward the door. We don't stop him. His backpack sits by his chair, forgotten or abandoned. "Last chance," I say, holding out a wrapped portion. "For the road." He runs. Actually runs. We listen to his footsteps fade. Silence. "Dibs on his beans," Kai says. "Dibs on his portion," Tom says, already pulling Graham's plate over. We divide the meat with practiced efficiency. No ceremony now. Just hunger despite being full. Always room for more. I open Graham's backpack. Three cans of green beans. A water filter. Half a chocolate bar. We eat the chocolate first, passing it around, one square each. It tastes like nothing. Like cardboard. Like disappointment. "Our palates have evolved," David says, trying to sound scientific. "We've ruined ourselves for normal food," Rosa corrects. "Good," I say, and mean it. We finish Graham's portion. Then dessert‚Äîsomething I've been working on, sweetened with mashed fruit, texture like panna cotta but wrong. Everything's wrong in the right way now. "He'll be back," Kai says. "They always come back," Rosa agrees. "When they're hungry enough," I add. Tom's already washing the dishes. We save the bones for stock. Waste nothing. Honor the meal if not the meat. Later, trying to sleep, I hear something outside. Scratching. Sniffing. Could be mutants. Could be Graham. The difference matters less each day.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 5)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter effectively executes the "dinner party" concept with sophisticated horror that emerges through politeness and social ritual rather than explicit violence. The author creates genuine tension through the disconnect between the elaborate meal preparation and the characters' casual dehumanization of both their food source and their guest. The characterization is particularly strong. Marie's wounded pride when Graham refuses her cooking feels authentic - her identity as a cook has become central to her survival and self-worth. The way she describes the food with genuine culinary passion while glossing over its horrific nature perfectly captures the character's psychological compartmentalization. David's pseudo-intellectual deflections ("bone broth... healing properties"), Rosa's maternal manipulation, and Kai's barely-contained aggression all feel true to their established personalities. The dialogue effectively reveals character while advancing the plot. The escalating lies about what they're eating ("rabbit," "venison," "chicken," "pork," "wild boar") become increasingly absurd, yet each character commits to the deception with their own particular style. Tom's rare contributions ("They always come back") land with ominous weight. The structure using the meal's courses creates effective pacing, building tension through Graham's growing resistance. The aftermath - casually dividing his belongings and finishing his portion - achieves genuine horror through understatement. The final ambiguity about what's scratching outside maintains the unsettling tone. The prose maintains Marie's distinctive voice throughout, with her food-obsessed perspective feeling authentic rather than forced. Her anger at Graham's refusal being treated as a personal insult to her cooking skills rings psychologically true. Minor weaknesses include some slightly on-the-nose moments ("Everything's funny when you're full") and the chocolate comparison feeling somewhat heavy-handed as symbolism. However, these don't significantly detract from the overall effectiveness. The chapter successfully balances the "cozy" and "horror" elements of the prompt - the domestic ritual of dinner service masking the complete moral transformation of the characters. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 18 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Compelling Plot: 16 Coherent: 18 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 4 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 3 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Characters Consistent with Profile: 19 Followed Chapter Plan: 19 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 18

Chapter 6

Ok now chapter 6. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
# Chapter 6: Preferences David likes them marbled. Says the ones who turned slowly taste better, something about gradual spore integration creating superior fat distribution. He's got a whole notebook now‚Äînot recipes like mine but data. Age at turning. Body mass index. Time from infection to full transformation. Like he's grading beef. "This one," he says, poking at the hanging torso, "sixty-plus years at turning. See the fat cap? That's decades of good living." "That's someone's grandfather," Rosa says, but she's already eyeing the liver. "Was," David corrects. "Was someone's grandfather." --- I wake up knowing there's three in the building. Not hearing them. Not seeing. Knowing. Like how you know it's going to rain. Like how you know someone's watching. Like how I used to know Marcus was cheating before I found the texts. Two floors down. Male, mature, well-fed. Female, young, terrified. Something else, harder to place. "There's food downstairs," I tell Kai. He doesn't ask how I know. The hunt takes twenty minutes. Would've taken ten but Kai insists on playing with the young one. Letting her run. Cutting off escape routes. Herding her back to center. "She's scared," he says, pupils black as oil. "They taste better scared." He's not wrong. The adrenaline does something to the meat. Brightens it. Like adding acid to a dish. "The old one's mine," David calls out, already moving toward the male. "Rosa wants the liver," I remind him. "Rosa can have the female's liver. Younger. Less cirrhosis." We're discussing organ allocation while they're still breathing. Still running. Still almost human-shaped. --- *ANXIETY REDUCTION* *Serves 6-8 depending on greed* *One terrified mutant, butterflied (the fear is essential‚Äîwithout it, the meat lacks depth)* *Salt (memory of)* *Pepper (suggestion of)* *That herb that might be rosemary or might be something toxic but who can tell anymore* *The good fat (always the good fat)* *Chase the mutant until exhaustion. The lactate buildup in the muscles creates tenderness. Corner it somewhere with no exits. Let it understand what's happening. The pupils will dilate‚Äîthis is when you strike. Quick, clean, or if you're Kai, whatever the opposite of clean is.* *The butterflying should be done while still warm‚Äî* Tom's reading over my shoulder. "That's sick." "Which part?" "All of it. None of it. I don't know anymore." He's been saying that a lot. His fingernails are growing faster now. We all noticed but no one mentions it. Like how Rosa's hair is thicker. Like how David doesn't need his glasses for distance anymore. Like how I can smell everything. --- "I want the runners," Kai announces at dinner. "Only the runners from now on." "Too lean," I argue. "You need the fat for‚Äî" "I don't care about the fat. I like the texture. The fight in them." He's got blood under his nails again. Always does now. Says it won't wash out but I think he's not trying. Rosa's separating her meal into careful piles. Organ meat left, muscle meat right, fat trimmed and set aside for later. "The females process differently," she says, clinical. "More tender. Something hormonal maybe." "We shouldn't gender them," David says, mouth full of what he insists on calling "the good cuts" but which are clearly reproductive organs. "You just called that one grandfather," Tom points out. "That was different." "How?" David doesn't answer. Can't answer. The categories are breaking down. Person, not-person, meat, not-meat, us, them. All sliding into each other like overcooked vegetables. --- I find Kai in the kitchen at three AM, eating something raw. "Couldn't sleep," he says. "That's mine. I was aging it." "It's been four days. It's ready." He tears off another piece with his teeth. His actual teeth, not even using his hands. The way he swallows without really chewing. The way his throat moves. "You're changing," I say. "We all are." "You faster." He smiles. His teeth look different. Sharper? Whiter? More? I can't tell in this light. "I like it," he says. "The changing. Like puberty but backward. Or forward. Direction doesn't matter anymore." He offers me a piece. I take it. It's perfect‚Äîthat funk of controlled rot, the copper undertone, the sweetness that comes with proper aging. We stand there, sharing it, not talking. His hand brushes mine. Electric or just blood-sticky. Both. "I can smell you," he says. "All the time now. Even when you're not here." "What do I smell like?" "Like kitchens. Like knives. Like that moment right before the kill when everything goes quiet." --- *Recipe #47 (untitled)* *Sometimes you don't cook it* *Sometimes you just* *tear and swallow and* *let the blood run down your chin like* *childhood watermelon but* *wrong* *all wrong* *perfectly wrong* Tom's crying again but not about roasts. He's looking at his hands. The three-fingered one and the five-fingered one and how both have these little raised bumps now. Like goosebumps but permanent. "It's the protein," David says. "We're all developing‚Äî" "Don't," Rosa cuts him off. "Don't explain it. Just let it be what it is." What it is: we're becoming something else. Or something more. Or something less. The distinction matters when you're thinking but not when you're eating. --- I watch them at dinner, cataloging preferences like wine pairings: David: aged, marbled, male, with a side of denial Rosa: organs, always organs, prepared simply, honesty in simplicity Kai: young, scared, female, raw when I'm not looking Tom: whatever's served, grateful and sobbing, grateful for sobbing And me? I like the ones that smell like memory. The ones that might have been teachers or lawyers or mothers. The ones with tan lines and surgical scars and evidence of life before. I like them cooked perfect medium-rare, pink in the center like a secret, like a promise, like the inside of Marcus's mouth when he smiled. --- "We should leave," Tom says suddenly over dessert (poached something in something else). "Why?" Rosa asks. "We're running out of notebook pages." We all look at my journal, filled margin to margin, writing over writing, recipes on top of recipes. "There's more notebooks in the world," David says. "But no more us," Tom says. "Not the us we were. Not the us who'd use them right." He's wrong. We're more us than ever. Distilled to essence. Hunger and fulfillment. Predator and cook. The knife and the meal. "I need more pages," I say. Kai stands. "I know where to find some." He heads for the door. We all know he's not looking for notebooks. Not really. But we let him go because we're hungry again. Always hungry. Differently hungry. Rosa starts sharpening knives. David updates his charts. Tom cries and laughs and cries. I turn to the last blank page in my notebook. Write only: "The meat knows what it wants to become."
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 6)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter effectively advances the established narrative while deepening the horror through its focus on developing "preferences" for human flesh. The writing maintains the distinctive voice of Marie as an unreliable narrator obsessed with culinary technique, and her cookbook format continues to provide a chilling contrast between domestic normalcy and cannibalistic horror. The characterization is particularly strong. Each group member's preferences feel authentic to their established personalities: David's pseudo-scientific categorization serving his need for control and denial, Kai's predatory arousal masked as practical preference, Rosa's clinical detachment, and Tom's enigmatic presence. The dialogue captures distinct voices well, especially David's pompous lecturing and Kai's casual admission of his darker impulses. The chapter succeeds in showing the group's continued transformation both psychologically and physically. The subtle details about enhanced senses, changing teeth, and growing fingernails suggest biological changes without over-explaining them. The intimate scene between Marie and Kai over raw meat is particularly effective at conveying their descent while maintaining the story's unsettling intimacy. The "Anxiety Reduction" recipe serves as an excellent example of the story's dark humor, presenting methodical cooking instructions for hunting and preparing terrified humans with the same tone one might use for a dinner party recipe. This maintains the "cozy" aspect of the cozy-horror genre while amplifying the disturbing elements. Some poetic flourishes work well ("pupils black as oil," "like childhood watermelon but wrong") while others feel slightly forced. The fragmented recipe toward the end with its repetitive "wrong/all wrong/perfectly wrong" structure feels authentic to Marie's deteriorating mental state. The chapter effectively follows both the established plan and the original prompt, advancing the normalization theme while introducing new elements like the characters' physical transformations and enhanced abilities.
