Chapter 7

Ok now chapter 7. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
# Chapter 7: The Good News Rosa's bleeding or she isn't. She's pregnant or she was. She's been pregnant for three months or six months or since before, when pregnancies made sense and babies were things you wanted. "I need the spinal fluid," she says, matter-of-fact, like asking for salt. "That's not a craving normal people have," David says. "Good thing we're not normal people." She's right. My gums bleed when I smile now. Tom's down to two fingers on the left hand‚Äîsays the third just fell off, no pain, like a tooth. Kai doesn't cast a shadow at noon anymore. We don't talk about it. --- The spine cracks different when fresh. More like a wishbone. Less like a branch. I've got the body strung up, head down, and if you tap the vertebrae in sequence‚ÄîC1 through L5‚Äîit sounds like a xylophone made of meat. "Here," I show Rosa, finding the sweet spot between L2 and L3. "Press and twist." The fluid comes out clear as water, then pink, then this gorgeous deep red like expensive wine Marcus would pretend he could afford. Rosa cups her hands beneath, drinks it like communion. Her face does something complicated‚Äîrelief, revulsion, recognition. "It tastes like the future," she says. David takes notes: "Subject experiences prophetic ideation following consumption of cerebrospinal‚Äî" "Shut up, David," Rosa and I say together. --- *CELEBRATION FEAST MENU* *(for Rosa's maybe-baby, never-baby, always-baby)* *First Course: Carpaccio of Could-Have-Been* *Second Course: Soup of Liquid Dreams* *Third Course: The Thing We Don't Name Anymore* *Fourth Course: Roasted Whole [REDACTED]* *Fifth Course: Tomorrow's Regret, Today's Feast* *Wine Pairing: Spinal fluid, aged 3 hours in open air until oxidized* --- "I fucked my professor," Kai announces during the second course. "Multiple times. In her office." We keep eating. "She turned first week of the outbreak. I watched from her apartment window. She became... beautiful. All these white filaments growing from her eyes like lashes made of light." "That's nice, dear," Rosa says, patting his hand. "I killed her yesterday." "Which one was she?" I ask, thinking about the meat in our stores. "The one that tasted like cinnamon." Oh. That one. She was delicious. --- David's making a toast with his cup of spinal fluid. We found the good glasses, crystal that sings when you flick it. The fluid looks almost elegant, almost champagne, almost like we're almost people having almost a dinner party. "To Rosa," he starts. "To the future. To the‚Äî" "My wife never existed," he says instead. "I made her up. Week two. Needed a reason to... to be. To not just lie down and become mulch. So I invented Margaret. Gave her allergies. A preference for documentaries. A way of humming while she cooked." We raise our glasses. The fluid is warm. Salty. Perfect. "To Margaret," Rosa says. "To Professor Cinnamon," Kai adds. "To whoever Tom used to be," I offer. Tom grins. His teeth are definitely different. Too many. "I've always been Tom. Tom's all there is. Tom's all there was." --- I'm carving the main course‚Äîsomething that was multiple someones, pressed together, formed into a roast, a mutant turducken‚Äîwhen my knife slips. Goes through my palm. Clean through. No pain. Just observation. The blood that comes out is too dark. Too thick. Like reduction sauce. "You're done," Rosa says. Not to me. To the blood. To the change. To the thing we're all becoming. Kai licks my palm. The wound seals. We don't discuss it. --- *Recipe for Anxiety Reduction (Revised Again)* *Cut the fear into manageable pieces* *Swallow without thinking* *Digest the impossible* *Shit out humanity* *Repeat until full* *(You're never full)* --- "What do we call it?" Rosa asks, hand on her belly that might be full of baby or might be full of meat or might be both. "If it's born?" "When," David corrects. "When it's born." "If it's born," Rosa insists. "Dinner," Kai says, then laughs. We all laugh. It's not funny. It's the funniest thing. It's the only thing. "No but really," Rosa continues. "What do we call something born into this? Born from this? Born of us?" "Lucky," Tom says. "Evolved," David offers. "Hungry," I say, which is the only true answer. --- The feast continues. Hours? Days? I lose track when eating. Lose myself. Become just mouth and throat and stomach and want. Kai brings out dessert‚Äîsomething he made himself. Pride in his face like a child's drawing. "It's still moving," Rosa observes. "It's supposed to. That's what makes it fresh." We eat it anyway. It twitches on the way down. Delightful. --- "I don't remember my last name," Kai announces. "I know it started with P. Or B. Something with lips together." "Park," I suggest. "Kim. Lee." "Racist," he says, laughing. "But maybe. They all sound right. They all sound wrong." "I don't remember my first name," Tom adds. "It's Tom," David says. "Is it? Are you sure? Have you always been sure?" David opens his mouth. Closes it. We watch him try to remember when Tom became Tom. "Marie's not my name," I say. "It's just what Marcus called me. My name is‚Äîwas‚Äîsomething else. Something with vowels." "Everything has vowels," Rosa points out. "Not the way mine did." --- Rosa stands, raises her glass one more time. The firelight catches her face and for a moment she looks exactly like what she is‚Äîa pregnant woman at a dinner party. Then the light shifts and she's something else. Something with too many teeth and perfect posture and eyes that don't blink enough. "To the good news," she says. "Whatever's growing inside me, it'll never go hungry." We drink. The spinal fluid tastes like possibility. Like evolution. Like the opposite of endings. "More?" Kai asks. "Always," we answer. I look at my notebook, my last page covered in scrawl: *hungry hungry hungry hungry hungry* *the meat knows* *the meat knows* *the meat* *knows* Tomorrow we'll hunt. Tomorrow we'll eat. Tomorrow Rosa will be more pregnant or less pregnant or differently pregnant. Tonight we feast on the things we've become. Kai's right. It does taste better when they're scared. I'm scared all the time now. I've never been more delicious.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 7)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter successfully executes a deeply unsettling dinner party that serves as both character revelation and horror showcase. The writing demonstrates strong control over tone, maintaining the "cozy-horror" atmosphere while advancing the group's psychological and physical transformation. The characterization is particularly strong. Each character's confession feels authentic to their established personality - David's admission about his fictional wife lands with genuine pathos, while Kai's revelation about his professor maintains his disturbing honesty about his dark impulses. Rosa's matter-of-fact approach to her pregnancy and cravings for spinal fluid perfectly captures her psychiatric nurse background adapting to impossible circumstances. The dialogue consistently hits character-specific voices without feeling forced. The casual way they discuss increasingly horrific topics ("Which one was she?" when discussing eating Kai's former professor) effectively demonstrates their normalization of cannibalism. The group dynamics feel lived-in and authentic. Marie's increasingly unhinged notebook entries provide effective structural variety and show her deteriorating grip on conventional reality. The "recipe" format becomes genuinely unsettling as it devolves into abstract horror. The chapter follows its outlined plan effectively, hitting the celebration feast, personal confessions, and group transformation beats. It maintains coherence despite the fragmented, stream-of-consciousness style that mirrors Marie's mental state. However, some metaphorical flourishes occasionally feel slightly overwrought ("drinks it like communion," "tastes like the future"), though most land effectively. The piece maintains its horror through implication and casual treatment of the horrific rather than graphic description, which serves the cozy-horror tone well. The ending effectively captures the group's complete transformation while maintaining the intimate dinner party atmosphere. The final notebook entries provide a disturbing crescendo that feels earned rather than forced. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Compelling Plot: 15 Coherent: 16 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 6 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 5 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Characters Consistent with Profile: 18 Followed Chapter Plan: 18 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 18

Chapter 8

Ok now finish the story with chapter 8. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
# Chapter 8: Tuesday It's Tuesday or it isn't. The weak one's at the door again. Third time this week. The mutants leave them now like cats leave mice. Not gifts. Not exactly. More like meal prep. Tom (definitely Tom, always was Tom, Tom forever) drags it inside by one leg. It's still breathing. They always are. "Dibs on the tenderloin," he says with two fingers. "You had tenderloin yesterday." "That was yesterday's tenderloin." Rosa's bigger now. Or smaller. Depends where you look. Her belly moves wrong‚Äîtoo many angles, not enough curve. She scores the hanging meat: 7 for marbling, 9 for freshness, question mark for the smell like flowers and copper. I'm writing in the margins of page 47, over a recipe for something I've already forgotten: *Tuesday's feast: the usual* *Wednesday's feast: the usual* *Thursday's feast: the* No more room. I turn the notebook sideways, write between lines: *they know we like them scared so they come scared* *evolutionary cooperation or* *or* *or* --- Kai doesn't knock anymore. Nobody does. He enters with something that was someone who was something. Female. Young. Architect maybe, from the calluses. Or pianist. Same difference now. "She was fast," he says, not breathing hard. He doesn't breathe hard anymore. Doesn't breathe much at all. I'm already sectioning before she stops moving. Efficiency matters. The meat knows what it wants to become and I'm just facilitating. "Save the eyes for David," Rosa says. "He doesn't like eyes." "He does now." She's right. We all like everything now. Preferences collapsed into preference: more. --- The kitchen fills with the sounds of not-talking. Knives through meat. Teeth through protein. That wet sound swallowing makes when you're really listening. David's organizing his portion by texture. Rosa's drinking something from a cup that steams. Tom's crying again but happily, gratefully, the way you cry at weddings or births or perfect meals. I write on my hand now, recipes in abbreviated code: *R=runner* *H=hulk* *F=female* *Y=young* *T=terrified* *D=delicious* *D=delicious* *D=del* --- "Someone's coming," I say, smelling it on the wind. Human. Actual human. Milk and soap and clothing washed in water that remembers machines. "How many?" Kai asks. "One." "Male?" "Does it matter?" "For portion size." We wait. The knock comes during dessert‚Äîsomething quivering Rosa pulled from something else. The knock is so normal it's obscene. One-two-three. Like civilization. Like before. Like the world where knocking meant something. Rosa answers. She's the most grandmother-shaped still. "Hello," the new one says. "I'm looking for‚Äî" "Dinner?" Rosa asks. "Shelter." "Same thing. Come in." --- She's young. Twenty-maybe. Backpack with college patches. Colorado State. Engineering department. Kai perks up. "I'm Sarah," she says. We don't introduce ourselves. Names are just mouth sounds now. "Sit," I say, already plating. "You must be hungry." "I have supplies. Protein bars. Some‚Äî" Tom laughs. Keeps laughing. Laughs until he's sobbing. Laughs until his two fingers clutch his sides. "We have protein," David says. "Better protein." I serve her the choice cut. Medium-rare. Perfect crust. The smell makes her lean forward before her brain catches up. "What is it?" "Food." "But what‚Äî" "Does knowing change the hunger?" Rosa asks. Sarah looks at the plate. At us. At how we sit too still and breathe too quiet and smile too wide. "You're sick." "We're full," I correct. --- She eats the vegetables first. The ones that might be vegetables. The ones we call vegetables because calling them fingers would be impolite. "It's good," she admits. "Try the meat." "I'm vegetarian." Kai snorts. "Not anymore." "I don't eat‚Äî" "You don't eat yet," Rosa says, hand on her moving belly. "Yet's just time plus hunger." --- *Last recipe (written on my wrist):* *Take what comes* *Cook with care* *Serve with what's left of love* *Repeat until full* *Repeat until empty* *Repeat until the difference doesn't* --- Sarah stares at the meat. We watch her stare. The room fills with the sound of us not chewing, waiting, patient as rot. "Just one bite," I say. Same words. Different mouth. How many times have I said this? How many will I say it? She cuts a piece. Small. Raises it halfway. "What happened to you?" "We got hungry," Tom says. "We got honest," David adds. "We got efficient," Rosa contributes. "We got good at it," Kai finishes. I don't say anything. I'm writing on my ankle now: *she'll eat it* *they always do* *tuesday's child is full of* --- Sarah puts the fork down. "I should go." "It's dark," Rosa says. "The mutants‚Äî" David starts. "Aren't the problem," Sarah finishes, looking at us. She's wrong. She's right. She's irrelevant. The mutants press against the windows now. Watching. Waiting. Offering. We're their reproduction strategy. Their evolutionary partners. Their mouths. "One bite," I say again. "Then you can go." She stands. Backs toward the door. Stops. Outside, the mutants part for her. Of course they do. She's not ripe yet. Not ready. Still too human to be delicious. "She'll be back," Kai says. "They always come back," Rosa agrees. "When they're hungry enough," David adds. Tom's already dividing her portion. --- I'm out of skin to write on. Started on the table now, knife-tip into wood: *wednesday brings fresh meat* *thursday brings fresh meat* *friday brings* Rosa births something during dessert. Or doesn't. Her belly's flat now. Or rounder. The thing that comes out has fingers. Or doesn't. We eat the placenta. Or the baby. Or both. Or neither. The categories collapsed somewhere between courses. "What should we name it?" she asks. "Dinner," Kai says. "Tomorrow," David offers. "Tuesday," I decide. It opens its mouth. Too many teeth or just enough. We feed it something that twitches. It swallows without chewing. One of us. --- Another knock. Or the same knock. Time's a circle when you're always eating. I open the door. Someone new. Someone same. Someone. "I'm looking for‚Äî" "Sit," I say. "You must be hungry." They sit. They're always hungry. I serve the usual. Perfect pink. Properly seasoned. The meat knows what it wants to become. "What is it?" they ask. "Tuesday," I say. Outside, the mutants gather. Offering. Waiting. Being. We eat. We're always eating now. Mouths and meals and the space between. Someone new arrives. Someone new always arrives. The cycle continues. The meat continues. Tuesday continues. It's delicious. It's always been delicious. It always will be.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 8)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter effectively delivers on the cozy-horror premise, presenting a deeply unsettling normalization of cannibalistic survival. The writing successfully maintains Marie's unreliable, food-obsessed narrative voice while showing the complete moral collapse of the group. Strengths include the fragmented, stream-of-consciousness style that reinforces Marie's deteriorating mental state. The notebook entries scattered throughout ("R=runner, H=hulk, F=female") are particularly effective, showing how she's systematized the horror. The cyclical structure with new arrivals works well thematically, and the sensory details around food preparation remain viscerally effective. The character consistency is strong - Marie's obsession with cooking and documentation, David's hoarding of choice cuts, Kai's hunting enthusiasm, and Rosa's twisted maternal instincts all align with the established profiles. The dialogue, while spare, feels authentic to people who've moved beyond normal social conventions. However, the piece suffers from some forced poetic moments that don't quite land. Lines like "Tuesday's child is full of" and "Mouths and meals and the space between" feel like they're reaching for profundity without earning it. The repetitive ending, while thematically appropriate, becomes somewhat tedious rather than hypnotic. Some metaphors feel strained - "moves with too much or too little purpose, nothing in between" for Tom, or Rosa's pregnancy described as "too many angles, not enough curve." The writing occasionally tips into purple prose territory with phrases like "patient as rot" and overly elaborate food descriptions. The horror elements work best when understated - the mutants leaving offerings, the casual discussion of portion distribution, the matter-of-fact serving of human flesh to newcomers. When the text becomes more explicitly poetic, it loses some of its unsettling effectiveness. The chapter successfully follows its plan and maintains the established tone, but the execution is somewhat uneven, with moments of genuine creepiness undermined by overwritten passages. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 15 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Compelling Plot: 14 Coherent: 17 Weak Dialogue: 8 Tell-Don't-Show: 7 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 6 Amateurish: 9 Purple Prose: 11 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 12 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 15 Characters Consistent with Profile: 18 Followed Chapter Plan: 19 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 18

Final Piece Evaluation

Judge Response (First Entry):
[Analysis] This multi-chapter horror story presents a darkly creative take on post-apocalyptic cannibalism, filtered through the lens of culinary obsession. The central conceit - a former chef applying her professional expertise to cooking mutant humans - is genuinely inventive and provides a unique angle on familiar zombie/survival horror tropes. The narrative voice is consistently strong throughout, maintaining Marie's perspective as both unreliable narrator and culinary artist. The author demonstrates impressive control over tone, balancing genuine horror with dark humor that feels earned rather than gratuitous. The food metaphors and cooking terminology create an effective cognitive dissonance that enhances the horror - describing human flesh with the same care and expertise one might apply to wagyu beef. The character development is particularly effective in showing gradual transformation. Rather than sudden shifts, the characters' descent into monstrosity feels organic and psychologically believable. Each character develops distinct preferences and justifications, creating nuanced portraits of people adapting to unthinkable circumstances. The world-building is atmospheric and immersive, created through accumulating details rather than exposition dumps. The post-apocalyptic setting feels lived-in and authentic, with practical concerns (rationing salt, finding notebooks) grounding the fantastic elements. However, the piece has notable weaknesses. The ending becomes repetitive, with the "Tuesday" cycle feeling more mechanical than meaningful. Some dialogue feels stilted, particularly exposition-heavy exchanges. Certain poetic flourishes don't quite land - phrases like "time's a circle when you're always eating" read as trying too hard for profundity. The story also struggles with length management. While the gradual transformation is effective, some chapters feel redundant, particularly the repeated pattern of new arrivals refusing then accepting the meat. The recipe interludes, while creative, occasionally interrupt narrative flow. Despite these issues, the piece succeeds in creating genuine unease and maintains coherent internal logic throughout its extended length. The horror feels earned rather than gratuitous, and the transformation arc provides satisfying character development within the constraints of the genre. [Scores] Believable Character Actions: 16 Nuanced Characters: 15 Pacing: 14 World Building: 17 Compelling Plot: 15 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Coherent: 16 Weak Dialogue: 12 Tell-Don't-Show: 5 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4 Amateurish: 6 Purple Prose: 8 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 9 Unearned Transformations: 4 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 18
Avg Final Item Score: 72.6/100
+ Victorian Romance ‚Äî The Upper Window (Chapter Avg: 80.3 | Final: 83.7)
Initial Writing Prompt:
Victorian Romance Write a short story over several chapters to this prompt: One quickly learns the art of entering a manor through the upper windows.
+ Planning Phase (5 Steps)
Victorian Romance Write a short story over several chapters to this prompt: One quickly learns the art of entering a manor through the upper windows. -- Your task is to create a writing plan for this prompt. The scope will be a short story, written over {n_chapters} chapters. Each chapter will be approximately 1000 words so plan accordingly for this scope. Your plan should be comprehensive and in this format: # Brainstorming <Brainstorm ideas for characters, plot, tone, story beats, pacing over the {n_chapters} chapters. The purpose of brainstorming is to cast a wide net of ideas, not to settle on any specific direction. Think about various ways you could take the prompt.> # Reflection <Reflect out loud on what works and doesn't work in these ideas. The purpose of this reflection is to narrow in on what you think will work best to make a piece that is a. compelling, and b. fits the prompt requirements. You are not making any decisons just yet, just reflecting.>
Model Output:
# Brainstorming ## Character Possibilities - **The Intruder**: A young woman of modest means who becomes a governess but moonlights as a jewel thief to support her ailing family - A disgraced aristocrat's son who must sneak into his former home to retrieve evidence of his innocence - A painter/artist commissioned for portraits who falls for the lady of the house - A female detective or investigator working undercover as a lady's maid - A street thief who accidentally witnesses a murder through a window and becomes entangled in aristocratic intrigue - A young nobleman who must court a woman in secret due to family feuds - A reformed thief now working as a private inquiry agent ## Plot Variations 1. **The Thief and the Lady**: A skilled cat burglar repeatedly encounters the same insomniac noblewoman during heists, leading to an unlikely romance and her eventual discovery that he's stealing to fund an orphanage 2. **The Secret Courtship**: Two lovers from feuding families conduct their romance entirely through midnight window visits, until a murder forces them to work together 3. **The Lady Detective**: A female Pinkerton agent poses as a governess to investigate missing jewels, but finds herself falling for the rakish second son who also sneaks through windows‚Äîfor very different reasons 4. **The Blackmail Plot**: A young woman must repeatedly break into a duke's manor to steal back compromising letters about her sister, only to discover the duke's younger brother is doing the same thing for his own reasons 5. **The Innocent Accused**: After being framed for theft, a former lady's maid must break into various noble houses to gather evidence of a conspiracy, aided by an unlikely ally‚Äîthe cynical youngest son of a powerful family ## Tone Options - Light and witty, in the style of Julia Quinn or Georgette Heyer - Gothic romance with darker undertones - Mystery-forward with romantic subplot - Character-driven with social commentary on class divisions - Adventure-romance with heist elements - Slow-burn romance with emphasis on tension and stolen moments ## Story Beats Across 8 Chapters **Version A - The Heist Romance:** 1. Opening heist goes wrong, first encounter with love interest 2. Forced to return to same manor, deeper connection forms 3. Love interest discovers truth but doesn't turn them in 4. They work together on a job 5. Betrayal or misunderstanding 6. Stakes raised - life or death situation 7. Grand gesture/sacrifice 8. Resolution and choosing love over old life **Version B - The Secret Investigation:** 1. Arrival at manor under false pretenses, first window entry 2. Discovery of mystery/crime, meeting the romantic interest 3. Building trust while maintaining deception 4. Romantic interest becomes ally 5. Danger escalates, near discovery 6. Truth revealed, relationship fractured 7. Redemption through action 8. Mystery solved, romance resolved **Version C - The Forbidden Romance:** 1. First accidental encounter through window 2. Deliberate return, connection deepens 3. Social obstacles revealed 4. Secret meetings continue, feelings develop 5. Near discovery by antagonist 6. Forced separation 7. Grand romantic gesture involving windows 8. Happy ending against social odds ## Pacing Considerations - Chapters 1-2: Setup and character introduction, establish window-entering skill - Chapters 3-4: Develop romance and raise stakes - Chapters 5-6: Major complications and dark moment - Chapters 7-8: Climax and resolution - Each chapter could represent a different "visit" through the windows - Alternating POV between the intruder and the love interest - Time jumps between chapters (days or weeks) # Reflection Looking at these ideas, I'm drawn to concepts that make the window-entering central to both plot and character development rather than just a quirky detail. The prompt's phrasing "One quickly learns the art" suggests this is a skill developed out of necessity, not just romantic whimsy. **What works:** - The Lady Detective angle provides natural conflict between duty and desire, plus explains the specialized skill set - The reformed thief/inquiry agent offers redemption arc possibilities - Having both protagonists engage in window-entering for different reasons could create interesting parallels - Setting up the manor as almost a character itself, with its windows being portals to different secrets - Using the window motif symbolically‚Äîwindows as barriers between social classes, between public and private selves **What might not work:** - Pure comedy might undermine the tension needed for 8 chapters - Too much focus on heist mechanics could overshadow romance - Making the heroine too passive (she should have agency) - Relying solely on misunderstandings for conflict **Most compelling direction:** I'm leaning toward a story where a young woman with a mysterious past works as a private inquiry agent (unusual for the era), hired to investigate thefts at various noble houses. She's developed her climbing skills from a questionable background she's trying to leave behind. At one particular manor, she keeps encountering the second son of the family‚Äîwho has his own reasons for sneaking about at night (perhaps investigating his father's suspicious death or protecting his sister from blackmail). This setup allows for: - Both characters to be active agents - Natural conflict (suspicion, competing goals) - Shared danger that forces cooperation - Class tension (if she's from humble origins) - Mystery element to drive plot alongside romance - The window-entering to be plot-essential, not just atmospheric The tone would be romantic suspense with witty dialogue, some Gothic atmosphere, but ultimately hopeful. Each chapter could feature a significant window scene, building their relationship through these liminal moments while the mystery deepens around them.
Great now let's continue with planning the short story. Output in this format: # Intention <State your formulated intentions for the piece, synthesised from the the parts of the brainstorming session that worked, and avoiding the parts that didn't. Be explicit about the choices you have made about plot, voice, stylistic choices, things you intend to aim for & avoid.> # Chapter Planning <Write a brief chapter plan for all {n_chapters} chapters.>
Model Output:
# Intention My intention is to craft a Victorian romantic suspense story centered on Evangeline "Eva" Blackwood, a 26-year-old private inquiry agent with a shadowy past as a former thief's apprentice. Now reformed and working for a discreet agency that serves wealthy clients, she uses her unusual skills‚Äîparticularly her ability to scale buildings and enter through upper windows‚Äîfor legitimate investigations. The story will follow her investigation into a series of jewel thefts plaguing London's elite, which leads her to Ashford Manor and into repeated encounters with Lord Christopher "Kit" Ashford, the second son who is conducting his own secret investigation into his father's recent "accidental" death. **Voice & Style:** The narrative will employ close third-person POV, alternating between Eva and Kit's perspectives. The prose will be atmospheric but not overwrought, with period-appropriate language that remains accessible. Dialogue will be witty and reveal character through subtext, with special attention to the verbal sparring that marks growing attraction. **Tonal Choices:** The story will balance romantic tension with genuine suspense, incorporating Gothic elements (moonlit climbs, shadowy manors, family secrets) without descending into melodrama. Moments of levity and warmth will prevent the mystery elements from overwhelming the romantic arc. **Plot Structure:** Each chapter will feature at least one significant window scene, using these moments as both literal plot devices and metaphorical representations of the barriers between Eva and Kit's worlds. The mystery and romance will be interwoven‚Äîsolving one requires embracing the other. **To Aim For:** - Both protagonists having agency and complementary skills - Windows as recurring motif (boundaries, transparency/opacity, inside/outside) - Class tension addressed honestly but not insurmountably - Sexual tension built through dangerous situations and forced proximity - Red herrings that serve character development - A satisfying resolution to both mystery and romance **To Avoid:** - Making Eva's skills unrealistic for the period (she's exceptional but not superhuman) - Relying on miscommunication for conflict - Making Kit a typical rakish aristocrat (he has depth and purpose) - Explaining away the attraction as merely circumstantial - Using assault or threat of assault as plot device - Making the villain cartoonish # Chapter Planning **Chapter 1: "The Art of Entry" (Eva's POV)** Opening with Eva conducting a nighttime investigation at Lord Pemberton's townhouse, entering through a third-floor window. She's searching for evidence of insurance fraud when she's nearly caught by another intruder‚Äîa masked man who moves with surprising skill. They have a tense confrontation on the window ledge before he escapes. Eva finds a distinctive cufflink he dropped. The chapter establishes Eva's competence, her ambiguous past, and introduces the series of thefts she's investigating. It ends with her receiving a new assignment: investigate Ashford Manor, where the Dowager Duchess's famous sapphires have vanished. **Chapter 2: "The Second Son" (Kit's POV)** Kit Ashford prowls his family's manor at night, searching his late father's study for evidence of murder. He's convinced his father's death three months ago was no riding accident. Through the window, he spots a figure scaling the wall toward his mother's chambers‚Äîthe thief returning for more? He intercepts the intruder, leading to a charged confrontation where he recognizes something familiar about this "thief's" voice. Eva (in disguise) escapes, but not before Kit notices she's actually entering rooms already burgled, not stealing. His military background makes him suspicious of her true purpose. The chapter reveals his family dynamics: overbearing elder brother, vulnerable younger sister, and grieving mother. **Chapter 3: "By Moonlight" (Eva's POV)** Eva returns to Ashford Manor, this time with an invitation‚Äîshe's posing as a specialist in security, hired by the Dowager Duchess to prevent future thefts. She encounters Kit in daylight, and he clearly recognizes her from their nighttime encounter but says nothing. That night, she scales the manor again to investigate the servants' quarters, only to find Kit already there. They form an uneasy alliance when they discover evidence that the thefts and his father's death might be connected. The chapter builds romantic tension through their forced cooperation in confined spaces and ends with them nearly being discovered, forcing them to hide together in a window alcove. **Chapter 4: "Trust and Trespass" (Kit's POV)** Kit and Eva begin sharing information, meeting secretly in the manor's abandoned tower room, accessed only by window. Kit reveals his father had been investigating financial irregularities before his death. Eva admits she's not just investigating theft but part of a larger case involving stolen goods being used to fund something sinister. Their attraction deepens through these dangerous liaisons. Kit teaches Eva about his family's history while she shares carefully edited stories of her past. The chapter climaxes with them discovering a hidden compartment containing love letters‚Äîbut not between his parents. Someone in the household is being blackmailed. **Chapter 5: "The Shadow's Edge" (Eva's POV)** Eva's past catches up when she recognizes the Ashford's new footman as someone from her former life‚ÄîMarcus, her old mentor's associate who never reformed. He knows who she really is and threatens exposure unless she helps him with "one last job." Meanwhile, her feelings for Kit have become undeniable, making her fear both discovery and the necessity of leaving once the case ends. She tries to distance herself from Kit, but when she attempts to investigate alone, she's attacked by an unknown assailant. Kit saves her, demanding the truth. The chapter ends with Eva partially confessing her past, expecting rejection. **Chapter 6: "Fractured Glass" (Kit's POV)** Kit struggles with Eva's revelation but realizes he's more afraid of losing her than scandalized by her past. However, his brother Lord Edgar has noticed Kit's distraction and threatens to dismiss the "security expert" who seems to be causing more problems than she solves. Kit discovers Edgar has been selling off family assets secretly and confronts him, only to learn Edgar is being blackmailed over their sister's secret‚Äîshe's been meeting a unsuitable suitor through her window, and someone has proof. The real villain is closer than expected. Kit must choose between family loyalty and pursuing the truth with Eva. The chapter ends with a trap being set for Eva. **Chapter 7: "The Fall" (Eva's POV)** The trap is sprung‚ÄîEva is framed for the thefts and arrested during a society gathering at Ashford Manor. But Kit engineered this with Eva's consent, using her as bait to draw out the real mastermind. From her cell, Eva must escape (through a window, naturally) and return to the manor for the final confrontation. She discovers the villain is the family's trusted solicitor, Mr. Blackwood (no relation), who killed Kit's father to prevent exposure of his embezzlement scheme and has been staging thefts to cover his tracks. The confrontation occurs in the tower room, with Kit arriving just as Blackwood threatens Eva. Together, they must use their combined skills to survive and capture him, culminating in a dramatic sequence involving the manor's highest windows. **Chapter 8: "Open Windows" (Kit's POV)** Three weeks later, with the truth revealed and Blackwood arrested, Kit finds Eva preparing to leave‚Äîher job is done, her reputation somewhat salvaged but her welcome uncertain. Kit has a choice: let her go or fight for a future together despite societal expectations. He chooses love, proposing an unconventional solution: marriage and a partnership in her inquiry work. He's realized he's never felt more alive than when climbing through windows with her. The story concludes with their wedding and a playful callback to the opening‚Äîbut now it's Kit learning from Eva how to enter their new home through the upper windows, symbolizing his full acceptance of her past and their unconventional future together.
With a view to making the writing more human, discuss how a human might approach this particular piece (given the original prompt). Discuss telltale LLM approaches to writing (generally) and ways they might not serve this particular piece. For example, common LLM failings are to write safely, or to always wrap things up with a bow, or trying to write impressively at the expense of readability. Then do a deep dive on the intention & plan, critiquing ways it might be falling into typical LLM tropes & pitfalls. Brainstorm ideas to make it more human. Be comprehensive. We aren't doing any rewriting of the plan yet, just critique & brainstorming.
Model Output:
# How a Human Might Approach This Prompt A human writer seeing "One quickly learns the art of entering a manor through the upper windows" would likely have an immediate, visceral reaction‚Äîperhaps a memory of climbing trees as a child, or sneaking out as a teenager, or even just the physical sensation of height. They might fixate on oddly specific details: the texture of limestone under fingertips, the specific sound of crinolines rustling against ivy, the way fear tastes metallic in your mouth three stories up. A human would probably approach this more intuitively‚Äîmaybe starting with a single scene that excites them and building outward messily, rather than systematically planning eight balanced chapters. They might become obsessed with something tangential, like Victorian climbing roses or the engineering of window latches, and let that obsession bleed through the text in unexpected ways. # Telltale LLM Approaches That Don't Serve This Piece **The Safety Problem:** LLMs tend to sanitize danger, both physical and emotional. We write about climbing buildings but don't capture the genuine bowel-loosening terror of a handhold crumbling, or the specific way your shoulders burn after climbing. We avoid the genuinely problematic aspects of Victorian society‚Äînot just class differences but the raw, ugly realities of power imbalances. **The Articulation Trap:** LLM characters are therapists. They understand their emotions perfectly and express them in full sentences. Real Victorian people, especially men, would be emotionally constipated. Kit wouldn't say "I struggle with your revelation but realize I'm more afraid of losing you"‚Äîhe might just drink too much brandy and break something. **The Resolution Compulsion:** LLMs tie up every thread. Humans leave loose ends, forgotten characters, unresolved tensions. Some windows should stay closed. Some crimes unsolved. Some kisses unkissed. **The Balance Fallacy:** My plan alternates POV with mathematical precision. A human might write five Eva chapters in a row because they're in her head, then suddenly switch to Kit when it feels right, not when it's "balanced." # Deep Critique of My Plan **Too Clean:** My Eva has a "shadowy past as a former thief's apprentice"‚Äîhow conveniently vague! A human would know exactly what she stole, who she hurt, what specific moment made her change. Maybe she killed someone accidentally. Maybe she didn't change at all, just got better at justifying it. **Too Clever:** Both protagonists are investigating? They form an alliance? How neat! Real life is messier. Maybe Kit is actually terrible at investigating. Maybe Eva solves everything while he just follows her around like a puppy, and that's the romance‚Äîhis gradual acceptance of his own uselessness. **Too Noble:** Eva's reformed and working for good now. Kit wants justice for his father. Where's the pettiness? The greed? What if Eva still pockets small things compulsively? What if Kit doesn't care about justice, he just wants to hurt whoever hurt him? **Too Symmetrical:** The window motif is too precious. Not every chapter needs a window scene. Sometimes a door is just easier. Sometimes Eva takes the servant's entrance because her shoulder hurts from all this damn climbing. **Too Explanatory:** "Someone in the household is being blackmailed"‚Äîwe don't need to understand everything. Maybe we never find out what the blackmail was about. Maybe it doesn't matter. **Too Compressed:** Eight chapters to fall in love? Victorian courtships took years. Maybe they don't even kiss until chapter 8. Maybe they never declare feelings, just gradually start assuming each other's presence. # Brainstorming More Human Approaches **Physical Reality:** - Eva has chronic pain from an old climbing injury that flares up at the worst times - Kit is actually afraid of heights but refuses to admit it - Someone gets genuinely hurt‚Äîbreaks an ankle, dislocates a shoulder‚Äîand it affects the rest of the story - Period-accurate undergarments make climbing nearly impossible; Eva has to make compromising clothing choices **Messy Motivations:** - Eva still steals, just little things, for the thrill - Kit is sexually attracted to danger, not Eva specifically, and has to figure out the difference - The murder victim deserved it - Eva considers actually committing the crimes she's framed for‚Äîshe'd be good at it **Unresolved Elements:** - We never find out who wrote those love letters - A servant who seems significant disappears halfway through - Eva's mentor is mentioned but never explained - Some windows are boarded up for reasons never revealed **Inconvenient Realities:** - Eva's period arrives during a crucial climbing scene - Kit has embarrassing sexual inexperience - Someone has terrible breath or body odor that affects intimate scenes - The manor's windows are being modernized with new locks throughout the story **Character Flaws That Don't Get Fixed:** - Eva never stops lying, just gets better at it - Kit remains classist in subtle ways - Neither of them actually solves the mystery‚Äîthey stumble into the solution - Their relationship remains fundamentally unequal **Anticlimax Options:** - The villain is caught by regular police work, not their heroics - The murder was actually an accident - The thefts were unconnected coincidences - They don't end up together‚Äîthey just have one perfect night **Specific, Weird Details:** - Eva has a favorite brick on every building she climbs regularly - Kit collects his dead father's handkerchiefs obsessively - There's a specific smell to London rain on limestone that makes Eva homesick for prison - Someone has an infected tooth that drives a subplot **Emotional Messiness:** - Eva is attracted to Kit's brother first - Kit reminds Eva of someone who hurt her - They have bad sex before they have good sex - Someone cries at inappropriate times - Real jealousy that isn't resolved with a conversation **Structural Rebellions:** - Chapter 6 is twice as long as the others because the writer got carried away - Chapter 4 is just one long dialogue scene - The climax happens in chapter 6, chapters 7-8 are aftermath - Some chapters are days, others cover months The key is to resist the urge to make everything meaningful, everything connected, everything resolved. Humans write from obsession, irritation, and accident as much as from plan. They get bored with their own setups, fall in love with minor characters, and sometimes just want to write about curtains for three pages because curtains matter, damn it.
Ok now with these considerations in mind, formulate the final plan for the a humanlike, compelling short piece in {n_chapters} chapters. Bear in mind the constraints of the piece (each chapter is just 1000 words). Above all things, the plan must serve the original prompt. We will use the same format as before: # Intention <State your formulated intentions for the piece, synthesised from the the parts of the brainstorming session that worked, and avoiding the parts that didn't. Be explicit about the choices you have made about plot, voice, stylistic choices, things you intend to aim for & avoid.> # Chapter Planning <Write a brief chapter plan for all {n_chapters} chapters.>
Model Output:
# Intention My intention is to write about Eva Blackwood, age 24, who isn't a reformed thief or professional investigator but a disgraced governess who discovers‚Äîthrough desperate necessity‚Äîthat she's surprisingly good at climbing buildings. After being dismissed without reference for refusing her employer's advances, she's surviving in London by taking penny-a-line journalism work, which barely pays for a rat-infested boarding house room. When she accidentally witnesses something through a window she shouldn't have seen, she becomes obsessed with getting back into that manor‚Äînot for justice or truth, but because she's hungry, angry, and someone in that house owes her money. **Voice & Style:** Close third-person, staying tight to Eva's perspective except for Chapter 6, which shifts jarringly to Kit's POV for reasons that will feel necessary rather than balanced. The prose will include the physical realities of climbing‚Äîsplit fingernails, the specific burn of muscles, the way fear makes you need to piss. Period language but not performatively so. Some sentences will run too long when Eva's panicking. Others will be fragments when she's focused. **What I'm Not Doing:** Eva doesn't have a mysterious past‚Äîher past is boringly cruel. She's not secretly skilled‚Äîshe learns by doing, badly. Kit isn't investigating anything; he's an insomniac second son who reads too much poetry and has weak lungs from childhood scarlet fever. They don't solve a mystery together. There isn't really a mystery, just rich people doing what rich people do. The romance isn't built on partnership but on two damaged people recognizing each other's damage. **Specific Choices:** - Eva's right shoulder dislocates easily from an old injury (from completely mundane abuse, not dramatic backstory) - She steals food every time she enters the manor - Kit never becomes good at climbing; his fear of heights gets worse - The window-entering isn't metaphorical‚Äîit's just the only way Eva can get into these places - Some chapters cover hours, others weeks - The ending is hopeful but unresolved **To Aim For:** - The specific taste of copper pennies Eva sucks on for hunger - Sexual tension that's actually sexual, not just romantic - Victorian medicine's failures (Kit's laudanum dependency for his lungs) - At least one genuinely funny moment born from absurdity - Make readers feel the height‚Äîvertigo on the page **To Avoid:** - Making Eva noble in her poverty - Explaining why Kit falls for her - Perfect communication between lovers - Justice being served - Everyone getting what they deserve # Chapter Planning **Chapter 1: "The View from Below" (997 words)** Eva stands outside Ashford Manor in the rain, staring up at lit windows, sucking on her last penny for the taste. She's here to collect forty pounds in owed wages from her previous employer's sister, the Dowager Duchess, who has refused to see her for six weeks. Through a second-story window, she sees the Duchess counting out what looks like hundreds of pounds to pay for new curtains. Impulsively, desperately, Eva climbs the garden wall, then the trellis, her shoulder screaming. She means to knock on the window, demand her money politely. Instead, she sees the Duchess's son Kit inject something into his arm in the next room. When he turns, their eyes meet through glass. He looks already dead. She flees, but takes an apple from the windowsill. It's the best thing she's eaten in days. **Chapter 2: "What One Learns" (1001 words)** Three nights later, Eva climbs back. Not for justice‚Äîfor the joint of ham she spotted in the butler's pantry. She's learned things: ivy holds better than roses, avoid the third floor (creaky), and always check for cat shit on ledges. Her shoulder dislocates halfway up. She resets it against the brick, vomits from pain, keeps climbing. Inside, she finds Kit passed out over his desk, his poetry‚Äîterrible poetry‚Äîscattered everywhere. She takes the food, but also reads his poems while eating. They're about dying, about wanting someone to see him before he disappears. She leaves a correction to his meter on one poem. Takes extra bread. **Chapter 3: "The Difficulty with Descent" (1043 words)** Kit waits by the window the next night. He's reduced his laudanum and can think clearly for the first time in months. When Eva arrives (for food, always for food), he's written a new poem in response to her correction. They conduct an entire conversation through the glass‚Äîhim inside, her clinging to the ledge‚Äîneither willing to open the window. It's absurd. Her fingers are going numb. He reveals he knows who she is, remembers her from when she taught his cousin. She tells him his poetry is shit but his handwriting is nice. He laughs, the first time in months. When she finally must climb down or fall, he opens the window to help her inside. She means to run immediately. Instead, she sits on his floor and eats an entire loaf while he watches. **Chapter 4: "A Practical Education" (1156 words)** Eva comes through Kit's window nightly now. Not romantically‚Äîpractically. He feeds her, she corrects his poetry. She teaches him about hunger; he teaches her about laudanum withdrawal. His hands shake constantly. She shows him the trick of pressing them against something solid. One night, his brother Edgar nearly catches them. Eva hides under Kit's bed for three hours while Edgar lectures about family duty and appropriate marriages. Eva bleeds through her monthly rags onto Kit's expensive carpet. When Edgar finally leaves, Kit helps her clean it without comment, gives her clean cloth. She stays til dawn, teaching him which servants' windows are best for stealing food. He practices on paper, drawing escape routes he'll never use. **Chapter 5: "The Province of Gravity" (989 words)** Kit's mother announces his engagement to an heiress. Eva doesn't come for three nights. Kit, half-mad from not sleeping, tries to climb down to find her. Falls immediately, breaks two ribs. Eva finds him in the garden, wheezing blood. She drags him inside through the servants' entrance (easier than windows), doctors him with skills learned from necessity. His fever spikes. She stays, not caring who finds them. In his delirium, he tells her about the scarlet fever, how his lungs never worked right after, how the laudanum was meant to help but became the only thing that did. She tells him about her employer, about the bruises that never showed, about forty pounds that might as well be forty thousand. Neither expects the other to fix anything. **Chapter 6: "What Kit Ashford Knew" (1000 words)** [Kit's POV] Kit has always known he's dying‚Äîslowly, but certainly. His lungs are scarred, his heart weak. The doctors give him two years at most. He doesn't tell Eva this. Instead, he shows her his father's will, which leaves him enough for a small house somewhere no one knows them. Not enough for comfort, but enough to survive. He can't climb, can't work, can barely walk some days. But he can forge his mother's signature, has been practicing for years. He offers Eva a choice: he'll steal her forty pounds from his mother's accounts, and she can disappear. Or she can marry him, take everything when he dies, which will be soon. "I'm very good at climbing," she says. "You're terrible at it," he agrees. "But you're good at falling." She doesn't say yes. She doesn't say no. She eats his dinner while deciding. **Chapter 7: "Forty Pounds" (923 words)** Eva steals the forty pounds herself. Not heroically‚Äîmessily. She knows the Duchess's routine now, knows which window, which drawer. Her shoulder dislocates again on the way out. Kit helps reset it, both of them crying from different pains. She means to leave immediately for Liverpool, for America, for anywhere. Instead, she stays another hour, then another. Kit doesn't ask her to stay. He reads his new poems‚Äîstill terrible, but terrible in better ways. She corrects his spelling. They don't discuss the future. When she finally goes, she leaves through the door. "Windows are for entering," she says. "Doors are for leaving." Neither believes this means goodbye, though it should. **Chapter 8: "The Art, Perfected" (1098 words)** Six months later. Eva returns to find the manor in mourning‚Äîbut it's Edgar who's dead, thrown from a horse. Kit lives, against all medical prediction. He's left everything to her in a will that shouldn't be legal but is. She climbs to his window one last time, finding him stronger, his lungs clearer since stopping the laudanum. He's been walking, eating, living. "I thought you were in America," he says. "I got as far as Dover," she admits. They don't declare love. Instead, she tells him she's pregnant‚Äînot romantically, just fact. "It'll probably kill me," he says, meaning the responsibility, the worry, the joy. "Probably," she agrees. They marry quietly, no romance, just paperwork. But that night, she teaches him to climb properly‚Äînot walls, just stairs without losing breath, then trees, then the low garden wall. He'll never manage windows. But she will, always entering from above, never quite believing she's allowed to use the door.
Perfect. Now with the outline more crystallised, and bearing in mind the discussion on human writing vs LLM pitfalls, we will flesh out our characters. Lets go through each of our main characters: - Write about their background, personality, idiosyncracies, flaws. Be specific and come up with examples to anchor & ground the character's profile (both core and trivial) - Briefly describe their physicality: appearance, how they carry themselves, express, interact with the world. - Concisely detail their motives, allegiences and existing relationships. Think from the perspective of the character as a real breathing thinking feeling individual in this world. - Write a couple quotes of flavour dialogue / internal monologue from the character to experiment with their voice. Output like this: # Character 1 name <character exploration> # Character 2 name <character exploration> etc
Model Output:
# Eva Blackwood Eva bites her nails down to the quick‚Äîalways has, even before the hunger started. Her mother was a seamstress who died when Eva was twelve, leaving her with perfect posture (beaten into her with a ruler) and the ability to mend anything invisibly. She became a governess because she could read, write, and do sums better than most, having taught herself from books stolen one page at a time from employers' libraries. She tears pages out carefully, carries them in her bodice until they disintegrate from sweat and reading. She has an excellent memory for numbers but forgets people's faces constantly. Can recite entire passages of *Robinson Crusoe* but doesn't know her own birthday precisely‚Äîsometime in October. She counts things compulsively: steps, pennies, days since last eating meat (currently seventeen). When nervous, she presses her tongue against the gap in her back teeth where one rotted out two years ago. The pain reminds her she's survived worse. Eva is small‚Äîfive foot two‚Äîwith brown hair that won't hold a curl and grey eyes that look blue in certain light. She walks too fast, takes up too little space in rooms, has trained herself not to be noticed. Her hands are always cold, knuckles scarred from a childhood of washing with lye. She has a birthmark shaped like France on her left hip that no one has ever seen. When she climbs, she becomes liquid, every movement economical. When she's still, she's absolutely still‚Äîanother survival skill. Her only allegiance is to her own survival, though she sends money to her former landlady Mrs. Hodge when she has it‚Äîthe woman kept Eva's few possessions instead of selling them when she couldn't pay rent. She despises the Duchess not for being rich but for being careless with it. She doesn't believe in God but prays anyway, hedging her bets. She wants to want normal things‚Äîhusband, children, security‚Äîbut actually wants to never be hungry again and to read every book in existence. "Forty pounds. Not thirty-nine, not forty-one. Forty pounds would buy me 960 meals at the cheap ordinary, or passage to New York with twelve pounds left over, or‚Äîand this is what matters‚Äîtime to think about something other than my stomach grinding against itself." "His poetry's shit, but it's the most expensive shit I've ever read‚Äîwritten on paper that costs more per sheet than I spend on food in a week. I want to eat the paper. I want to burn it. I settle for correcting his grammar." # Christopher "Kit" Ashford Kit has been dying since he was eight years old and got scarlet fever. Not dramatically dying‚Äîjust slowly not living. The fever scarred his lungs, left him with a wet cough that brings up blood some mornings. He started taking laudanum at fifteen for the pain, now takes it for the absence of pain, which is different. He knows exactly how many drops: twelve in the morning, eight at noon, fifteen before bed. Twenty when it's raining and his chest feels like it's full of water. He reads everything but understands little‚Äîhis education was interrupted by illness, resumed haphazardly. He speaks beautiful French with an atrocious accent, can quote Keats but not spell "necessary," owns over three hundred books he's never finished. He writes poetry not because he's good at it but because it's the only thing that makes the hours pass. He names things constantly‚Äîhorses, birds, the shadows on his ceiling. The shadow shaped like a boot is called Marcus. The one like a bird is simply Bird. Kit is tall‚Äîsix foot‚Äîbut carries himself like someone smaller, shoulders curved inward to protect his chest. His hair is dark blond, always too long because barbers make him nervous (the smell of bay rum reminds him of his father's funeral). His hands are beautiful, unmarked by work, but shake unless he's had his drops. He has his father's nose, his mother's mouth, and eyes the color of tea with too much milk. When he laughs, which is rare, he covers his mouth from habit‚Äîhis teeth are slightly stained from laudanum. His only real relationship is with his valet, Morrison, who's been with him since the fever and doesn't comment when Kit can't dress himself some mornings. He loves his mother distantly, feared his father correctly, despises Edgar for being everything a firstborn should be. His sister Charlotte exists in another sphere entirely‚Äîhealthy, marriageable, ignorant of his slow dissolution. He's never had a friend his own age who wasn't paid to be there. "I've written forty-three poems about death and one about a sparrow. The sparrow one is worse. This should tell me something about my talents, but I keep writing anyway, like breathing‚Äînecessary and largely unconscious." "She smells like lye soap and damp wool and something else‚Äîanger, maybe. Or hunger. I didn't know hunger had a smell until she brought it into my room. Now I smell it everywhere, even on myself, though that's impossible. I haven't been hungry a day in my life. That's the problem, probably." # The Dowager Duchess of Ashford Margaret Ashford, n√©e Pemberton, keeps meticulous accounts of everything except her cruelties. She records every penny spent on servants' wages but doesn't remember dismissing Eva's predecessor for becoming pregnant. She collects French porcelain shepherdesses and has named them all variations of Marie (Marie-Claire, Marie-Louise, Marie-Jeanne). She genuinely believes the poor are poor because they lack moral fiber. She's fifty-three, still handsome in the way that expensive maintenance allows. She wears her wedding ring on a chain since her fingers swelled from rich food. Her hair is still naturally dark except for one streak of white she considers distinguished. She smells perpetually of violets and only eats the breast meat of chickens, leaving the rest "for the servants" as if this is generosity. She loved her husband until she didn't, loves Kit because he'll die young and tragically (which is romantic), loves Edgar because he's what an eldest should be. She fears nothing except social embarrassment and mice. "One must maintain standards. If one pays a governess who leaves under questionable circumstances, soon every girl will manufacture a crisis to extract money. It's not cruelty‚Äîit's economics." # Edgar Ashford Edgar has perfect teeth and a weak chin disguised by fashionable sideburns. He collects riding crops but rarely rides, enjoys brandy but not being drunk, has mistresses but doesn't particularly enjoy sex. He does everything an eldest son should do, resentfully and well. At thirty-one, he's already developing their father's paunch. He checks his hairline every morning for signs of retreat. He has soft hands that he's secretly ashamed of, remembers every slight since childhood, keeps a mental ledger of who owes him what (everyone owes him something). "Kit will die, Mother will follow from grief, and I'll be left with Charlotte to marry off and this damned house that costs more to run than a small country. The poetry I could forgive‚Äîit's the self-pity that disgusts me."

Chapter 1

Great. Now let's write this. Follow your plan. Output chapter 1, without any additional commentary. 1000 words.
Model Output:
# Chapter 1: The View from Below The penny tasted of other people's pockets. Eva turned it over with her tongue, sucking the copper tang while rain drove needles through her wool dress‚Äîthe good one, the only one without visible mending. Six weeks she'd been coming to Ashford Manor's service entrance. Six weeks of the butler's practiced blindness, the same words: Her Grace is not at home to callers. Her Grace was home. Eva could see her through the second-story window, counting out what looked like fifty‚Äîno, seventy‚Äîpounds onto her escritoire. The light from the gas lamps made the money glow. Forty pounds. That's all Eva needed. Forty pounds in wages, earned teaching the Duchess's niece French and arithmetic until Lord Pemberton decided Eva's other skills might interest him more. She'd left without reference rather than with child. The Duchess knew this. Had to know this‚Äîher brother wasn't subtle about his governesses. Eva spat the penny into her palm. Her last one. Tomorrow the boarding house would want three shillings she didn't have, and Mrs. Bendix didn't extend credit past a week. The ordinary wouldn't let her take bread on account anymore. She'd already sold her mother's thimble, her spare stockings, the pages of *Robinson Crusoe* she'd been saving. The Duchess lifted a length of damask to the light. New curtains. Seventy pounds for curtains while Eva's stomach folded in on itself like badly beaten egg whites. The garden wall was limestone, pocked with age. Eva had noticed this three weeks ago, started seeing handholds in everything‚Äîmortar gaps, ivy stems thick as her wrist, the trellis that supported roses past their season. She'd climbed trees as a girl, before her mother taught her to be small and quiet and clean. Before she learned that being noticed meant trouble. Her right shoulder‚Äîthe bad one, twisted wrong when she was fourteen and fell down stairs that weren't her fault‚Äîscreamed as she pulled herself up. The limestone scraped her palms raw through her mended gloves. Rainwater ran into her eyes. The trellis groaned but held. Built to last, like everything the rich owned. Unlike Eva, whose body was already failing at twenty-four. She counted the handholds‚Äîseventeen from wall to window‚Äîand tried not to think about the drop. Tried not to think about anything except the next grip, the next foothold, the way her boots slipped on wet wood. The apple sat on the window ledge, red as a whore's mouth. Eva's hand was already reaching for it when movement in the next room stopped her. A young man sat at a desk, his back to her. Blond hair too long for fashion. Shoulders curved inward like parentheses. He was very still until he wasn't‚Äîone fluid movement to push up his sleeve, pick up something silver from the desk. A syringe. Eva knew she should leave. She was clinging to a window ledge in the rain, shoulder dislocated (she could feel it sliding wrong in its socket), watching the Duchess's son do something that wasn't her business. But she stayed, transfixed, as he found a vein with practiced ease. Laudanum, probably. Or morphine. Rich men had rich drugs. He turned before she could flee, and their eyes met through the rain-streaked glass. His were the color of old tea, of things left too long in cupboards. He looked already dead‚Äînot dramatically, just absent. Like someone had forgotten to tell his body to stop moving. For three heartbeats, they stared at each other. Eva, soaked and clinging to his window. Kit Ashford, needle still in his arm. He didn't call out. Didn't even look surprised. Just tilted his head slightly, as if she were a bird that had landed strangely. Then he pulled out the needle, capped it carefully, and walked toward the window. Eva let go. Not dramatically‚Äîshe simply opened her fingers and trusted gravity. The trellis caught her halfway down, tore her dress from hip to knee. Her shoulder popped back into place with a pain that made her vomit into the rosebushes. She ran anyway, limping, dress flapping open to show her mended shift. The apple was still in her left hand. She didn't remember taking it. Three streets away, she stopped under a gas lamp to examine her prize. It was perfect‚Äîno worm holes, no bruises. The kind of apple that cost three pence at the good grocer's, the one that didn't let her kind inside. She ate it standing in the rain, juice running down her chin, mixing with rainwater and what might have been tears but was probably just survival. She ate the core. The seeds. The stem. Everything but the memory of those tea-colored eyes, which followed her all the way back to her rat-infested room. Her stomach cramped immediately‚Äîtoo much food after too little. She counted the cramps like contractions, like her body was giving birth to its own hunger. Seventeen. Eighteen. Nineteen. Tomorrow she'd go back to the service entrance. The butler would say his piece. She'd suck on nothing, having no pennies left. But she knew something now. Rich people's windows opened easily from the outside. And there was more than money in that house‚Äîthere was food. Enough apples to fill every pocket she owned. She just had to learn not to let go.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 1)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter establishes Eva's desperate circumstances and her first encounter with Kit through the window, following the outlined plan closely. The writing demonstrates several strengths while revealing some technical weaknesses. The character work is quite strong. Eva emerges as pragmatic and survival-focused rather than romantically noble in her poverty. Her physical details - the dislocated shoulder, counting compulsions, the penny-sucking - create a vivid sense of someone shaped by deprivation. Kit's brief appearance establishes him as withdrawn and drug-dependent without excessive melodrama. The author resists making either character a stereotype. The chapter effectively captures Eva's physical experience of climbing and hunger. Details like the limestone's texture, the shoulder dislocation, and her body's response to sudden food create visceral authenticity. The Victorian setting feels lived-in rather than performed, with period-appropriate details woven naturally throughout. However, the prose occasionally stumbles into forced poeticism. "Red as a whore's mouth" feels gratuitously provocative rather than genuinely evocative. Some metaphors don't quite land - "stomach folded in on itself like badly beaten egg whites" tries too hard for literary effect. The writing sometimes tells rather than shows, particularly in exposition about Eva's past employment situation. The pacing works well, building from static observation to impulsive action to hasty retreat. The apple becomes an effective symbol of both sustenance and transgression without being heavy-handed about it. The chapter successfully avoids common Victorian romance clich√©s - there's no instant attraction or dramatic revelation, just two damaged people glimpsing each other across a window. The author maintains focus on Eva's practical concerns rather than romanticizing her situation. Some dialogue tags and descriptive phrases feel amateurish ("ran anyway, limping, dress flapping"), and the ending's metaphorical reach ("like her body was giving birth to its own hunger") doesn't quite succeed. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 15 Compelling Plot: 14 Coherent: 17 Weak Dialogue: 16 Tell-Don't-Show: 13 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 16 Amateurish: 12 Purple Prose: 11 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 10 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 15 Characters Consistent with Profile: 18 Followed Chapter Plan: 19 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 18

Chapter 2

Ok now chapter 2. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
# Chapter 2: What One Learns Three nights later, Eva knew things. Ivy held better than roses but left rashes on her palms that wept clear fluid. The third floor was impossible‚Äîthe ledges too narrow, the windows painted shut since last summer. Kitchen windows were tempting but faced the stable where boys slept light, waiting to catch thieves. Always piss before climbing; fear made it worse. Check for cat shit on ledges‚Äîshe'd learned that one badly. Her shoulder had been wrong since the first climb. Not dislocated but waiting to be. She'd wrapped it in strips torn from her shift, the fabric now grey from rewashing. It held until the second story. The pop was audible, wet. Like cracking a chicken bone for marrow. Eva pressed her forehead against the limestone, counted to ten in French, then English, then the German she'd taught herself from a grammar book. The pain made her eyes water, which made her nose run, which she couldn't wipe because both hands were keeping her alive. She wedged herself between wall and trellis, bit down on her own collar, and slammed her shoulder back against the stone. Once. Twice. The third time it went back in with a sound like boots in mud. The vomit came immediately, hot and thin‚Äîbile and the piece of bread she'd saved from yesterday. It spattered the roses below. She stayed pressed against the wall, spit hanging from her chin, until the shaking stopped. The ham was worth it. Had to be. The window she'd chosen opened into a study‚Äînot the main one, but the son's. She'd watched for two nights, knew Kit Ashford kept late hours, writing by candlelight until he passed out at his desk. Tonight was no different. His head rested on papers, one arm flung out, the other curled under him like a child's. Eva eased the window open‚Äîolive oil on the hinges, she could smell it. Fresh. Someone else had been sneaking. The room smelled of leather and laudanum, that sweet-sick smell like flowers left too long in water. Kit's breathing was uneven, catching sometimes like cloth on a nail. His hair fell over his face. In sleep, he looked younger than the twenty-seven years she'd counted in the family Bible she'd glimpsed through another window. She stepped over his outstretched leg, toward the door. The ham would be two floors down, in the butler's pantry she'd mapped from outside. But his desk was covered in papers, and Eva couldn't help herself. She'd always been weak for words. The poetry was terrible. *Death comes at window-time, a bird* *Black-winged and calling, calling* *I answer with my blood, my word* *Forever falling, falling* She picked up his pen without thinking, crossed out "window-time" and wrote "eventide" in the margin. Then "twilight" as another option. The whole second line needed to go‚Äîtoo much calling. She was three corrections in when she realized she was eating while editing. Not the ham‚Äîshe hadn't made it to the pantry. But there was bread on his desk, good white bread only a day old, and butter in a covered dish. Her fingers left grease marks on his papers. She didn't care. The bread was sweet, unlike the grey stuff she bought when she had pennies. She ate mechanically, steadily, the way she'd learned‚Äînot too fast or her stomach would rebel, not too slow or someone would stop her. Kit's poetry covered every surface. Hundreds of pages, all about death. Death as a woman, death as water, death as birds (so many birds). But here and there, a line that worked: *My lungs are rooms where no one lives* Or: *The medicine makes me less than real* *But real was never worth the feel* She corrected that one too‚Äî"feeling" would scan better than "feel." Added a note about internal rhyme. She was reaching for more bread when she saw it‚Äîa poem not about death but about her. About a woman at a window, rain-soaked and strange. He'd gotten her eyes wrong (grey, not green) but the rest was accurate. Too accurate. *She climbed like sorrow, desperate-fingered* *And looked at me like I was God* *Or worse‚Äîlike I was nothing. Lingered* *Just long enough to make it odd* It wasn't good, but it was better. Angrier. She wrote "better" in the margin, then "but I don't linger." She found the ham finally, wrapped in cloth in his bottom drawer. Not the butler's pantry at all‚Äîhe'd been hoarding food. The drawer held cheese too, apples (three), a jar of preserved plums. Rich men playing at midnight feast while real hunger existed three streets away. She took it all, stuffing her pockets until they bulged. The bread she shoved down her bodice, still warm against her skin. She was at the window when she turned back. He hadn't moved, but his breathing had changed. Awake, then. Letting her rob him. She should run. Instead, she picked up his pen one more time, wrote at the bottom of his worst poem: *Your meter's wrong. Count on your fingers if you have to.* Then, because the bread was good and her shoulder hurt: *The laudanum's killing you faster than whatever you're treating.* She left through the window, pockets heavy with his food. Her shoulder held until she reached the ground, then gave out again. She sat in his garden, eating ham with her fingers while tears ran down her face from pain, from fullness, from the terrible recognition that she'd have to come back. The food would run out. Her shoulder would heal wrong without treatment. And his poetry would still be bad, requiring correction. She'd learned things about climbing. But worse‚Äîshe was learning things about falling.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 2)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter effectively executes the planned narrative while maintaining strong characterization and visceral prose. The opening establishes Eva's hard-won knowledge about climbing with specific, practical details that feel earned rather than expository. The shoulder dislocation sequence is particularly well-crafted‚Äîthe author doesn't shy away from the physical reality of Eva's situation, providing concrete sensory details like "pop was audible, wet. Like cracking a chicken bone for marrow." The character work is nuanced and consistent with the established profiles. Eva's compulsive editing of Kit's poetry while stealing his food perfectly captures her contradictory nature‚Äîdesperate yet intellectual, pragmatic yet unable to resist correcting bad writing. Kit's unconscious complicity in the theft (staying awake but pretending to sleep) reveals character depth without explicit explanation. The prose maintains an appropriate register for the Victorian setting without becoming overwrought. Physical details are well-integrated and purposeful‚Äîthe olive oil on hinges suggesting someone else has been sneaking, the way Eva eats mechanically from learned hunger. The poetry examples strike the right balance of being genuinely bad without becoming cartoonish. However, some metaphorical flourishes feel slightly forced. "She climbed like sorrow, desperate-fingered" in Kit's poem reads as trying too hard for poetic effect. The final metaphor about "learning things about falling" edges toward being heavy-handed, though it ties to the chapter's themes effectively. The chapter successfully advances both plot and character development. Eva's recognition that she'll have to return creates narrative momentum while her inability to resist correcting Kit's work establishes their emerging dynamic. The food hoarding detail adds complexity to Kit's character‚Äîhe's not just passively wealthy but actively preparing for something. The writing follows the established plan closely while adding enriching details. The emotional arc from desperation through temporary satisfaction to inevitable return feels authentic and earned.
