Finds his obvious need for approval both pathetic and weirdly attractive. **Voice & Style:** - Dialogue-heavy with interruptions, talking over each other, sentences that trail off - Rhys code-switches badly between "Hollywood charm" and desperate authenticity - Cerys oscillates between cutting observations and flustered silences - Physical details over emotional exposition‚Äînervous habits, looks that linger too long - Conversations that miss each other, fail to connect, then suddenly do **What I'll Aim For:** - Genuine awkwardness: failed jokes, uncomfortable silences, saying the wrong thing - Attraction that's inconvenient and poorly timed rather than destiny - Incomplete resolution‚Äîlife doesn't fix itself in 8 chapters - Specific, weird details that don't serve symbolism - Characters who don't learn lessons so much as muddle through **What I'll Avoid:** - Perfect banter where every line lands - Clear character growth arcs - Welsh culture as magical healing force - Convenient external conflicts that unite them - Tidy endings that resolve all tensions - Characters who understand their own motivations # Chapter Planning **Chapter 1: "Emergency Exit"** Rhys crashes into the shop, genuinely panicked about photographers, knocking over a display. Cerys is eating her lunch, annoyed at the interruption. His opening charm offensive is a disaster‚Äîhe quotes Yeats incorrectly, name-drops authors she's never heard of, and steps on the shop cat's tail. She makes him buy the books he knocked over (¬£73 worth) while he hides behind the Biography section. He tries Welsh on her; it's grammatically horrifying. She responds in rapid Welsh he doesn't understand. An elderly customer needs help reaching a book and Rhys, desperate to be liked, nearly pulls the shelf down getting it. Cerys finds herself staring at his forearms when he rolls up his sleeves. He notices her noticing. They both pretend it didn't happen. **Chapter 2: "The Apology Tour"** Rhys returns with expensive coffee she doesn't drink (she takes tea, three sugars, builder's style). He's googled Welsh phrases but pronounces everything wrong. Cerys is hunched over accounts, genuinely stressed about money. He offers to sign books for resale; she points out nobody wants signed copies of books he didn't write. They argue about a film adaptation of a book‚Äîshe hated it, he was in it. He admits it was shit. She laughs, then catches herself. He helps her move boxes (she doesn't need help but his cologne is distracting). They develop a weird rhythm‚Äîhim talking too much, her mmm-hmming while secretly enjoying his desperate need for her approval. He leaves his number "in case she needs more boxes moved." **Chapter 3: "Thursday Night Mistake"** She texts him at 11pm, slightly wine-drunk from book club (they discussed his terrible action film, she defended it without meaning to). He's at a Cardiff hotel bar, three drinks in, posts a story that he immediately deletes. Messaging becomes calling. She's lying on her shop floor doing inventory, he's walked out onto a balcony. They talk for three hours about nothing‚Äîworst films, sandwich preferences, whether cats have accents. Neither remembers who falls asleep first. She wakes up with her phone dead, his last message: "you snore btw." She's mortified. Then pleased. Then mortified about being pleased. **Chapter 4: "Performance Issues"** Local primary school visit. Rhys volunteers to read (trying to impress her), but the kids are brutal‚Äîthey prefer YouTubers. He starts doing increasingly desperate voices, action scenes, even attempts a Welsh accent that makes Cerys physically wince. One kid asks if he's Cerys's boyfriend. They both say "no" too quickly, too loudly. After, drinking terrible instant coffee in her office, he admits the box office bomb was his fault‚Äîhe can't actually act, just does the same thing every film. She says she knows, she's seen them all. "All of them?" "I have a lot of quiet afternoons." They're sitting closer than necessary. Someone knocks; they spring apart like teenagers. **Chapter 5: "Local Celebrity"** Village pub quiz. Rhys insists on joining her team (her, her sister Sian who immediately recognizes him and is trying to be cool about it, and Gareth from the chip shop who has no idea who he is). Rhys is terrible at everything except the film round, where he's embarrassingly good. Gets competitive. Drinks too much. His hand keeps finding her knee under the table. She doesn't move away but won't look at him. They lose spectacularly. Walking her home, he tries to kiss her outside the shop. She turns her head, his lips hit her ear. "I don't do complicated," she says. "I'm not complicated," he lies. She laughs. "You're literally famous." "Only a bit famous." They stand there, not kissing, for too long. **Chapter 6: "Damage Control"** Photos surface of him at the pub, headlines scream about "mystery woman." His manager calls; Cerys can hear the shouting from across the shop. Customers keep coming in for gossip, not books. She closes early, finds him sitting on her back steps, head in hands. "I fucked it up. I always fuck it up." She sits beside him, their knees touching. "You didn't fuck up anything. This is just your life, isn't it?" He shows her his phone‚Äîhis ex calling him "pathetic" for "hiding in Wales." Cerys takes his phone, turns it off. "Come on. I'll make you a sandwich." They eat cheese and pickle in her flat above the shop. End up kissing messily against her fridge. Stop. Start again. Her sister texts: "MUM KNOWS." **Chapter 7: "Terrible Timing"** Morning after. He's wearing her late uncle's Wales rugby shirt, making scrambled eggs badly. They're being very careful not to talk about anything real. Her mother arrives with gossip and casserole, finds him barefoot in the kitchen. Excruciatingly polite conversation. After she leaves: "I have to go back to LA next week." "Right." "For reshoots." "Of course." They're terrible at this conversation. Keep starting sentences. He says he'll be back. She says sure. Neither believes it. The sex that night is desperate and a bit sad. He leaves at 4am for a flight. Kisses her forehead. She pretends to be asleep. **Chapter 8: "Ongoing Situation"** Six weeks later. He sends daily messages she sometimes answers. Terrible selfies from sets. She sends photos of new books, the cat, her sandwich. Video calls that lag. He's coming back "soon"‚Äîalways soon. She's started seeing Gareth from the chip shop (not really, but it's easier than explaining). The shop's busy‚Äîhis fans keep coming, buying books, asking questions. She's hired help. One Tuesday, no warning, he's there with a black coffee (she still takes tea) and a speech prepared. She cuts him off: "I know. It's complicated." "Everything's complicated." They stand there, holding hot drinks, the morning sun through dusty windows. A customer needs help. Life goes on. He stays. Or leaves. The cat doesn't care either way. But his terrible Welsh is getting marginally better, and she's started watching his new film on her phone, and maybe that's enough. Maybe it isn't. The shop is open 9 to 5:30, closed Sundays.
Perfect. Now with the outline more crystallised, and bearing in mind the discussion on human writing vs LLM pitfalls, we will flesh out our characters. Lets go through each of our main characters: - Write about their background, personality, idiosyncracies, flaws. Be specific and come up with examples to anchor & ground the character's profile (both core and trivial) - Briefly describe their physicality: appearance, how they carry themselves, express, interact with the world. - Concisely detail their motives, allegiences and existing relationships. Think from the perspective of the character as a real breathing thinking feeling individual in this world. - Write a couple quotes of flavour dialogue / internal monologue from the character to experiment with their voice. Output like this: # Character 1 name <character exploration> # Character 2 name <character exploration> etc
Model Output:
# Rhys Morgan **Background & Personality:** Rhys left Merthyr Tydfil at 21 for drama school in London, changed his surname from Pritchard because his agent said Morgan was "more marketable." Has been in three Fast & Furious knockoffs and a superhero film where he played "British Villain #2." His mum still lives in the same council house; he bought her a new build in Cardiff but she refused to move. Sends money home but hasn't visited in three years. Desperately insecure about his intelligence‚Äîfailed his A-levels, reads Wikipedia summaries of classic books before parties. Has a genuine love for terrible action films, not ironically, actually thinks Commando is high art. Laughs too loud at other people's jokes. Touches people when he talks‚Äîarms, shoulders, unconscious need for connection. Still quotes his dad who died when he was fifteen, always starts with "My old man used to say..." **Physicality:** 5'11" but tells people he's 6 foot. Gym-built in that specifically Hollywood way‚Äîtoo defined to be natural. Dyes his hair darker than its natural brown. Has a scar through his left eyebrow from a school fight he tells different stories about. Walks like he's always being filmed‚Äîshoulders back, slight swagger that disappears when he's actually relaxed. Rubs his jaw when lying. Expensive veneers that make his smile too white for his face. Wears designer clothes that never quite fit right‚Äîhe's between sizes and too vain to size up. Has reading glasses he never wears in public. **Motives & Relationships:** Wants to be taken seriously as an actor but also terrified of actual failure, so keeps taking safe roles. Sends his ex (actress Madeleine Cross) long texts at 2am he deletes in the morning. His manager, Simon, is the closest thing he has to a friend but he's not sure Simon actually likes him. Has a therapist in LA he lies to. Wants his mum to be proud but she keeps asking when he'll be in something she's heard of. Three-year relationship with Madeleine ended because she said being with him was "like dating a golden retriever who could do push-ups." Still hurt about it. **Voice Samples:** "Right, yeah, absolutely. That's brilliant. Really brilliant. Is it Wordsworth? No, wait‚ÄîKeats? Fuck, sorry, I know this one..." "My old man used to say you can tell everything about a person by their shoes. Course, he wore the same pair for fifteen years, so not sure what that said about him. These? They're... Italian. Cost more than... sorry, that's wanky, isn't it? Christ, I'm shit at this." Internal: *She's looking at me. Say something clever. Shakespeare. No, she'll know you googled it. Just smile. Not that much, you look mental. Christ, why is this so hard? It's just talking. You talk for a living. Technically.* # Cerys Davies **Background & Personality:** Inherited the shop when her gran died two years ago. Was doing a PhD in Contemporary Literature at Cardiff, quit to run the shop out of guilt and some romantic notion about "keeping it in the family." Regrets it every month when she does the accounts. Has an English degree she's defensive about using. Watches Love Island religiously but tells people she doesn't own a TV. Orders the same Chinese takeaway every Friday (sweet and sour chicken, fried rice, no prawn crackers because of a childhood incident). Has been engaged twice, never married, both times said yes when she meant "maybe" and let it drag out until they left. Bites her nails, paints them to stop, bites them anyway. Secretly writes book reviews on Goodreads under a fake name, surprisingly harsh. **Physicality:** 5'6", carries herself like she's trying to take up less space. Dark hair she cuts herself when anxious‚Äîcurrently uneven. Wears the same rotation of five jumpers, all slightly pilled. Has her gran's hands‚Äîlong fingers, always cold. Touches her neck when nervous. Smile comes slowly but changes her whole face when it's real. Terrible poker face‚Äîevery thought shows. Needs glasses but wears contacts, eyes always slightly red. Has a tattoo of a Virginia Woolf quote on her ribcage she got at uni, regrets it because it's slightly misquoted. Stands with her weight on one hip, arms crossed, defensive by default. **Motives & Relationships:** Wants to want the shop, if that makes sense. Feels like she should be grateful but mostly feels trapped. Sister Sian is married with kids, proper adult life, makes Cerys feel perpetually behind. Mum drops in daily with gossip and unsolicited advice about her love life. Dad thinks she should sell to developers, won't say it directly. Still in love with her ex Owen from uni who's now married, teaches at Cardiff, comes in sometimes to buy poetry. Tells herself she's waiting for something but doesn't know what. **Voice Samples:** "No, that's not... you're thinking of Byron. Everyone thinks that's Byron but it's actually... sorry, doesn't matter. It's ¬£8.99. Do you want a bag?" "I'm not impressed by the fame thing, if that's what you're doing. I've seen your films. Well, some of them. One and a half. The one with the helicopter was... loud." Internal: *Oh God, he's doing the smile. The Hollywood smile. Does he practice that? Probably. Definitely. Why is it working? It's not working. It's a bit working. Stop staring at his arms. Christ, Cerys, you're thirty-four, not fourteen.* # Sian Davies (Cerys's sister) **Background & Personality:** Younger by two years but has her life "together"‚Äîhusband Marc, two kids, teaches primary school. Secretly thrilled by Cerys's drama. Pretends to be above celebrity gossip but has Google alerts set for Rhys Morgan now. Drinks ros√© at 4pm "because it's practically juice." Gives advice through questions: "Have you thought about maybe not being so difficult?" Loves her sister but also enjoys being the stable one for once. **Physicality:** Cerys but softer‚Äîsame features but filled out from kids and contentment. Wears Boden, owns it. Always slightly harried, hair in a mum bun that actually looks good. **Voice Sample:** "I'm not saying you should shag him, but I'm also not saying you shouldn't. God, when did you get so precious about things? He's fit and he's clearly gagging for it. What's complicated about that?" # Mrs Pritchard (Regular customer) **Background & Personality:** 73, husband recently died, comes in daily for company not books. Buys one paperback a week, same genre (crime), same complaint ("not as good as Agatha Christie"). Knows everyone's business, shares it freely. Has no idea who Rhys is, doesn't care. Thinks Cerys needs to "get on with it" regarding everything‚Äîlife, love, the shop. **Physicality:** Tiny, imperious, same coat regardless of weather. Smells of Pears soap and cigarettes she claims she doesn't smoke. **Voice Sample:** "You've got a customer, love. Tall one. Looks lost. Bit pleased with himself if you ask me. Is that new? The thing with your hair? Well. It's certainly different."

Chapter 1

Great. Now let's write this. Follow your plan. Output chapter 1, without any additional commentary. 1000 words.
Model Output:
# Chapter 1: Emergency Exit The door slammed open hard enough to rattle the Victorian crime novels. "Shit, sorry, I‚Äî" The man stopped mid-apology, breathing hard, designer trainers squeaking on the worn floor. "Can I just‚Äîthere's photographers‚Äî" Cerys looked up from her cheese sandwich, a string of pickle hanging from her mouth. She sucked it in. "We're closed for lunch." "Your door was open." "For air. Not customers." He was already moving deeper into the shop, crushing himself between Biography and Local Interest. A camera flash went off outside. Then another. "Please." His voice cracked slightly. "Five minutes. I'll buy something." She recognized him then‚Äînot immediately, but in pieces. The jaw from that terrible submarine film. The eyes from the posters. Rhys something. Morgan? The Welsh one who wasn't actually Welsh anymore. "You're dripping on my books," she said. He looked down. He was. Rain from his designer jacket making small puddles on a stack of marked-down hardbacks. "Christ, sorry, I'll‚Äî" He shrugged off the jacket, knocked over the entire display of Welsh poetry. Twenty-three books cascaded across the floor. The shop cat, Mr. Darcy, yowled and shot upstairs. "Fuck." He dropped to his knees, grabbing books. "Sorry, God, I'm not usually‚Äî'I will arise and go now, and go to Innisfree.' Yeats, right? I know poetry." "That's Wordsworth." It wasn't. It was Yeats. But his desperate need to impress annoyed her. "Right. Yes. Wordsworth." He was still kneeling, holding a collection of R.S. Thomas like it might explode. "I knew that." Another flash outside. He flinched, duck-walked behind the counter where she was sitting. Too close. She could smell his cologne‚Äîexpensive, trying too hard. "You can't be back here." "Sorry, yes, I'll just‚Äî" He stood too fast, banged his head on the till. "Shit." "There's a stockroom." She pointed. "Through there. Don't touch anything." He disappeared. She heard a crash. Then: "Found it!" Cerys returned to her sandwich. Through the window, she counted three photographers, maybe four. They were patient, she'd give them that. Smoking, checking phones, waiting. "Diolch yn fawr." His head appeared around the doorframe. "That's thank you. In Welsh." "I know what it means." "Right. Course. You're Welsh." "So are you, supposedly." "I am!" He emerged fully, indignant. "Merthyr born and bred. Fy enw i yw Rhys." His pronunciation was painful. Like someone reading phonetically from a guidebook. "Dwi ddim yn credu bod gen ti Gymraeg," she said flatly. His face went blank. "Yeah, absolutely. Same to you." She nearly smiled. Caught herself. Mrs. Pritchard chose that moment to shuffle in, Tuesday crime novel clutched in her liver-spotted hand. "You've not got the new Rankin, have you, love? This one was rubbish. Too much swearing." She squinted at Rhys. "Who's this then? Bit tall for you." "He's not‚Äîhe's a customer." "Am I?" Rhys looked pleased. "Yes. I am. I need... books." "They're all around you," Cerys said. "Right. Yes." He grabbed the nearest one. "Perfect. This one." "That's volume three of a history of Welsh mining." "I love mining. History of it. Especially Welsh." Mrs. Pritchard was reaching for something on a high shelf, straining on her tiptoes. "Give us a hand, would you?" Rhys practically vaulted the counter in his eagerness to help. Grabbed the shelf for leverage. It creaked ominously. "Just the book, not the whole bloody thing," Mrs. Pritchard said. He extracted the book carefully, handed it over like an offering. She patted his arm. "Good lad. Bit eager, aren't you?" Outside, the photographers were multiplying. Six now. Maybe seven. "I should go," Rhys said, but didn't move. "They'll follow you," Cerys pointed out. "Yeah." "Must be nice. Being so important." "It's not‚ÄîI'm not‚Äî" He ran his hand through his hair. It stood up at strange angles. "It's just because of the thing with Madeleine." "I don't know who that is." "My ex. She was in that Netflix thing. With the horses." "I don't have Netflix." He stared at her. "Everyone has Netflix." "I have books." Mrs. Pritchard snorted. "She's got Netflix. Saw her watching that thing with the murders on her phone last week." Cerys felt her face heat. "That was research." "Course it was, love." Mrs. Pritchard shuffled toward the door. "Ta-ra then. Try not to break anything else, tall boy." The bell jangled. The photographers perked up, then deflated when they saw her. Rhys was rolling up his sleeves, apparently settling in. His forearms were ridiculous. Like someone had designed them specifically to make sleeves look restrictive. Cerys realized she was staring. He noticed her noticing. They both looked away. "So," he said. "The mining book." "You don't want the mining book." "I might." "It's ¬£45." "Bargain." "And the poetry you destroyed?" He looked at the scattered books. "All of them?" "You break it, you buy it." He calculated. She could actually see him doing maths. "How much?" "¬£73. Including the mining." He pulled out his wallet. Black. Expensive. Slightly too shiny. "Do you take cards?" "Machine's broken." It wasn't. He counted out cash. New twenties that looked like play money. "Keep the change." "That's a ¬£7 tip." "For the cat. Trauma counseling." This time she did smile, just slightly. He caught it, looked absurdly pleased with himself. The photographers were getting restless. One knocked on the window. Rhys gave them a very specific hand gesture. "Charming," Cerys said. "Sorry. They bring out the worst in me." "This isn't the worst?" "This is me trying very hard to be likeable." "How's that working out?" He looked at her, then at the destroyed poetry section, the mining book he didn't want, the photographers outside. "Honestly? I've had better days." The admission was unexpected. Real. For a moment, neither of them said anything. Then his phone rang. The Superman theme. He winced. "I should‚Äîit's my manager." She waved him toward the stockroom. He disappeared again. She heard his voice change‚Äîsmoother, more American somehow. "Simon! Yeah, small hiccup..." Cerys picked up the scattered poetry. One had his wet handprint on the cover. She should have been annoyed. Instead, she found herself checking if his number might be there somewhere. It wasn't. But he'd left his jacket behind. Definitely on purpose.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 1)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter successfully establishes the meet-cute scenario with genuine awkwardness and charm. The writing demonstrates strong command of dialogue-driven storytelling, with each character maintaining a distinct voice throughout. Rhys's desperate-to-please energy comes through in his overlapping speech patterns and cultural fumbling, while Cerys's dry, defensive responses create effective contrast. The physical comedy works well - the knocked-over poetry display, the head-banging on the till, and the photography situation all feel organic rather than forced. The author handles the attraction subtly, showing it through specific moments like Cerys noticing his forearms and the mutual awareness of her staring, rather than declaring it outright. Character consistency is strong. Rhys embodies the insecure performer perfectly - his bad Welsh, desperate name-dropping, and eagerness to help Mrs. Pritchard all serve his need for approval. Cerys maintains her prickly exterior while showing glimpses of interest, staying true to her profile as someone defensive about her circumstances. The Welsh setting feels authentic without being heavy-handed. The language barrier joke works effectively, and details like Mrs. Pritchard and the village atmosphere ground the story convincingly. Some dialogue could be tighter - occasionally characters explain things that could be implied. The mining book joke runs slightly long. However, these are minor issues in an otherwise well-crafted opening that establishes character dynamics, setting, and conflict efficiently. The chapter follows both the writing prompt and planned structure faithfully while maintaining narrative momentum. The ending with the forgotten jacket provides a natural hook without feeling contrived. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Compelling Plot: 15 Coherent: 18 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 5 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 6 Amateurish: 4 Purple Prose: 3 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Characters Consistent with Profile: 18 Followed Chapter Plan: 19 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 18

Chapter 2

Ok now chapter 2. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
# Chapter 2: The Apology Tour Wednesday. 10:47 am. He was back. "Bore da!" Rhys announced, shouldering through the door with a coffee tray. "That's good morning. I looked it up." "It's nearly eleven," Cerys said, not looking up from her accounts. The numbers were depressing. The numbers were always depressing. "Still morning though." He set a cup in front of her. "Oat milk latte. Extra shot." She stared at it. "I drink tea." "Tea?" "Builder's. Three sugars." "Who drinks three sugars?" "People who like sugar." He deflated slightly, then rallied. "Prynhawn da, then. Good afternoon. For later." His pronunciation made it sound like he was choking. She winced. "Please don't." "I'm trying to reconnect with my roots." "Your roots are in Merthyr. They speak English in Merthyr." "They speak Welsh too." "Do they though?" He picked up the untouched latte, took a sip himself. Made a face. "Christ, that's awful. How do people drink oat milk?" "Vegans, mostly." "Are you vegan?" "I was eating a cheese sandwich yesterday." "Right. Yes." He wandered over to her desk, peered at the spreadsheet. "That's a lot of red." She slammed the laptop shut. "Did you just come for your jacket?" "My jacket?" "The one you deliberately left." "I didn't‚Äî" He stopped. Grinned. "Fine. But also to apologize. Properly. For yesterday." "You already apologized. With money." "That was transactional. This is heartfelt." He pressed his hand to his chest dramatically, then dropped it. "Sorry, that was wanky. I'm nervous." "Why?" "You make me nervous." "I'm literally nobody." "You're not‚Äîthat's not‚Äî" He picked up a book from her desk. Put it down. Picked it up again. "Can I help? With something? Anything? I could sign books. For an event or something." "Why would anyone want you to sign books you didn't write?" "People are weird? I signed a woman's arm once. At a Tesco." "Was it your autobiography?" "I haven't written one." "Shocking." He laughed. "You're mean. I like it. Everyone's usually so‚Äî'Oh Rhys, you're wonderful, tell us about the helicopter scene again.'" "The helicopter scene was ridiculous." His face lit up. "You saw it?" "Ten minutes on someone's phone. Over their shoulder. On a train." "That still counts." He was absurdly pleased. "What else have you seen?" "The one where you're a rogue detective." "Death Warrant or Final Justice?" "There's two?" "Three actually. Final Justice 2: No Appeal comes out at Christmas." "Catchy." "It's shit. They're all shit." He said it cheerfully, like discussing weather. "But the helicopter one‚ÄîSkyfire‚Äîthat was based on a book." "No it wasn't." "It was! Michael Crichton. Well, 'inspired by.'" "That's not the same as based on." "The main character reads. In one scene. He's holding a book." "A book you clearly never opened, since you spent the whole film shirtless shooting people." "You watched more than ten minutes." She'd watched all of it. Twice. Once drunk with Sian. "It was ambient noise while I did inventory." "Inventory must have taken two hours and eighteen minutes then." "There's a lot of books here." He was grinning now, moving closer to her desk. That cologne again. Why did he have to smell so unnecessarily good? "I could help," he said. "With inventory." "Can you alphabetize?" "I know the alphabet." "All of it?" "Most of it. The important bits." A delivery van pulled up outside. The driver started unloading boxes. Heavy ones. "Shit," Cerys muttered. "My back's still fucked from yesterday." Rhys was already moving. "I've got it." "You don't‚Äî" But he was out the door, chatting to the driver, lifting boxes like they weighed nothing. His t-shirt rode up when he reached for the highest one. She absolutely did not notice the strip of skin above his jeans. "Where do these go?" He was holding three boxes at once. Showing off. "Stockroom. Carefully. They're books, not weights." He disappeared into the back. No crash this time. He was learning. They developed a rhythm‚Äîhim bringing boxes, her checking invoice numbers, him talking constantly about nothing. His last film shoot in Bulgaria ("Everyone got food poisoning except me because I only ate McDonald's"). His mother ("She asks when I'll be in something clever, like Poirot"). His trainer in LA ("Nazi with a six-pack"). "You don't have to narrate everything," she said, but not unkindly. "Sorry. I talk when I'm nervous." "You're still nervous?" "Bit, yeah." "Why?" He set down the last box. Rubbed his jaw. "You don't like me." "I don't know you." "But you don't like what you know." "I didn't say that." "You didn't have to. You've got one of those faces. Every thought just..." He gestured at her face. "Right there." She touched her cheek self-consciously. "I do not." "You're thinking right now that I'm an arrogant prick who can't act." She wasn't. She was thinking about his forearms again. "I'm thinking you talk too much." "Same thing really." "It's not." They stood there, him sweating slightly from the boxes, her clutching her invoice list. The shop felt smaller with him in it. "I should go," he said but didn't move. "Your jacket's behind the counter." "Right. My jacket." He retrieved it, found a pen in the pocket, wrote something on a bookmark. "My number. In case you need... more boxes moved. Or alphabetizing. Or someone to watch Skyfire with and point out all the plot holes." "That would take longer than the film." "See? You did watch it properly." She took the bookmark. His handwriting was terrible. "This could be anyone's number." "07799..." "I can read it." "Can you though? That might be a three. Or an eight." "It's a three." "Is it?" She looked closer. It definitely wasn't a three. "Fine, it's an eight." He backed toward the door, knocked into a display. Caught it. "I'm usually much cooler than this." "I don't believe you." "Fair." He paused at the door. "The coffee's still here." "I don't drink coffee." "I know. But maybe..." He shrugged. "Tomorrow you might." After he left, she sat at her desk, staring at the numbers that still didn't add up. Picked up the latte. Cold now. Took a sip. Still awful. But she drank it anyway, and hated herself for finding his desperate need for her approval endearing. She was thirty-four, for Christ's sake. Not fifteen. Her phone buzzed. Sian: "Mum says Rhys Morgan was in your shop AGAIN!!!! DETAILS NOW." Cerys turned it face down. Picked up the bookmark with his terrible handwriting. Definitely an eight.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 2)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter succeeds admirably at building romantic tension through believable awkwardness and authentic character interaction. The model follows its own plan quite faithfully while staying true to the original prompt's requirements. The dialogue feels genuinely natural, with each character maintaining a distinct voice. Rhys's desperate need for approval comes through in his over-eager Welsh attempts and constant chatter, while Cerys's dry wit and reluctant attraction are well-balanced. The coffee/tea miscommunication is a perfect small detail that shows he's trying but doesn't really know her yet. The romantic chemistry builds organically through physical proximity (the box-moving scene) and verbal sparring about his films. The model avoids the trap of making their banter too perfect or witty - instead, it feels like real people fumbling toward connection. Cerys's internal contradiction (claiming she only watched ten minutes while clearly having seen the whole film) is particularly well-executed. Character consistency is strong throughout. Rhys's nervous talking, physical confidence paired with emotional insecurity, and desperate charm offensive all align with his profile. Cerys's defensive posture, secret attraction, and practical concerns about money feel authentic to her character. The writing avoids purple prose and forced metaphors, keeping the tone light and conversational. The humor emerges naturally from character rather than forced wit. The pacing allows for both the romantic tension and practical mundanity of running a struggling bookshop. Small weaknesses include some slightly predictable beats (the deliberate jacket-leaving, the number exchange) and occasional moments where the romantic comedy formula shows through. However, these don't significantly detract from what is otherwise naturalistic character work. The chapter successfully advances the relationship while maintaining the central dynamic of his neediness versus her resistance, building anticipation for future developments. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Compelling Plot: 15 Coherent: 18 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 7 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 2 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Characters Consistent with Profile: 18 Followed Chapter Plan: 17 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 17

Chapter 3

Ok now chapter 3. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
# Chapter 3: Thursday Night Mistake Thursday. 11:13 pm. Cerys was lying on the shop floor, surrounded by empty wine bottles and the remnants of book club. Three members this month‚Äîher, Sian, and Bethan from the post office who only came for gossip. "I'm just saying," Bethan slurred, horizontal on the Poetry section carpet. "His arms in that helicopter scene." "We're supposed to be discussing Hamnet," Cerys said. "Fuck Hamnet. Dead kid. Sad. Done. Now back to Rhys Morgan being in your shop." "Twice," Sian added, unhelpfully. "Mum counted." Cerys's phone sat on her stomach, rising and falling with her breathing. That bookmark with his terrible number had migrated to her pocket. Then her purse. Now her phone case. "We watched Skyfire," Bethan announced. "Instead of reading." "I noticed," Cerys said. "You defended it," Sian said. "You literally said the plot made sense if you didn't think about it." "I was drunk." "You're drunk now." This was true. The room had a pleasant spin to it. Mr. Darcy was sitting on her chest, purring aggressively. "Text him," Bethan said. "No." "Just text him," Sian said. "Something casual." "It's eleven at night." "So?" "Nothing casual happens at eleven at night." Her phone buzzed. Instagram notification. She opened it accidentally-on-purpose. Rhys had posted a story‚Äîhotel bar, Cardiff by the look of it. Glass of something amber. Caption: "Method acting for tomorrow (I play an alcoholic detective)." It was deleted ten seconds later. "He's in Cardiff," she heard herself say. "TEXT HIM," both women shouted. She typed: "Your handwriting is shit." Deleted it. Typed: "Watching Skyfire for book club." Sent it. "Oh my God," Sian squealed. "You did it." Three dots appeared immediately. Disappeared. Appeared again. "Please tell me you're joking." She typed back: "Bethan says your arms deserve an Oscar." "Bethan has excellent taste. The rest of me was robbed." "Your acting definitely was." "Harsh. True. But harsh. How pissed are you?" "Medium." "Scale of one to ten?" "Thursday." "That's not a number." "Seven. Maybe eight. We drank all the wine." "Book club sounds fun." "We didn't read the book." "What was it?" "Hamnet." "Shakespeare's kid?" "You know about Shakespeare's kid?" "I'm not completely thick." Bethan and Sian were reading over her shoulder now, breathing wine fumes onto her neck. "Call him," Bethan whispered. "Don't call him," Sian said. Her phone rang. "Shit," all three said. Cerys answered. "Hi." "Sorry, my finger slipped." His voice was rougher. Drinking voice. "Your finger slipped onto my contact and then onto the call button?" "Very slippery fingers. It's a medical condition." "Is it?" "No." She could hear bar noise behind him. Music. Voices. "Where are you?" "Cardiff. Hotel bar. Having a very sad drink alone because my co-star hates me." "Why?" "I might have said her dog looks like a Victorian child with consumption." "Does it?" "Absolutely. But apparently you're not supposed to say that." She laughed. Bethan gave her a thumbs up. Sian mouthed 'be cool.' "Where are you?" he asked. "Shop floor. Doing inventory." "At eleven at night? After seven drinks?" "Eight. And yes. Very important inventory." "Of what?" She looked around. "Contemporary fiction." "You're lying on contemporary fiction?" "Among it." "That sounds uncomfortable." "Mr. Darcy's here too." "The cat?" "No, the actual Mr. Darcy. Very disappointing in person." She heard him moving, the bar noise fading. A door opening. Wind. "Are you outside?" she asked. "Balcony. Room 412. In case you want to... I don't know. Throw rocks at me." "From Hay? That's a very long throw." "You could drive." "I'm Thursday drunk, remember?" "Right. Yes. Don't drive." Bethan and Sian had retreated to the corner, pretending not to listen while obviously listening. "Tell me about the worst film you've ever made," Cerys said, rolling onto her side. The cat protested, relocated. "Oh God. Venice Vengeance." "Never heard of it." "Direct to DVD. I play a rogue gondolier who's secretly CIA." "A rogue gondolier?" "With a heart of gold and a dark past." "Naturally." "There's a speedboat chase through the canals." "That seems impractical." "The speedboat explodes." "Of course it does." "While I'm jumping from it. Onto another speedboat. Which also explodes." "Why do you keep getting on exploding boats?" "Poor judgment? It's a theme in my life." She could hear him smoking. The little exhale. "Disgusting habit," she said. "I know. I'm quitting." "When?" "Tomorrow. Always tomorrow." They talked. About films (he'd never seen The Princess Bride, she was horrified). About sandwiches (he thought pickle was "aggressive," she thought his preference for hummus was "aggressively middle class"). About whether cats had accents. "Of course they do," she insisted, now in the History section. "Mr. Darcy's is very posh." "Mr. Darcy's a Welsh cat." "He's bilingual." "Can he say 'Llanfairpwllgwyngyllgogerychwyrndrobwllllantysiliogogogoch'?" "Can you?" "No. But I'm not claiming to be bilingual." "Your Wikipedia says you speak fluent Welsh." "You looked at my Wikipedia?" Fuck. "Bethan did." "Is Bethan there?" "No. She left. Ages ago." This was true. Both Sian and Bethan had left around midnight, making obscene gestures as they went. "So you're alone?" "Yes." "On your shop floor." "Yes." "Drinking." "Not anymore. Lying down. The ceiling has a weird stain. Like Italy. If Italy had water damage." "My ceiling has a chandelier. It's hideous." "Poor you." "I didn't mean‚Äî" "I know." Silence. But not uncomfortable. She could hear him breathing. Traffic below his balcony. "I should let you sleep," he said. "I'm doing inventory." "Right. The very important drunk inventory." "Critical to the business." "How's that going?" "I've counted to twelve. Several times." He laughed. Low and tired. "What time do you open?" "Nine." "Christ." "Yeah." "I could... bring you breakfast? Hangover breakfast?" "I don't eat breakfast." "Everyone eats breakfast." "I eat lunch at ten-thirty." "That's basically breakfast." "It's a sandwich." "Cheese and pickle?" He'd remembered. "Maybe." "I'll bring you a bacon sandwich. From that place on King Street." "I don't like bacon." "You're lying." She was. "Nine?" he asked. "I'll be here." "Good. Yes. Right." Neither hung up. "This is stupid," she said. "Very." "We should stop talking." "Absolutely." They kept talking. About nothing. Everything. She migrated to Travel Writing. Then Biography. Her phone was hot against her ear. "My battery's dying," she said. "Mine too." "We should‚Äî" "Yeah." At some point, one of them fell asleep. She woke at 3:47 am, phone dead, cheek stuck to a book cover. Charged it enough to see his last message, sent at 2:33 am: "you snore btw" Then: "it's quite cute" Then: "that's weird sorry" Then: "ignore that" Then: "fuck" She smiled at her phone like an idiot. Then remembered she'd have to see him in five hours. With a hangover. After snoring at him. "Fuck," she said to Mr. Darcy. Mr. Darcy yawned in Welsh.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 3)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter successfully executes the planned late-night phone conversation between Rhys and Cerys, maintaining the distinctive character voices and awkward chemistry established in earlier chapters. The writing follows the detailed chapter plan quite faithfully, hitting all the key beats: wine-drunk book club, texting that turns to calling, meandering conversation topics, and falling asleep on the phone. The character work is particularly strong. Cerys's internal contradictions come through well - defending Rhys's terrible film while drunk, then being mortified about it, oscillating between attraction and resistance. Her dry, deflecting conversational style ("Thursday" as a drunkenness scale) feels authentic and consistent with her established personality. Rhys maintains his desperate-to-please energy even over the phone, sharing embarrassing film stories and remembering small details about her (the cheese and pickle sandwich). The dialogue flows naturally and captures the slightly drunk, intimate randomness of a late-night conversation. The topics - worst films, sandwich preferences, whether cats have accents - feel genuine rather than constructed. The progression from texting to calling to talking for hours builds intimacy convincingly. The writing shows rather than tells throughout. We understand their growing connection through their willingness to share silly details and stay on the phone despite having nothing "important" to discuss. The physical details (Cerys moving around the shop floor, Rhys going to the balcony) ground the scene without being overwrought. The tone strikes an appropriate balance between lighthearted and genuinely romantic. The awkwardness feels earned rather than forced - these are two people who don't quite know how to navigate their attraction to each other. Some minor weaknesses: the pacing drags slightly in the middle conversation section, and a few moments feel slightly constructed (the convenient timing of his Instagram story). The supporting characters (Sian and Bethan) serve mainly as plot devices to encourage the phone call. Overall, this is competent romantic writing that serves its purpose in the larger narrative while maintaining character consistency and authentic dialogue. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 15 Compelling Plot: 13 Coherent: 18 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 5 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 8 Amateurish: 4 Purple Prose: 3 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Characters Consistent with Profile: 18 Followed Chapter Plan: 19 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 17

Chapter 4

Ok now chapter 4. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
# Chapter 4: Performance Issues Friday. 2:30 pm. Year 3 had arrived like a natural disaster. "Miss, why's the shop smell funny?" "Can we touch stuff?" "Ewan's eating a book!" "I'm not!" "You are!" Mrs. Hughes, their teacher, looked apologetic. "They're excited." Cerys had forgotten about the school visit. Completely. Until twenty-seven eight-year-olds thundered through her door. She was catastrophically hungover, surviving on Lucozade and spite. "Right," she started. "Everyone sit‚Äî" "I'll do it!" Rhys appeared from behind Poetry, wielding The Gruffalo like a weapon. He'd brought the bacon sandwich as promised, stayed for tea, helped with actual inventory. Been there all day, actually. Making himself useful. Making her notice things like how he hummed when concentrating. "You don't have to‚Äî" she began. "I'm an actor. I act." He was already in position, chair in the center of the carpet. "Sit down, yeah? I'm going to read you the best story." "Are you famous?" a girl with plaits asked. "Bit famous." "My dad says you're shit." "Sophie!" Mrs. Hughes gasped. "He does! He said 'that shit actor's in town.'" Rhys's smile tightened. "Your dad's got good taste." "I've never heard of you," a boy announced. "Me neither." "Me neither." "My brother says YouTubers are better than actors." Cerys watched Rhys shrink slightly. His fingers were white on the book. "Should we just‚Äî" she started. "A mouse took a stroll through the deep dark wood," he practically shouted, voice pitched weird, half-American, half-something else. The children stared. He tried a different voice for the fox. Cockney? Australian? Somehow both? The children exchanged looks. "You're doing it wrong," Sophie said. "There's no wrong way to read," Mrs. Hughes said. "There is and he's doing it." Rhys abandoned The Gruffalo. Grabbed another book. "What about superheroes?" "Boring." "For babies." "Do you know MrBeast?" "I was in a film with a helicopter," Rhys tried, desperate now. "And explosions." "Was it on YouTube?" "No, it was in cinemas‚Äî" "Then no one saw it." He stood up, actually started acting out an action scene. Full commitment. Sound effects. Mime-fighting invisible enemies. One child laughed. Not with him. At him. "Is he having a breakdown?" Sophie whispered, very loudly. "Do the helicopter bit," Cerys said suddenly. Everyone looked at her. "From Skyfire. Where you hang from the ladder." "You want me to..." "Hang from something. Be an idiot. They're eight. They like idiots." He looked around. Spotted the heavy-duty shelving. "If I die, my manager will sue you." "Your manager's a prick." "Miss said prick!" Ewan screamed, delighted. Chaos. Beautiful chaos. Rhys hauled himself up the shelving, hung from one arm, quoting his terrible dialogue: "Looks like this bird's about to fly!" The kids screamed with laughter. He was good at physical comedy, she realized. When he wasn't trying so hard. "Do more!" He did the bit where his parachute didn't open. Mime-plummeting. Crashed into beanbags they used for reading corner. Children piled on top of him. "Are you Cerys's boyfriend?" Sophie asked, sitting on his chest. "No," they both said. Too fast. Too loud. "Why not?" "Because‚Äî" "We're not‚Äî" "He's just‚Äî" "She doesn't‚Äî" The children watched this car crash with interest. "My mum says you need a boyfriend," Sophie told Cerys. "She says your eggs are getting old." "Your mum needs to mind her business." "She says that's impossible in Hay." Mrs. Hughes corralled them toward the door eventually, full of apologies and promises about "discussing appropriate questions." Rhys was sprawled in the beanbags still, sweating. "That was fucking humiliating." "You were good with them." "They thought I was pathetic." "They're eight. They think everyone over twelve is pathetic." "Do you want coffee?" He asked suddenly. "Proper coffee? Not the shit I brought yesterday?" "I have instant." "That's not coffee." "It's brown and caffeinated." "Low bar." They sat in her office‚Äîgenerous term for a cupboard with a desk. Knees touching under the narrow space. He made the instant coffee wrong‚Äîwater first, then powder. She didn't correct him. "The film bombed," he said suddenly. "Skyfire. Lost the studio forty million." "I know." "How?" "I have Google." "Right." He stared at his terrible coffee. "It was my fault. The director wanted someone else. Tom Hardy, actually. But I screen-tested better. Except I can't... I can't actually act. I just do the same thing. Charming rogue with a gun. That's it. That's all I've got." "You were in that period drama. With the bonnets." "Charming rogue with a horse." "The spy thing?" "Charming rogue with gadgets." "The one where you're a teacher?" "Charming rogue with a gradebook." He paused. "You've seen a lot of my films." "Insomnia." "All of them?" She drank her coffee to avoid answering. "You were different today. With the kids. When you stopped trying." "I'm always trying. That's the problem. I can't stop." He rubbed his jaw. "Madeleine said being with me was exhausting. Like dating a YouTube compilation of 'actor tries too hard.'" "That's specific." "She was very precise about my failings. Had a spreadsheet." "Actually?" "Colour-coded." Cerys laughed. He looked pleased. "I can't believe you quoted your own line," she said. "'This bird's about to fly' is iconic." "It's terrible." "I know." He shifted. Their knees pressed harder. "I've got three more films in contract. All the same. Charming rogue with various props." "What do you want to do?" "Theater, maybe? Something where the words matter. Shakespeare. Except I tried once and forgot my lines. Opening night. Just stood there. Two hundred people watching me say nothing." "What did you do?" "Took my shirt off." "Of course you did." "Got a standing ovation." "For taking your shirt off?" "It was a very good shirt removal." She was laughing properly now. He was too. The tiny office felt warmer. His hand was on the desk, close to hers. Not touching. Almost. Someone knocked on the door. They jumped apart like teenagers. Cerys banged her knee. Rhys spilled the terrible coffee. "Shit‚Äî" "Sorry‚Äî" Mrs. Pritchard's voice: "You've left the till open, love. And that child's definitely eaten some of that book. His mum wants a discount." Reality rushed back. The shop. The till. The real world where he was famous and she sold books for a living. "I should go," he said. "Okay." Neither moved. "I'm filming tomorrow. In Cardiff. More charming rogue business." "Right." "But Sunday?" "Sunday I do the accounts." "Sexy." "Devastatingly." He stood to leave. In the doorway: "I wasn't acting today. The trying too hard. That was just... me." "I know." "Is that worse?" She thought about it. "No. It's better. The real thing's always better than the performance." He looked at her for a long moment. "Yeah. It is." After he left, she sat in the coffee-stained office, thinking about his knee against hers and how badly he'd wanted those kids to like him. Sophie was right. He probably was having a breakdown. She was probably having one too.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 4)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter effectively executes a key turning point in the romance, where Rhys's polished facade completely crumbles in front of children who have no patience for his practiced charm. The writing captures the excruciating comedy of his failed performance while maintaining sympathy for his character. The dialogue is one of the chapter's strongest elements. The children's voices ring authentically brutal: "My dad says you're shit" and "Is he having a breakdown?" feel like genuine kid observations. Rhys and Cerys maintain their distinct voices throughout - his desperate over-enthusiasm ("I'm an actor. I act!") contrasting with her dry observations ("They're eight. They think everyone over twelve is pathetic"). The progression from public humiliation to private vulnerability works well structurally. Rhys's admission about his acting limitations feels earned after we've witnessed his spectacular failure with the kids. The physical proximity in the cramped office creates appropriate tension, and the interrupted moment when someone knocks maintains the slow-burn romance pacing. The chapter succeeds in showing rather than telling character development. Rhys's desperation comes through his actions - the increasingly frantic voice changes, the physical comedy, the climbing on shelves. Cerys's growing attraction is conveyed through small details like not correcting his coffee-making and her admission to watching his films. However, some moments feel slightly overwrought. The "Reality rushed back" transition is a bit heavy-handed, and occasionally the dialogue becomes too neat ("The real thing's always better than the performance"). The chapter also relies somewhat predictably on the "interrupted intimate moment" trope. The writing maintains good pacing and natural humor without forcing jokes. The children's brutal honesty provides genuine comedy that serves character development rather than existing purely for laughs. Rhys's vulnerability about his career failures creates authentic emotional weight. Minor weaknesses include some repetitive phrasing ("too fast, too loud" appears twice) and a few moments where the internal monologue becomes slightly explanatory rather than revelatory. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 15 Compelling Plot: 14 Coherent: 17 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 6 Amateurish: 4 Purple Prose: 3 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Characters Consistent with Profile: 18 Followed Chapter Plan: 19 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 17

# Chapter 5: Local Celebrity Tuesday. 7:45 pm. The Cross Keys smelled of thirty years of spilled beer and broken dreams. "He's not coming," Cerys said for the third time. "He literally just texted you," Sian said, arranging their answer sheets. "He texted 'be there in five' twenty minutes ago." "That's how men tell time." Gareth from the chip shop arrived with crisps. "Alright? We winning tonight?" "We've never won," Cerys said. "First time for everything." "We came last when the category was 'Fish and Chips.'" "That was rigged. Everyone knows curry sauce isn't traditional." The pub was filling up. Quiz night was serious business. The Quizlamic Extremists had a spreadsheet. Norfolk and Chance brought reference books. The Smarty Pints were already drunk. "Sorry, sorry‚Äî" Rhys burst through the door, rain-soaked, still in costume. "Fucking M4. Fucking sheep. Fucking‚Äîis that a sword?" He was wearing some sort of period military jacket. Brass buttons. Epaulettes. Tight trousers that were‚Äî "It's from the film," he said, catching her stare. "Didn't have time to change." "You look like a stripper," Gareth said cheerfully. "Naval theme?" "I'm playing Nelson." "Nelson had one arm." "Before that." "Still a stripper outfit." Rhys dropped into the seat beside Cerys. Too close. The jacket was still damp. He smelled like hairspray and fake smoke. "This is Gareth," Cerys said. "He runs the chippy." "Best battered sausage in Wales," Gareth said. "Doubt it," Sian muttered. "And this is my sister‚Äî" "Oh my God, you're actually him," Sian said. "I mean‚Äîhello. Normal hello. Not weird." "That was weird, Sian." "Shut up." Derek the quizmaster tapped the microphone. "Right, you lot. Phones away. No Wikipedia, Norfolk‚ÄîI can see you." "Team name?" Rhys whispered. "Quiz Pro Quo," Cerys said. "That's terrible." "It was that or Quizteama Aguilera." "Also terrible." "You're very judgmental for someone dressed like Captain Pugwash." "Round one," Derek boomed. "Geography." They were catastrophically bad. Rhys thought Uruguay was in Europe. Gareth insisted France was landlocked. Sian spelled Reykjavik with a Q. "We're losing to the team that's just three dogs in a trenchcoat," Cerys hissed. "Those aren't dogs," Gareth said. "That's the Williams brothers." "Round two. Science." Worse. Rhys drew a penis instead of a molecule. Claimed it was "abstract chemistry." "That's not a thing." "Could be." His hand found her knee under the table. Just resting there. Warm through her jeans. She didn't move away. Didn't acknowledge it. The quiz continued around this fixed point of contact. "Round three. Film and Television." Rhys came alive. "Finally. My moment." "Name the film: 'I'll be back.'" "Terminator," he whispered, writing fast. "Everyone knows that," Gareth said. "Which Terminator?" "Does it matter?" "There are six." "Six?" "And a TV series." He was right about everything. Directors, years, obscure sequels. His hand stayed on her knee, thumb moving slightly when he got excited about an answer. "You're Rain Man for shit films," Sian said, impressed. "It's my job." "Which film won Best Picture in 1994?" "Forrest Gump," Rhys said. "Beat Pulp Fiction. Travesty." "You weren't even born." "I was eight." "You're old," Gareth said. "Thirty-six isn't old." "It's dad age." "Jesus Christ." "Round four. History." They gave up. Rhys ordered shots. Then more shots. His hand moved higher on her thigh. Not suggestively. Absently. Like he'd forgotten it was there. "Which Welsh prince‚Äî" "Owain Glynd≈µr," Cerys said automatically. "You don't know the question." "It's always Owain Glynd≈µr." She was right. "We should get points for that," Rhys told Derek, too loud. "Psychic points." "Sit down, Nelson." "I have both arms!" "Not for long if you keep shouting." They came second to last. Beat only by the Williams brothers who might have been dogs. Outside, unexpected rain. Gareth ran for his van. Sian suddenly remembered an urgent appointment. "Very urgent. Elsewhere. Bye!" Subtle as bricks, her sister. They stood under the pub's leaking awning. Rhys swayed slightly. "You're pissed," Cerys observed. "Bit pissed. Medium pissed." "Thursday pissed?" "Tuesday pissed. Different scale." He turned to face her. Too close. "I should tell you something." "Okay." "I'm complicated." "I know." "No, like... properly complicated. Ex-girlfriend, career shit, managers, the whole... thing." "I know." "I live in Los Angeles." "I know." "I'm probably having some sort of breakdown." "Definitely." He laughed. Leaned closer. "You make me want to be less complicated." "That's a line from your Venice film." "Is it? Fuck. See? I can't even... I'm not good at real things." "This feels real." "Does it?" He was going to kiss her. She could see it happening‚Äîthe lean, the intent. She turned her head at the last second. His lips hit her ear. Warm breath, awkward angle. "Sorry‚Äî" "I don't do complicated," she said to his shoulder. "I'm not complicated." She laughed. Couldn't help it. "You're literally famous. That's the definition of complicated." "Only a bit famous." "You've been papped three times this week." "Twice. The third was just someone really interested in my coffee order." They stood there. Not kissing. Her ear was warm where his mouth had missed. His hand found hers. Their fingers didn't quite interlace. Just tangled. Confused. "I want to kiss you," he said. "Properly. Not... ear kissing." "Ear kissing isn't a thing." "Could be. New trend." "Started by you?" "I'm an innovator." An old man emerged from the pub, looked at them. "You're that actor. The one who can't act." "That's me," Rhys agreed. "Thought so. You're better looking in person." "Thanks?" "Still can't act though." He wandered off. They laughed. Tension broke and reformed differently. "Walk me home?" Cerys asked. "Yes. Good. Walking." They walked badly. Rhys kept listing left in his Nelson jacket. She kept not quite taking his arm. The rain was persistent, Welsh rain, more mist than drops. At her shop door, he said, "I want to do this right." "There's no right." "Less wrong then." "That's achievable." "Sunday?" "I told you, accounts." "Monday?" "Stock take." "Tuesday?" "You're very available for someone famous." "I'm method acting unemployment." She unlocked the door. Paused. "Tuesday maybe." "Maybe?" "Probably maybe." He grinned. Swayed. Caught himself on the doorframe. "I should go before I fall over." "Very sexy." "I'm extremely sexy. The coat says so." "Go home, Nelson." "I don't have a home. Just hotels." It was meant to be flippant. Came out sad. They both heard it. "Tuesday," she said firmly. "Tuesday." He did a terrible salute, walked backward into a lamppost, recovered with surprising grace. She watched him weave down the street, period costume dark with rain. Her ear was still warm. Her thigh still felt his hand. Inside, Mr. Darcy gave her a look. "Shut up," she told him. She made cheese on toast at midnight, checked her phone forty times. No message. Then at 1 AM: "home save. SAFE. home safe. got an uber. driver recognized me. gave me two stars. fair tbh." Then: "your ear smells nice." Then: "weird sorry." She turned off her phone. Turned it back on. Typed: "Tuesday." Deleted it. Typed it again. Sent it. Three dots immediately. "tuesday tuesday tuesday tuesday" "Go to sleep." "can't. wearing nelson coat to bed. buttons complicated." "That's not my problem." "could be though" She turned the phone definitely off. Smiled at her ceiling like an idiot. Tuesday.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 5)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter effectively captures the awkward romantic tension between Rhys and Cerys in the pub quiz setting. The writing demonstrates solid character work, particularly in maintaining the established dynamic where Rhys's desperate need for approval creates genuine chemistry with Cerys's resistance to his charm. The pub quiz setting works well as a vehicle for character development. Rhys's expertise in film trivia while failing at everything else reinforces his insecure performer persona, while his casual physical contact (hand on knee) creates believable romantic tension. The dialogue feels natural and differentiated - Sian's sisterly ribbing, Gareth's oblivious commentary, and the main characters' verbal sparring all ring true. The chapter's strength lies in its authentic awkwardness. The missed kiss moment is particularly well-executed - Cerys turning her head so his lips hit her ear feels genuinely clumsy rather than manufactured cute. The subsequent conversation about complications has realistic rhythm, with both characters acknowledging the obvious obstacles while still being drawn to each other. The writing maintains good pace and energy throughout, though some transitions feel slightly rushed. The secondary characters serve their purpose without overwhelming the central dynamic. The text messages at the end provide a satisfying emotional resolution while maintaining the established character voices. However, the chapter occasionally relies on predictable romantic beats - the convenient sister disappearing, the walk in the rain, the doorstep moment. While executed competently, these don't add much freshness to the genre. Some descriptions border on functional rather than vivid, and a few comedic moments (the Nelson costume joke) feel slightly forced. The chapter successfully advances the relationship while maintaining the core tension between Rhys's public persona and private vulnerability. The writing demonstrates good technical control and character consistency, creating an engaging if not groundbreaking romantic scene. Chapter 6

Model Output:
# Chapter 6: Damage Control Wednesday. 8:47 am. Cerys woke to thirty-seven WhatsApp messages and a headache where her dignity used to be. "LOOK AT THE DAILY MAIL" "OH MY GOD" "MUM KNOWS" "CHECK TWITTER" "IS THAT HIS TONGUE???" She sat up too fast. Rhys's arm fell off her waist. He was wearing her uncle's Wales rugby shirt and nothing else, face mashed into her pillow, snoring. Her phone rang. Unknown number. "Don't answer that," he mumbled into cotton. She answered it. "IS THIS CERYS DAVIES?" "Who's‚Äî" "DAILY MAIL. CAN YOU CONFIRM‚Äî" She hung up. It rang immediately. "Turn it off," Rhys said, pulling a pillow over his head. She opened Twitter. Mistake. The photos were everywhere. Him at the pub in that ridiculous Nelson jacket. Her laughing. His hand on her thigh (when did that happen?). Then grainier ones‚Äîthem against her fridge, her hands in his hair, his mouth on her neck. "Fuck." "Hmm?" "We're on the internet." He sat up, shirt riding up. Grabbed her phone. "Oh." "Oh? That's it?" His phone started ringing. Simon's name flashing. "Don't‚Äî" she started. He answered. She could hear shouting from across the room. "WHAT THE FUCK WERE YOU THINKING?" "Simon‚Äî" "WELSH BOOKSHOP OWNER? ARE YOU TAKING THE PISS?" "She has a name‚Äî" "I DON'T CARE IF SHE'S PRINCESS FUCKING DIANA‚Äî" Rhys held the phone away from his ear. "He's upset." "I got that." "THIS IS PERFECT!" Simon's voice changed. "Local girl, wholesome, salt of the earth‚Äî" "I'm right here," Cerys said loudly. "Is that her? Brilliant. Love the accent. Very authentic." "I'm hanging up," Rhys said. "DON'T YOU DARE‚Äî" He hung up. Turned off his phone. "Sorry." "He seems nice." "He's actually worse in person." She scrolled through the photos. They looked... intimate. Happy. Her hand on his chest. Him looking at her like‚Äî "I look drunk," she said. "You were drunk." "I wasn't that drunk." "You tried to speak Welsh." "I can speak Welsh." "You told me my arse was like two eggs in a hanky." "That's... that's not what I said." "It's what it sounded like." Someone knocked on the door downstairs. Then again. Harder. "Customers?" he asked hopefully. She checked the shop's Instagram. Forty-three messages. Someone had found her personal Facebook. Her mum's Facebook. "Oh God, my mum." Her phone rang. Mum. "Don't‚Äî" She answered. Had to. "Cerys Ann Davies." "Mum‚Äî" "Mrs. Henderson saw the photographs." "Which Mrs. Henderson?" "All of them. They have a WhatsApp group." Rhys was getting dressed, hopping into his period military trousers. Still no pants, she noticed. Then felt weird for noticing. "I have to go, Mum." "Sian says he's there." "Sian doesn't know anything." "She's outside." Cerys looked out the window. Sian waved from the street, holding coffee and what looked like crisis pastries. "I'm not opening the shop today," Cerys decided. "You have to open. It's Wednesday." "Nobody cares if a bookshop's closed on Wednesday." More knocking. Rhys peered out. "There's quite a lot of people." She looked. Photographers. Actual customers. Mrs. Pritchard with her Wednesday crime novel. "Fuck." "We could go out the back?" he suggested. "That's an alley. With bins." "Romantic." "This isn't funny." "It's a bit funny." He was buttoning the jacket wrong. Gave up. "Look, we just... go down. Act normal." "Normal? You're in a Nelson costume doing the walk of shame." "It's not shame. It's... historical romance." "That's worse." Her phone buzzed. The shop phone started ringing downstairs. "I fucked it up," he said suddenly. "This is my fault." "It takes two people to‚Äî" "No, I mean... I knew they were following me. Since Sunday. Should have been more careful." "You knew?" "They always are. Part of the... thing." She stared at him. "So you knew when you came to the pub?" "Yes." "When you put your hand on my leg?" "I wasn't thinking about‚Äî" "When you came back here?" "Cerys‚Äî" She stood up. Started dressing properly. Angrily. "Right. Got it." "It's not like that." "Bit like that though." "I didn't plan this." "Just happened to be photographed. Just happened to be good PR." "That's not‚Äî" His phone was ringing again, silent but insistent. "I don't care about PR." "Your manager does." "He's a prick." "He's your prick." "That sounds wrong." "You know what I mean." They stood there, half-dressed, phones screaming, the world pressing in through thin windows. "I like you," he said. "Actually like you. Not PR like. Real like." "That's very articulate." "I'm not good at this." "At what?" "Real things. Actual feelings. Without scripts." Someone got the shop door open downstairs. The bell jangled. "Cerys?" Mrs. Pritchard's voice. "You've got a situation out here, love." "Fuck." She headed down. He followed. The shop was chaos. People with cameras. Actual customers confused by the fuss. Mrs. Pritchard holding court by Crime, telling someone Rhys was "adequate at best." "We're closed," Cerys announced. "It's Wednesday," Mrs. Pritchard said. "Emergency closure." "Gas leak," Rhys added helpfully. "You don't smell gas," someone said. "Silent gas," he tried. "That's not a thing." Cerys physically herded people out. Locked the door. Pulled down the blind that had never worked properly and still didn't. "Well," Mrs. Pritchard said, still inside somehow. "You've made a mess of this." "Thanks for the insight." "He's still too tall for you." "I'm right here," Rhys said. "I know, love. Hard to miss in that outfit." She left through the back, tutting. They stood in the empty shop. Phones still ringing. Someone knocked again. "I should go," he said. "Yeah." "I'll fix this." "Sure." "Cerys‚Äî" "Just go." He went to the back door. Stopped. "Last night was‚Äî" "A mistake?" "I was going to say nice." "Nice?" "Really nice." After he left, she sat on the floor behind the counter. The shop felt wrong. Invaded. Her phone buzzed. Sian: "Mum wants you for dinner. Bringing wine. And questions. So many questions." Then: "He looked proper fit in that jacket though." Then: "Your ear thing made the Mail Online." She turned off her phone. Made a sandwich. Cheese and pickle. It tasted like disappointment. At 4pm, she heard someone at the back door. Rhys, holding terrible coffee and good wine. "Silent gas emergency over?" "Apparently." They sat on her back steps. Drank wine from mugs. He'd changed into normal clothes. Still looked absurd. "My ex called me pathetic," he said. "For hiding in Wales with my 'shop girl.'" "Shop girl?" "Her words." "Charming." "She's actually quite charming. When she's not being a massive‚Äî" His phone rang. He threw it into the bins. "That was dramatic." "I'm an actor. We're dramatic." "You can't act though." "Exactly. So I'm just dramatic for no reason." She laughed despite herself. He shifted closer. "Don't," she said. "I'm not." "You are." His hand found hers. "This is just hand stuff. Not complicated." "Everything with you is complicated." "My left hand isn't complicated. Very straightforward, my left hand." Her phone buzzed. Sian: "MUM KNOWS ABOUT THE TONGUE THING." "Kill me," Cerys said. "That seems extreme." "My mother knows about your tongue." "My tongue's famous. It's been in films." "Saying words." "Sometimes." They sat there, holding hands like teenagers, the world shouting through their phones. "I don't know how to do this," she said. "Neither do I." "You literally date actresses." "Dated. Past tense. And that was just... posing next to each other at things." "That's not dating?" "Apparently not." The sun was setting. The bins smelled terrible. His thumb was doing something devastating to her palm. "Tuesday seems very far away now," she said. "We missed Tuesday. It's Wednesday." "I meant next Tuesday." "That's eight Tuesdays away." "That's not how days work." "Feels like it." Someone knocked on the front door again. They ignored it. "We could try this," she said carefully. "But I don't know how." "Try what?" "Whatever this is." "Hand stuff?" "Stop calling it that." He turned to face her properly. Nelson jacket gone but something in his eyes that made her stomach flip. "We could just... see what happens," he said. "That's not a plan." "I don't have a plan. My plans involve explosions and terrible dialogue." "And gondolas." "One gondola. Singular." She kissed him. Badly. Noses bumped. He laughed into her mouth. "Smooth," he said. "Shut up." "Make me." "That's definitely from one of your films." "Probably." They kissed better the second time. Until her phone rang. Mum again. "Dinner," Cerys sighed. "In an hour." "I should come." "That's a terrible idea." "I'm good with parents." "No you're not." "I'm not. But I should come anyway." "You'll make it worse." "Definitely. But in a charming way." She looked at him. Period costume ruined, hair ridiculous, trying so hard it hurt to watch. "Fine. But you're not wearing that." "I've got a shirt in the bins now." "Why‚Äînever mind." They stood to go inside. He stopped her. "This is probably a disaster," he said. "Definitely." "But a good disaster?" "That's not a thing." "Could be." Her phone buzzed. Sian: "MUM'S MADE WELSH CAKES. SHE ONLY DOES THAT FOR PROPER BOYFRIENDS." "Oh God," Cerys said. "What?" "Welsh cakes." "Is that code?" "It's worse. It's hope."
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 6)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter successfully captures the chaotic aftermath of a paparazzi exposure while maintaining the established character dynamics and romantic tension. The writing demonstrates strong adherence to both the overall prompt and the specific chapter plan, incorporating all the key plot points including the photo scandal, Simon's angry phone call, media attention at the shop, and the progression toward meeting Cerys's family. The dialogue is particularly strong, with each character maintaining their distinct voice. Rhys's desperate charm and tendency toward dramatic gestures ("He threw it into the bins") contrasts effectively with Cerys's dry observations and practical nature. The banter feels natural rather than overly polished, which suits these characters who are supposed to be awkward with each other. Lines like "Silent gas emergency over?" and the back-and-forth about his tongue being "famous" strike the right balance of humor and genuine connection. The chapter excels at showing rather than telling emotional states. Cerys's mortification comes through in her actions (angrily dressing, physically herding people out) rather than exposition. Similarly, Rhys's vulnerability emerges through small details like "trying so hard it hurt to watch" and his admission about not being good at "real things." Character consistency is strong. Rhys maintains his desperate need for approval while showing genuine care for Cerys, exemplified in his offer to "fix this" and his insistence on meeting her parents despite knowing it's a bad idea. Cerys stays true to her defensive nature while allowing herself moments of vulnerability, particularly in the hand-holding scene and her decision to let him come to dinner. However, there are some minor weaknesses. Occasionally the narrative voice becomes slightly inconsistent, shifting between close third person limited and a more omniscient perspective. Some of the humor feels slightly forced, particularly around the Nelson costume and the "tongue thing" running gag. The social media chaos, while realistic, sometimes feels like it's being used primarily for plot convenience rather than organic character development. The emotional authenticity is generally strong, particularly in moments like Rhys's confession about his ex calling him pathetic and Cerys's realization about the invasion of her private space. The progression from anger to tentative reconciliation feels earned rather than rushed. The writing avoids purple prose and forced metaphors, maintaining a conversational tone that suits the characters and setting. The Welsh cultural elements feel authentic rather than tokenistic, and the small-town dynamics ring true. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Compelling Plot: 15 Coherent: 17 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 6 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 7 Amateurish: 5 Purple Prose: 3 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 4 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Characters Consistent with Profile: 18 Followed Chapter Plan: 18 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 17

Chapter 7

Ok now chapter 7. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
# Chapter 7: Terrible Timing Saturday morning. 7:23 am. Rhys was destroying her kitchen. "That's not how you make scrambled eggs," Cerys said from the doorway. "It's exactly how you make them." He was wearing her uncle Dai's rugby shirt. Nothing else. Wielding a spatula like a weapon. "The pan's too hot." "It's fine." "They're turning grey." "That's the desired color." "Of eggs?" "My eggs." She watched him scrape what looked like rubber into two bowls. He'd used all six eggs. The milk was out, going warm. Sugar in the salt cellar‚Äîshe could tell from here. "Delicious," she lied, taking a bite. "You don't have to eat it." "No, it's... interesting." "Interesting?" "Textured." They were being so careful. Like the last three days hadn't happened. Like her mother hadn't interrogated him over Welsh cakes. Like they hadn't spent Thursday and Friday hiding in her flat, phones off, pretending the world didn't exist. "My flight's at noon," he said to his eggs. "Right." "From Bristol." "That's good. Close." "Two hours." "Better leave at nine then." "Half nine maybe." Neither of them looked at each other. The eggs sat between them, accusatory. Someone knocked. They both froze. "It's seven in the morning," she said. "Maybe they'll go away." More knocking. Then: "I know you're in there. I can smell burning." Her mother. "Fuck," they said together. "I'll get dressed," he said, but her mother was already using her spare key. "Cerys? I've brought casserole for‚Äîoh." She stopped in the doorway. Rhys in the rugby shirt. Cerys in his t-shirt from yesterday. The murdered eggs. "Morning, Mrs. Davies," Rhys said, pulling the shirt down. It didn't help. "That's Dai's shirt." "I... yes." "He died in that shirt." "Mum, he didn't die in it." "Watching rugby. Same thing." She set down a casserole dish. Enormous. "Cawl. For your drive." "That's kind," Rhys said. "It's not for you. You probably don't eat real food." She looked at the eggs. "I can see that." "Mum‚Äî" "Mrs. Henderson saw you yesterday. In Tesco. Buying wine." "People buy wine." "Three bottles." "It was on offer." "Hmm." She was opening cupboards now. Tutting. "No proper tea. What's this? Chamomile? Are you ill?" "It's calming," Rhys said. "Are you nervous?" "Currently? Yes." She turned to really look at him. "You're leaving." Not a question. "I have work. In LA. Reshoots." "Reshoots," she repeated. Like he'd said 'puppy murdering.' "I'll be back." "When?" "Soon." "Soon." She looked at Cerys. "He says soon." "I heard." "Men always say soon." "Mum‚Äî" "Your father said soon. Went to get milk. Came back three days later from Ibiza." "That was different‚Äî" "Had a sunburn. In February." Rhys was backing toward the bedroom. "I should... trousers." He fled. Her mother sat down. "He seems nice." "Mum‚Äî" "Bit stupid. But nice." "He's not stupid." "He put sugar in your salt." "How do you‚Äînever mind." "His films are terrible." "I know." "Sian made me watch one. The gondola one." "Oh God." "Ninety minutes I'll never get back." They sat in silence. Could hear Rhys dropping things in the bedroom. "You like him," her mother said. "It's complicated." "It's not. You like him or you don't." "He lives in Los Angeles." "And?" "And I live here." "Planes exist." "It's not that simple." "It never is with you." Rhys emerged, dressed. Designer jeans that cost more than her monthly shop rent. The t-shirt she'd pulled off him yesterday. "I should go," he said. It was only 7:45. "Traffic," he added. "On Saturday?" "Sheep. Possibly." Her mother stood. "I'll leave you to it." At the door: "That casserole's for four people. Don't let him have any." She left. They stood in the kitchen, three feet and a lifetime apart. "Your mum's terrifying." "She likes you." "How can you tell?" "She didn't mention your height." He smiled. Weak but real. "I do have to go." "I know." "I'll call." "Time difference." "Text then." "Yeah." They were terrible at this. Both moving toward each other, stopping, starting again. "This is stupid," he said. "I'm coming back. Two weeks max." "Okay." "Maybe three." "Right." "There's awards season stuff. But after‚Äî" "It's fine." "It's not fine. This isn't‚Äî" He stopped. Started again. "I want this to be something." "It is something." "Something more than me fucking off to LA after three days." "Four days." "Does Wednesday count?" "Half a Wednesday." "So three and a half days." They were closer now. She could smell her shower gel on his skin. "This is going to be complicated," she said. "I know." "Properly complicated. Not rom-com complicated." "I know." "I don't know if I can do complicated." He touched her face. Thumb on her cheekbone. "We could try?" "That's not a plan." "I don't have a plan." "You never have plans." "I had one. Come to Wales, hide from photographers, meet nobody, leave." "How'd that work out?" "Fucking terribly." She kissed him. He tasted like terrible eggs and possibility. "I have to go," he said against her mouth. "You said that." "Still true." But they were moving backward, toward the bedroom. Her mother's casserole cooling on the counter. "You'll miss your flight." "There's others." "Your manager‚Äî" "Can fuck off." Later‚Äîmuch later‚Äîhe was actually leaving. 11:47. Definitely missing the flight. "There's a two-thirty," he said, throwing things in a bag. "You should go." "Going." "Now." "Yes." But he was kissing her again. Against the door. Her leg around his hip. "This is ridiculous," she breathed. "Very." A car horn outside. His Uber. "Fuck." He grabbed his bag. Stopped. "I'm coming back." "Okay." "I am." "I know." He didn't look convinced. Neither was she. At the door: "Keep the shirt." "The one your ex gave you?" "It looks better on you." "Everything looks better on me." "True." The horn again. "Go." He went. Came back. Kissed her hard. Left again. She watched from the window. He looked up, waved.
